Stoddard, Charles Hurt, Jonah GoldbergNEWSDomestic121101cb.254Border Wall Showdown; Google Grilling; Criminal Justice Reform Bill; Resolution on Khashoggi Killing; Russian Connection; Tariffied; French Peace Offering; Interview with French Ambassador to U.S. Gerard Araud; President Trump Meets with Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi to Discuss Government Funding Bill; Google CEO Testifies Before CongressBret Baier, Kevin Corke, Gillian Turner, Mike Emanuel, Peter Doocy, Catherine Herridge, Dan Springer

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: Well, she's looking great. But let me just say.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: She looks good.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: You're not allowed to say that -- Juan.

WILLIAMS: George H.W. Bush and now this woman --

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: They're braver than me, that's for sure.

WILLIAMS: I'm going to be like 65 shortly. I'm worried.

ORTAGUS: I know I wouldn't do it.

WILLIAMS: No, I don't want to go.

PERINO: Set your DVRs, everyone. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE. I mean why would you. It's amazing.

"SPECIAL REPORT" is up next. Hey, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Granny is very attractive. Thanks, Dana.

President Trump trades threats with congressional Democrats over shutting down the government.

The Google CEO takes center stage on Capitol Hill and takes heat from both political parties.

The French offer protesters a peace offering after weeks of violent protests. The French ambassador will joined me to explain the strategy going forward.

This is SPECIAL REPORT.

BAIER: Good evening. Welcome to Washington. I'm Bret Baier.

President Trump says he would be proud to shut down the government over the border wall. The Senate Minority Leader calls the wall threat a temper tantrum. The House Minority leader and possibly future Speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi says President Trump does not have the votes.

There are still ten days left for more political fireworks until the funding runs out for the government, at least partially. We'll explain that.

Correspondent Kevin Corke is at the White House tonight where the negotiations took place in the Oval Office and importantly on camera. Good evening -- Kevin.

KEVIN CORKE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret. Quite the afternoon here.

What was billed as a chance to work together to avoid a government shutdown and perhaps secure funding for the border wall quickly devolved into political mayhem here at the White House this afternoon with the President, as you pointed out, promising to shut down the government if he doesn't get funding for the wall.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I am proud to shut down the government for border security, Chuck. because the people of this country don't want criminals and people that have lots of problems and drugs pouring into our country.

So I will take the mantle. I will be the one to shut it down. I'm not going to blame you for it. The last time you shut it down, it didn't work. I will take the mantle of shutting down. And I'm going to shut it down for border security.

(CROSSTALK)

SENATOR CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: But we believe you shouldn't shut it down.

CORKE: It was a rare glimpse of the bare-knuckle battles that few outside Washington get to see. The President suggesting the Democrats would rather keep the border open than keep the government open. And Democrats accusing him of trying to force a shutdown.

TRUMP: We need border security, the wall is part of border security you can't have very good border security without the wall. No.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: That is (INAUDIBLE). That is a political term. Border security is a way to effectively honor or responsibility.

SCHUMER: And the experts say you can do border security without a wall which is wasteful and doesn't solve the problem.

TRUMP: It totally solves the problem.

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: And it's very important.

PELOSI: -- we came at a place to say how do we meet the needs of American people?

CORKE: Ahead of the meeting, the President made clear his intentions, repeatedly tweeting about the wall and the border, promising the wall get built.

TRUMP: I don't mind owning that issue. I mean Chuck's problem is that, you know, when we last closed down, that was his idea. And honestly, he got killed. And so he doesn't want to own it. And I said, you know what, rather than us debating who's owning it, I'll take it. I'll take it.

If we close down the country, I will take it because we are closing it down for border security. And I think I win that every single time.

CORKE: The latest Marist polls suggest a majority of Republicans prefer he dig in with 65 percent saying the President shouldn't compromise on the border wall even if it means a shutdown. But 56 percent of those surveyed including 71 percent of Democrats say he should.

SCHUMER: This Trump shutdown, this temper tantrum that he seems to throw, will not get him his wall and it will hurt a lot of people because he will cause a shutdown. He admitted he wanted a shutdown. It's hard to believe that he would want that.

CORKE: South Carolina GOP Senator Lindsey Graham is among those urging the President to stand his ground.

SENATOR LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I find it pretty hypocritical for the Democrats to deny the President $5 billion which could be well spent to help secure a border by having walls in places that make sense.

If I were the President, I would dig in on this. And I would also put DACA on the table and try to solve two problems at once.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: Bret -- as you know, the clock is ticking on both the President and the White House as well as congressional lawmakers. The government funding runs out December 21st at 11:59:59 p.m. after which real political and financial consequences will ensue -- Bret.

BAIER: Kevin Corke, live on the north lawn. Kevin -- thanks.

A district court judge ordered adult film star Stormy Daniels to pay President Trump almost $300,000 to cover three quarters of the President's attorney's fees. An additional thousand dollars was added in sanctions to punish Daniels for filing what the judge called a quote, "meritless defamation lawsuit".

Members of the House Judiciary Committee peppered the head of Google today, focused on potential bias and data collection.

Correspondent Gillian Turner reports on the tech giant's time on the hot seat at today's congressional hearing.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SUNDAR PICHAI, CEO, GOOGLE: I lead this company without political bias and work to ensure that the products continue to operate that way.

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Google CEO, Sundar Pichai faced a grilling in front of the House Judiciary Committee today, his first ever hearing on Capitol Hill. Knowing this might be their only face time with Google's chief for a long time, lawmakers came armed with a gigabyte's worth of accusations and questions.

At the top of Republicans' agenda, anti-conservative bias in the search engine.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: We need to be sure that any political bias within Google's workforce does not creep into its search product.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R), OHIO: So I've got really just one question for you -- why? Why did Google configure its features and pay for rides to the polls to get out the Latino vote only in key states?

TURNER: Democrats taking an opposing view. The leading Democrat on the Committee, Jerrold Nadler said political bias at Google is no big deal. And one Democrat even accused Google of an anti-liberal bias.

REP. STEVE COHEN (D), TENNESSEE: I put my name in here, RepSteveCohen@PunchNews. This weekend I was on MSNBC four times. And yet the first thing that comes up is the "Daily Caller", not exactly a liberal and I guess well-known group. Then Rollcall. Then Breitbart News. And I would like you to look into the overuse of conservative news organizations to put on liberal people's news on Google.

TURNER: Knowing he would be on the hot seat, Pichai came prepared to reassure lawmakers and armed with big promises. He told them "Google hasn't ever sold user data to third parties nor will it in the future".

But whether it was enough to allay their concerns over privacy is unclear.

REP. TED POE (R), TEXAS: So Google knows that I am moving over there. It's not a trick question. You know, you make $100 million a year.

REP. SHEILA JACKSON LEE (D), TEXAS: Would you commit to hearing to Article 12 or the declaration of human rights as it relates to protecting the privacy of individual e-mails?

PICHAI: We think privacy is an important individual rights. It's an important human right. And we are committed to upholding that.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TURNER: Pichai also addressed speculation about Project Dragonfly. That's Google's super secret project to develop a tailored search engine for China where the government have always censored online content. He confirmed Google spent months working on a prototype and insisted they have no plans to launch it. This was the company's first public acknowledgment of involvement, Bret, in this project.

BAIER: Interesting hearing today. Gillian -- thank you.

More on this with the panel.

While funding for the wall is causing political divisions, as you just saw, the parties seem to be coming together for criminal justice reform.

Chief congressional correspondent Mike Emanuel looks at that bill and the schedule ahead if Congress wants to pass it.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MIKE EMANUEL, FOX NEWS CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Majority leader Mitch McConnell says lawmakers will vote on a bipartisan package after President Trump pressured him to get it done.

SENATOR MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: The Senate will take up the recently revised criminal justice bill this month. I intend to turn to the new text as early as the end of this week.

EMANUEL: Pushing for cooperation, McConnell noted senators may need to work between Christmas and the New Year to complete it. In the Oval Office, with the top congressional Democrats, the President expressed his delight.

TRUMP: We have great Democrat support, great Republican support - so criminal justice reform something that people have been trying to get how long, Nancy -- many years.

PELOSI: Exactly.

TRUMP: Many, many years. EMANUEL: The bill would allow judges to reduce sentences for nonviolent drug crimes and eliminate some mandatory sentences. It also includes assistance to help inmate develop skills to cope when they get out of prison.

Democrats note this is the first criminal justice reform in a generation.

SENATOR DICK DURBIN (D), ILLINOIS: I've been at this for five years for criminal sentencing reform and I think we've reached that magic moment.

SENATOR CHRIS COONS (D), DELAWARE: I'm very excited. This is a bipartisan approach to criminal justice and sentencing reform. I have been honored to work with a wide range of bipartisan colleagues.

EMANUEL: Part of the McConnell's reluctance is the bill has divided the Senate GOP. Arkansas Republican Senator Tom Cotton likens it to a jailbreak.

SENATOR TOM COTTON (R), ARKANSAS: I don't think the Senate should vote to let carjackers and bank robbers out of prison. Maybe other senators do. That's their prerogative but I will have a lots of amendments to offer and they can make those choices.

EMANUEL: But South Carolina Republican Senator Lindsey Graham says it is smart legislation.

GRAHAM: This a great reform package, it allows people who have been incarcerated for a long time for nonviolent drug offenses to earn their way out of jail quicker by achieving a skill set that will allow them to stay out of jail.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EMANUEL: Republican Whip John Cornyn says the Senate could pass this measure in an afternoon with a little cooperation. Speaker Paul Ryan says the House will be prepared to act once the Senate gets it done -- Bret.

BAIER: Mike Emanuel, live on the Hill. Mike -- thanks.

Some Republican senators are pushing to break with the White House over the relationship with the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, specifically the Crown Prince there. Pushback at least in a symbolic way by the Senate.

Correspondent Peter Doocy reports from the Capitol Hill.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The U.S. Senate is ready to respond to a journalist's bloody murder with a resolution, condemning Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.

SENATOR BOB CORKER (R), TENNESSEE: My sense is it will pass and it will not affect policy.

DOOCY: That's not the point at least not right away.

GRAHAM: I think it's important for the Senate to get on the record that this was unacceptable and we hold MBS responsible for the murder. That's a big deal.

DOOCY: Progressive Democrats are on the same page.

SENATOR KAMALA HARRIS (D), CALIFORNI: Well, I think that we have to act.

DOOCY: Tomorrow's resolution is sponsored by Republican Senator Mike Lee and Independent Senator Bernie Sanders who writes, "The time is long overdue for the United States to stop following the lead of Saudi Arabia, a brutal regime that recently murdered a dissident journalist and has no respect for human rights."

That journalist, Jamal Khashoggi is now on the front page of "Time Magazine" after being named one of their people of the year.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is the first time we've ever chosen someone no longer alive.

DOOCY: Now, Khashoggi's old boss at the "Washington Post" Fred Ryan writes, "We hope this recognition will prompt our nation's leaders to stand up for America's values and hold accountable those who attempt to silence journalists who cover our communities or in Jamal's case an oppressive authoritarian government. But the White House warns that hopes for peace in the Middle East could crumble if Congress cracks down too hard.

JARED KUSHNER, TRUMP SENIOR ADVISOR: We're hoping to make sure that there is justice brought where that should be. We're focused now on the broader region which is figuring out how to hopefully bring a deal together between the Israelis and the Palestinians.

DOOCY: Outgoing foreign relations committee chairman Bob Corker just hopes whatever happens, happens before he retires.

CORKER: I think that Congress is going to deal with Saudi Arabia. And I want to be a part of that even though I'm leaving in a couple of weeks, I want to be a part of making sure that happens.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOOCY: Lawmakers are so eager to act here on the Senate side because the intelligence implicating certain Saudis in the murder is so strong. Now, House leaders want to see that intel. They will tomorrow morning, and then they will decide if they want to take further action -- Bret.

BAIER: Peter Doocy, live on the Capitol Hill. Peter -- thank you.

Search and rescue operations have stopped off the coast of Japan. The U.S. Military declared the five missing crewmembers dead after their refueling plane collided with a fighter jet last week. That brings the death toll of this accident up to six. One survivor is in stable condition tonight.

Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sent a message of condolences to President Trump. The cause of that crash remains under investigation.

U.S. prosecutors allege Maria Butina is a Russian spy. Vladimir Putin says he never heard of her before her arrest. Today Butina accepted a plea deal with an agreement to cooperate.

Chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge has details.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: According to a legal agreement reviewed by Fox News, Russian national Maria Butina will plead guilty to acting as an unregistered foreign agent for the Russian government. The deal includes a promise to cooperate, quote, "in any and all matters the government deems relevant.

The filing states quote, "Butina sought to establish unofficial lines of communications with Americans having power and influence over U.S. politics, for the benefit of the Russian Federation.

Prosecutors allege the 29-year-old targeted a gun rights organization sources say is the National Rifle Association along with an unidentified American. Sources say that American is a longtime Republican Party activist.

Court papers indicate Butina set up a trip to Moscow for NRA members and so-called friendship dinners with those she believed quote, "would have the ear of the next U.S. presidential administration."

The filing continues, "She was introduced to influential members of political party one -- one of whom announced his campaign to run for the presidency of the United States believe to be Candidate Trump.

The Butina case is separate from special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. Today the Russian President said his spy chiefs know nothing about Butina quote, "She risk 15 years in jail. For what", Putin said. "I asked all the heads of our intelligence services what is going on, nobody knows anything about her."

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERRIDGE: And late today a Kremlin aide reported Butina's father says she would never admit to crime she did not commit. Butina's lawyer unsuccessfully argued that she is a foreign student interested in American politics and better U.S.-Russia relations -- Bret.

BAIER: Catherine, meantime there was this status hearing today in the Paul Manafort case with an interesting development. What about that?

HERRIDGE: Well Bret -- the federal judge wants more information from special counsel investigators before deciding whether the President's former campaign chairman violated his plea agreement. The allegation is that Paul Manafort lied about his foreign contacts and communication with the administration.

The special counsel sentencing memos filed Friday were heavily redacted or blacked out to protect sensitive information. But the federal judge had full access to the evidence and still wants more information. A tentative court date has been set for the end of January but it's expected both sides will continue their private negotiations -- Bret.

BAIER: Catherine -- thank you.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

Up next, one local crop is being hit hard by the China tariffs. We'll have that.

And later the French ambassador joins us live to talk about the situation in his country.

First, what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 35 in Richmond, Virginia where a jury is recommending life in prison plus 419 years for James Alex Fields, the man convicted of first-degree murder for driving his car into counter protesters at a white nationalist rally last year in Charlottesville. The judge will make the final sentencing decision in March.

Fox 41 in Louisville, Kentucky where the statue of the founder of the "Louisville Journal" has been taken down. The mayor said George Prentiss used his position as a newspaper editor to push an anti-Catholic and anti- immigrant message that led to a riot in 1855 where at least 22 people were killed.

And this is a live look at Chicago from our affiliate, Fox 32. One of the big stories there tonight the startling quantity of illegal guns collected by law enforcement there. Chicago police say the number of firearms collected could top 10,000 by the end of the year. The 2018 tallies currently over 9,000 or more than one illegal guns seized per hour in Chicago.

That's tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT.

We'll be right back.

BAIER: This is a Fox News alert. A Canadian court has just granted bail to Meng Wanzhou while she awaits an extradition hearing. The judge made the deal subject to a guarantee of 10 million Canadian dollars -- about $7.5 million along with other conditions.

China warning Canada of consequences for her recent arrest. She is an executive of Huawei, the company under scrutiny and being looked by the U.S. and other countries. Tensions were already high after a former Canadian diplomat had been arrested while visiting Beijing. Canada's public safety minister did not draw a direct line between the two arrests but says the country is deeply concerned and is sparing no effort to look after his safety.

Meantime trade negotiations continue with China, there are some hopeful signs tonight. According to a source familiar with the conversations, China is going to roll back its auto tariffs eliminating the 25 percent surcharge. The move would bring the rate back down to 15 percent which is the level it was before the trade war began.

It was a mixed day on the markets today, the Dow dropped 53, the S&P 500 lost less than one, the Nasdaq gained 11.

This evening we look at the human toll here in the U.S. of Chinese tariffs. They are having a huge impact on one major industry in the Pacific Northwest.

Correspondent Dan Springer reports from Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DAN SPRINGER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: When it comes to the impact of Chinese tariffs on U.S. farm goods, sweet cherries are the canary in the gold mine. Unlike other commodities that can be stored, cherries are perishable. They are picked, packed and sold right away. Wen China's tariffs hit 50 percent last July right in the middle of the harvest, exports to China went from the most profitable to the pits. Growers in Washington State saw their bumper crop lose $86 million in value overnight.

MARK POWERS, NORTHWEST HORTICULTURAL COUNCIL: They are upset clearly. I mean they are patriotic. They want to do the right thing. They understand that there are problems with our trade relationship with China.

SPRINGER: Washington fruit and produce companies saw exports to China plunged 54 percent, extra painful because China pays top dollar for American produce. Growers fear they will lose their best market to Turkey and South America and never get it back, and worry about where the trade war is heading.

FRANK DAVIS, Washington FRUIT AND PRODUCE COMPANY: Because we are such a small share, you really don't like to be used as the pawn.

SPRINGER: Soybeans from the Midwest are a much bigger player accounting for 60 percent of $20 billion of food exports to China. A Nebraska Farm Bureau report released this week says the retaliatory tariffs have cost state growers $1 billion this year and farmworkers another $200 million in income.

Supporters of President Trump say farmers need to keep the big picture in mind.

DOUG ERICKSEN (R), WASHINGTON STATE SENATE: I think a lot of the farmers are feeling the pain right now but I think a lot of them also understand it's important for America overall to have fair trade relationships.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SPRINGER: Farmers suffering from the trade war with China are getting some relief in the form of a $12 billion aid package but a growing refrain from a national campaign titled "Tariffs for the Heartland" is they want trade, not aid -- Bret.

BAIER: Dan -- thank you.

Up next, the French ambassador joins me to talk about the efforts to calm the violent yellow jacket protests in France.

First beyond our borders tonight.

At least four are dead and several injured following a shooting near a Christmas market in Strasbourg, France. Police have opened a terrorism investigation into that attack. Some of the wounded are in critical condition tonight. The suspect has been identified, may have been shot but he is being actively pursued now by authorities.

January 20th is the final date to swap over 15,000 prisoners from rival factions of Yemen's devastating civil war, following talks held in a Swedish castle. The International Community of the Red Cross will oversee that process. The United Nations declared the country, Yemen as one of the world's worst humanitarian crises with 22 million of its 29 million people in some need of aid.

The bells of Balangiga are back in the Philippines after 117 years. The three bells were taken by U.S. troops in 1901 as spoils of war during one of the bloodiest periods of American occupation of the Philippines. Two of the bells had been displayed for decades at a base in Wyoming. The third was with the U.S. Army in South Korea. The U.S. Ambassador called it the end of a painful chapter in history.

Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight.

We'll be right back.

BAIER: French President Emmanuel Macron hopes tax relief and other fiscal measures will calm violent nationwide protests there. The reforms are expected to cost around 10 billion euros.

French ambassador to the United States Gerard Araud joins me here on set. Mr. Ambassador -- thanks for being here.

GERARD ARAUD, FRENCH AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED STATES: Thank you.

BAIER: First, this breaking news out of Strasbourg. There is a death toll now, the Associated Press has it at four. A shooting at a Christmas market. Suspect wounded -- it says a terrorism investigation.

ARAUD: Well, apparently, you know, I don't have of course news. It has been -- it has happened a few hours ago. The suspect has not been arrested. We know who he is, you know. Apparently he is an Islamist terrorist. He is chased. There are three or maybe four people who have been killed but at least 12 have been wounded. We have been facing this challenge for some time now unfortunately.

BAIER: The threat from radical --

ARAUD: Radical Islam, yes, it's still there.

BAIER: I want to turn to the protests. It seems -- and here is the French president in his address to the nation. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, FRENCH PRESIDENT (through translator): I feel the anger. Give us another chance. I want to see an immediate and real improvement in the salaries and this is why I am ordering an end of the year bonus for all employees without any tax.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: He is increasing minimum wage, (INAUDIBLE) tax cuts for retirees, other concessions as well and yet it doesn't seem like that's stopping the protests.

ARAUD: You know, in a sense, the powder keg of the explosion was more or less what we are seeing in the U.S., in U.K. with Brexit, everywhere. We have in France like in this country, we have millions of citizens who feel they have been left behind by globalization, automation. It's the lower middle class, the people living in small cities and are rebelling, and they have been rebelling also against our government, the government of President Macron, who has been trying to reform France. So I think that's the social background of the crisis.

BAIER: It was interesting to watch politicians and people here in this country, especially on the left because this started as a climate change effort, this fuel tax. Neera Tanden with the Center for American Progress tweeted "I don't understand why any progressive is cheering French protesters who are amassing against a carbon tax." There is a real divide about how to do that if you want to tackle it, especially if you are coming from the left side of at least American politics.

ARAUD: In French politics, the protesters are saying we are serious ourselves about bringing change. But basically they say, one of them said something very special. He said we are concerned about the end of the world, but we also have to be concerned about the end of the month. So really it's full of common sense. When you are increasing the price of gas for the people, especially for the people living in the rural areas, it has consequences on the standard of living. And I think that's what the French government didn't take into account, so now I think the president has decided to face this problem.

BAIER: Right. So he lists all these concessions, he says I'm sorry. He wants to do all of these different things, yet it doesn't seem to be appeasing the protesters which have cost your country a lot of money in tourism and shopping and everything else.

ARAUD: France are very good demonstrators, that's a tradition in our country. We are going to see. And, of course, there are always people who are not satisfied with what the president decided, but I think we are going to see in the coming days whether these demonstrations are going to be as strong as they were last week.

BAIER: The relationship between President Trump and President Macron, largely talked about when the two visiting, it was very warm. You had the foreign minister saying, "I say to Donald Trump, the French president told him as well, we don't take part in American debates. Let us live our life in our country." That message sent I guess after the tweets he sent out about France?

ARAUD: In the family, you have very good squabbles. So in the Franco- American relationship, you have bumps. We have had bumps, you have them. But fundamentally the relationship between the two countries remain excellent.

BAIER: And they still talk?

ARAUD: And they still talk. They talk a lot on the phone, yes.

BAIER: I want to turn to another foreign policy issue, and that is Iran. They've just tested some long-range ballistic missiles. France was actually on the forefront of really cracking down on Iran in the nuclear agreement. Where do you see Iran today and what could be happening?

ARAUD: Basically, what we have been telling our American friends is that we take very seriously with the Iranians are doing in terms of missile activities, in terms of terrorism, in terms of regional aggression, and that we are ready to work with the Americans on that. There is a negotiation actually between the three main European countries and the U.S. on this issue. So we are still ready to work with the Americans, and really we share 100 percent the concerns of the Americans.

BAIER: Do you think a deal is going be repurposed?

ARAUD: We really -- basically, we do consider the decision of the American administration to get out of the Iranian deal was a bad decision, but we hope that we can work together on the other issues I have already referred to, terrorism, regional activities, and missiles. And actually there are negotiations between the Europeans and the Americans on these issues.

BAIER: Mr. Ambassador, we appreciate your time.

ARAUD: Thank you very much.

BAIER: Thank you.

The border wall is dividing President Trump and Congressional Democrats, and the government potentially partially shuts down in 10 days. The panel joins me next to go over where things stand.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHUCK SCHUMER, (D) SENATE MINORITY LEADER: I think we can agree on is we shouldn't shut the government down over a dispute. And you want to shut it down. You keep talking about it.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The last time, Chuck, you shut it down.

SCHUMER: No, no, no. Twenty times.

TRUMP: And then you opened it up very quickly. I don't want to do what you did.

SCHUMER: Twenty times. Twenty times you have called for I will shut down the government if I don't get my will.

TRUMP: You know what I'll say? Yes, if we don't get what we want, I will shut down the government.

SCHUMER: OK, fair enough. We disagree. We disagree.

TRUMP: And I am proud -- and I'll tell you what, I am proud to shut down the government for border security, Chuck.

SCHUMER: This temper tantrum that he seems to throw will not get him his wall and it will hurt a lot of people because he will cause a shut down.

REP. NANCY PELOSI, (D) HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: We think we left it in a pretty good place. We gave him two possibilities. They said they would think about it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Welcome to divided government in 2019, Oval Office meeting between the Democratic leadership, the president there fighting for the border wall funding, later at another event said he was fine with that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I don't mind having the issue of border security on my side. If we have to close down the country over border security, I actually like that in terms of an issue but I don't want it to be an issue. I want it to be something that the country needs. It's not really an issue. It's something the country needs. It's common sense.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: So where are we as a partial government shutdown looms 10 days from now? Let's bring in our panel, Charles Hurt, opinion editor for "The Washington Times," A.B. Stoddard, associate editor at Real Clear Politics, and Jonah Goldberg, senior editor at "National Review," Charlie, it was quite something to see, obviously, just the moment was quite something to see. But then the minority leader saying, you know what, get the cameras out of here, let's talk. And then the president turning and saying, Nancy, it's about transparency.

(LAUGHTER)

CHARLES HURT, OPINION EDITOR, "WASHINGTON TIMES": That's one of the things I'll never understand, a complaint that I'll never understand in this era of Trump. I would think that at the very least people who don't like Trump and don't like the stuff that he says would at least applaud the fact that he is, shall we say, transparent. He doesn't mind having the press in these meetings.

But you got two people here in Pelosi and Schumer who have 60, 65 years of political experience on the guys. This guy is a complete novice. And what we saw in that 15 minutes in the Oval Office was him completely getting them -- playing rope-a-dope with them so that they are playing 100 percent his game.

He is right, on the issue of border security, Republicans win that fight, Trump wins that fight. In fact, it's what got him elected. But there are a couple things that Chuck Schumer said in particular that I thought were fairly amazing. One is the line about election matter. I guess elections matter except 2016 when Trump won. And then also he says this having just lost two seats, a pretty historical difficult thing to do.

BAIER: But then kind of blows it off. North Dakota and Indiana, who cares about that?

HURT: That was the most astonishing thing out of it to me, the idea that he would say that when the president brings up North Dakota and Indiana he's in big trouble, completely dismissing two very important entire regions of the country. I thought that he will live to regret that remark.

BAIER: A.B., Democrats seemed to be happy with the fact that they had the president on camera, on tape saying I will own it. If it shuts down, I will own it. But negotiations are continuing.

A.B. STODDARD, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, REAL CLEAR POLITICS: And to Charlie Hurt, it's a rope-a-dope. Look, Republicans have dreaded this moment for months, and they don't want a government shutdown. Yes, the Democrats did this last year and they regretted it very quickly. As the president pointed out, they opened it right back up. Government shutdowns are a loser particularly when you proclaim that you want one and you are the architect of the shutdown. You will get blamed.

Republicans still have a majority in the Senate and the House. They don't want to shut the government down on their watch. The Democrats like Nancy Pelosi are saying you guys have the votes, you guys fund the government. You're right, it's a partial shutdown. It's only five agencies left, about 20 percent of the discretionary spending, but it still is a political loser to shut the government down and jump up and down smiling about it.

It doesn't matter that border security is not a potent issue. It is. The wall is a popular policy idea among Republicans. But shutting the government down is never a good idea, so Republicans like Mitch McConnell had to come out and clean up and say I don't know what happened with that contentious meeting, but we don't want to shut the government down.

BAIER: Let's listen to the Senate majority leader.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MITCH MCCONNELL, (R) SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: I understand it was a rather spirited meeting that we all watched. But I'd still like to see a smooth ending here, and I haven't given up hope that's what we'll have.

SEN. PATRICK LEAHY, (D) VERMONT: This is irresponsible. If you saw it a comedy show or you saw it on some television program you might think, OK, this goes over the top. Well, it does go over the top.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, (R) SOUTH CAROLINA: I talked to the president just a few minutes ago, and I told him you are right to make this request, this demand. He seems pretty dug in.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Jonah, there is going to be horse-trading over the next 10 days, a lot of it. We could be seeing the beginning dance of what could be a lot of things that happen on Capitol Hill.

JONAH GOLDBERG, SENIOR EDITOR, "NATIONAL REVIEW": We could be. We could also be looking for faces in clouds.

(LAUGHTER)

GOLDBERG: I think in six months we will look back at this White House meeting and marvel at the level of decorum and civility.

(LAUGHTER)

GOLDBERG: We'll be nostalgic for this kind of thing. All this seemed like with Chuck Schumer and Trump was like -- as a New Yorker I know the types - - two old guys fighting over whose cab it is.

(LAUGHTER)

GOLDBERG: And it's going to get worse. I agree with some of the things Charlie said about transparency and all that, but the idea that this was 100 percent Trumps game and rope-a-dope, Republicans on the Hill were calling it the Schumer shutdown right before this meeting. They can't call it Schumer shutdown anymore. I think at minimum the Democrats, they can overplay their hand, they get strategy wrong all the time. But they went in hoping to get what they got today.

BAIER: Right, but for the base, Charlie, the president, this is probably his last chance to stand up and say I want this wall funding.

HURT: So obviously it's very good, this is an important issue for the base. But if you move away from the word "wall" and start talking about border security, which is kind of the thing that's being debated here, that's far more widely popular beyond just the Republican base. That is where you start eating into a lot of Democratic support. And when you have people in the party who are legitimately in favor of sanctuary cities and legitimately opposed to any kind of border security, that's a winner for Republicans.

I also think we should be careful overstating how damaging a shutdown is. Obviously, it's very disruptive around here. But remember the last time Republicans got blamed for a shutdown, they went on to win historic, in 2012, went on to win historic margins in the House. So I think that we get really upset about this sort of thing because it's so unusual, but I don't think that beyond here it makes quite as big a difference.

BAIER: We'll have many panels to discuss this going forward. Next up, Google's CEO takes questions on Capitol Hill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SUNDAR PICHAI, GOOGLE CEO: I lead this company without political bias and work to ensure that our products continue to operate in that way. To do otherwise would be against our core principles and our business interests.

KEVIN MCCARTHY, (R-CA) HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: We need to be sure that any political bias within Google's workforce does not creep into its search products.

ZOE LOFGREN, (D-CA) HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: If you Google the word "idiot" under images, a picture of Donald Trump comes up. I just did that.

TED LIEU, (D-CA) HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: If you're getting bad press articles and bad search results, don't blame Google or Facebook or Twitter. Consider blaming yourself.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: OK, Google's CEO up on Capitol Hill taking a lot of questions, a lot of heat. We're back with the panel. What do we gain from this? Is there anything that comes out of this, Jonah?

GOLDBERG: To be honest, I don't know. I don't think this was one of Congress's finest moments. A lot of them seem like the modern equivalent of the oldster who doesn't know how to set the clock on the VCR the way they were talking about some this technology. Look, 90 percent of web searches are by Google. That's an important thing. That makes looking into abuse of monopoly power, antitrust stuff a legitimate concern for Congress. We are entering into a brave new world with a lot of issues that we've never really tackled before.

So I encourage Congress to look into this. I don't think worrying about this pure bias of Google searches things is the best face for this. There are more important issues. But you could also see Google asking for regulation, which is what these big companies often end up doing because it locks in their market share.

BAIER: Right. A.B., there is a serious side to all of this, and that is something is going to happen eventually on Capitol Hill when it comes to big tech.

STODDARD: There is a day or a period of reckoning upon them, and they know that, which is why every hearing that they attend when they get asked about their opportunities in China and they get to sort of deflect around that, or they spend most of the entirety of the three hours talking about bias on their engines is a good day for them, because what they don't want to talk about his antitrust violations and that kind of bipartisan push, and it is bipartisan, coming in the future.

The Congress has shown itself in these hearing setting where we are all cringing like this at what the next guy is going to say, and their staffs are in the background, who should be replacing them at the hearings, by the way, asking all the questions. And you can just see the pillars, the leaders who are giving this testimony are trying to not smile, because they know if they can run out the clock and not talk about major changes and just say we can't share our algorithms, but we promise you there's no bias. Or, it's true, we are trying to improve our privacy protections, that they can push it off for another year while Congress tries to keep pace with this furious rate of change.

BAIER: And it's furious. Here is Bob Goodlatte talking about collecting data. This is a big issue here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BOB GOODLATTE, (R-VA) HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: With Americans carrying their smartphones all day every day, Google is able to collect an amount of information about its users that would even make the NSA blush. I think it is fair to say that most Americans have no idea the sheer volume of detailed information that is collected.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: That is a true statement. We don't know how much data is being collected.

HURT: But we do know that it's truly terrifying, the amount of information, the amount of very, very personal information that these companies are vacuuming up. And as I think Jonah and A.B. both pointed out, looking at -- watching hearings like we saw today, it just underscores the folly of expecting the federal government to somehow protect Americans' interests in this field. Honestly, at the end of the day, and I'm deeply suspicious of all of these companies, especially that phone thing that tracks you everywhere, but at the end of the day, the answer is don't give them any of your information.

BAIER: Yes. He can set his VCR clock. I think he can.

GOLDBERG: I'll take that action.

(LAUGHTER)

BAIER: You'll take that action?

Chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge back for a quick correction now. Catherine?

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: That's right. Earlier this evening, Bret, we reported citing a court filing that Maria Butina met with a candidate believed to be Donald Trump. We now understand that she did meet with a candidate but it was not Trump. Butina, did, however, ask the president a question at a public event in 2015 and we are happy to clarify it, Bret.

BAIER: All right, Catherine, thank you.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

BAIER: We'll follow that story and others. When we come back, a special moment in the airport.

BAIER: Finally tonight, a really great moment, travelers at the Nashville airport stopped in their tracks to sing the National Anthem.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(SINGING)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The moment was captured over the weekend as an American Airlines flight was taking children who lost their parents in combat to a trip to Disney World. So everybody stopped and started singing the National Anthem. Airport travelers took notice after an announcement was made as the kids were boarding. It was impromptu, and the military was there to salute the families as well. That's a great moment.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for the SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and still unafraid.

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: Well, she's looking great. But let me just say.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: She looks good.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: You're not allowed to say that -- Juan.

WILLIAMS: George H.W. Bush and now this woman --

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: They're braver than me, that's for sure.

WILLIAMS: I'm going to be like 65 shortly. I'm worried.

ORTAGUS: I know I wouldn't do it.

WILLIAMS: No, I don't want to go.

PERINO: Set your DVRs, everyone. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE. I mean why would you. It's amazing.

"SPECIAL REPORT" is up next. Hey, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Granny is very attractive. Thanks, Dana.

President Trump trades threats with congressional Democrats over shutting down the government.

The Google CEO takes center stage on Capitol Hill and takes heat from both political parties.

The French offer protesters a peace offering after weeks of violent protests. The French ambassador will joined me to explain the strategy going forward.

This is SPECIAL REPORT.

BAIER: Good evening. Welcome to Washington. I'm Bret Baier.

President Trump says he would be proud to shut down the government over the border wall. The Senate Minority Leader calls the wall threat a temper tantrum. The House Minority leader and possibly future Speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi says President Trump does not have the votes.

There are still ten days left for more political fireworks until the funding runs out for the government, at least partially. We'll explain that.

Correspondent Kevin Corke is at the White House tonight where the negotiations took place in the Oval Office and importantly on camera. Good evening -- Kevin.

KEVIN CORKE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret. Quite the afternoon here.

What was billed as a chance to work together to avoid a government shutdown and perhaps secure funding for the border wall quickly devolved into political mayhem here at the White House this afternoon with the President, as you pointed out, promising to shut down the government if he doesn't get funding for the wall.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I am proud to shut down the government for border security, Chuck. because the people of this country don't want criminals and people that have lots of problems and drugs pouring into our country.

So I will take the mantle. I will be the one to shut it down. I'm not going to blame you for it. The last time you shut it down, it didn't work. I will take the mantle of shutting down. And I'm going to shut it down for border security.

(CROSSTALK)

SENATOR CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: But we believe you shouldn't shut it down.

CORKE: It was a rare glimpse of the bare-knuckle battles that few outside Washington get to see. The President suggesting the Democrats would rather keep the border open than keep the government open. And Democrats accusing him of trying to force a shutdown.

TRUMP: We need border security, the wall is part of border security you can't have very good border security without the wall. No.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: That is (INAUDIBLE). That is a political term. Border security is a way to effectively honor or responsibility.

SCHUMER: And the experts say you can do border security without a wall which is wasteful and doesn't solve the problem.

TRUMP: It totally solves the problem.

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: And it's very important.

PELOSI: -- we came at a place to say how do we meet the needs of American people?

CORKE: Ahead of the meeting, the President made clear his intentions, repeatedly tweeting about the wall and the border, promising the wall get built.

TRUMP: I don't mind owning that issue. I mean Chuck's problem is that, you know, when we last closed down, that was his idea. And honestly, he got killed. And so he doesn't want to own it. And I said, you know what, rather than us debating who's owning it, I'll take it. I'll take it.

If we close down the country, I will take it because we are closing it down for border security. And I think I win that every single time.

CORKE: The latest Marist polls suggest a majority of Republicans prefer he dig in with 65 percent saying the President shouldn't compromise on the border wall even if it means a shutdown. But 56 percent of those surveyed including 71 percent of Democrats say he should.

SCHUMER: This Trump shutdown, this temper tantrum that he seems to throw, will not get him his wall and it will hurt a lot of people because he will cause a shutdown. He admitted he wanted a shutdown. It's hard to believe that he would want that.

CORKE: South Carolina GOP Senator Lindsey Graham is among those urging the President to stand his ground.

SENATOR LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: I find it pretty hypocritical for the Democrats to deny the President $5 billion which could be well spent to help secure a border by having walls in places that make sense.

If I were the President, I would dig in on this. And I would also put DACA on the table and try to solve two problems at once.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: Bret -- as you know, the clock is ticking on both the President and the White House as well as congressional lawmakers. The government funding runs out December 21st at 11:59:59 p.m. after which real political and financial consequences will ensue -- Bret.

BAIER: Kevin Corke, live on the north lawn. Kevin -- thanks.

A district court judge ordered adult film star Stormy Daniels to pay President Trump almost $300,000 to cover three quarters of the President's attorney's fees. An additional thousand dollars was added in sanctions to punish Daniels for filing what the judge called a quote, "meritless defamation lawsuit".

Members of the House Judiciary Committee peppered the head of Google today, focused on potential bias and data collection.

Correspondent Gillian Turner reports on the tech giant's time on the hot seat at today's congressional hearing.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SUNDAR PICHAI, CEO, GOOGLE: I lead this company without political bias and work to ensure that the products continue to operate that way.

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Google CEO, Sundar Pichai faced a grilling in front of the House Judiciary Committee today, his first ever hearing on Capitol Hill. Knowing this might be their only face time with Google's chief for a long time, lawmakers came armed with a gigabyte's worth of accusations and questions.

At the top of Republicans' agenda, anti-conservative bias in the search engine.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: We need to be sure that any political bias within Google's workforce does not creep into its search product.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R), OHIO: So I've got really just one question for you -- why? Why did Google configure its features and pay for rides to the polls to get out the Latino vote only in key states?

Or, it's true, we are trying to improve our privacy protections, that they can push it off for another year while Congress tries to keep pace with this furious rate of change.

BAIER: And it's furious. Here is Bob Goodlatte talking about collecting data. This is a big issue here.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. BOB GOODLATTE, (R-VA) HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: With Americans carrying their smartphones all day every day, Google is able to collect an amount of information about its users that would even make the NSA blush. I think it is fair to say that most Americans have no idea the sheer volume of detailed information that is collected.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: That is a true statement. We don't know how much data is being collected.

HURT: But we do know that it's truly terrifying, the amount of information, the amount of very, very personal information that these companies are vacuuming up. And as I think Jonah and A.B. both pointed out, looking at -- watching hearings like we saw today, it just underscores the folly of expecting the federal government to somehow protect Americans' interests in this field. Honestly, at the end of the day, and I'm deeply suspicious of all of these companies, especially that phone thing that tracks you everywhere, but at the end of the day, the answer is don't give them any of your information.

BAIER: Yes. He can set his VCR clock. I think he can.

GOLDBERG: I'll take that action.

(LAUGHTER)

BAIER: You'll take that action?

Chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge back for a quick correction now. Catherine?

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: That's right. Earlier this evening, Bret, we reported citing a court filing that Maria Butina met with a candidate believed to be Donald Trump. We now understand that she did meet with a candidate but it was not Trump. Butina, did, however, ask the president a question at a public event in 2015 and we are happy to clarify it, Bret.

BAIER: All right, Catherine, thank you.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

BAIER: We'll follow that story and others. When we come back, a special moment in the airport.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Finally tonight, a really great moment, travelers at the Nashville airport stopped in their tracks to sing the National Anthem.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(SINGING)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The moment was captured over the weekend as an American Airlines flight was taking children who lost their parents in combat to a trip to Disney World. So everybody stopped and started singing the National Anthem. Airport travelers took notice after an announcement was made as the kids were boarding. It was impromptu, and the military was there to salute the families as well. That's a great moment.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for the SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and still unafraid.

urn:contentItem:5XSJ-RM31-F021-61P7-00000-00Boris doesn't need an ideology - just remove the barriers to growth2019-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Boris doesn't need an ideology - just remove the barriers to growthBy Ryan Bourne

Endless debates or setting winners against losers will not work, but much better transport will get the UK going

It's difficult to pigeonhole Boris Johnson's economic worldview. He calls his Cabinet a One Nation government, given its ambition for higher public service spending, regional infrastructure investment and minimum wage increases. His musings on regulation, free trade and the nanny state often sound liberal, if not libertarian.

To confuse matters more, his proposed state aid laws suggest he's partial to some old-school national collectivist thinking too. Anyone hoping for a principles-based coherent economic agenda during this Parliament will be disappointed.

One concept the prime minister does appear to intuitively understand though is the importance of economic growth. His desire to "unleash the potential" of the country might not be based on theoretical models, like Gordon Brown's penchant for "post-neoclassical endogenous growth theory".

But in acknowledging wealth must be produced before being spent, Johnson understands that growth is the essential precondition for the rising wages, regional levelling-up and better public services promised in today's Queen's Speech.

A legacy of the Blair and Brown era is that we spend inordinate time in politics debating distributional issues, analysing "winners and losers". Rich are pitched against poor, young against old, North against South. Deficit reduction from 2010 necessitated tough spending choices, adding to this zero-sum economic framing in respect of government departments or local government - the idea that one person's gain must be another's loss.

Yet faster economic growth eases these constraints. It allows "having your cake and eating it," as Boris might say. An economy growing more quickly means stronger public finances, faster wage growth, and people far less occupied with comparing their spoils. Positive sum, not zero sum.

The central economic problem the UK has faced over the past decade is simply too little growth. Whether it was the cause or simply reflective of a past unsustainable trend, the crisis's aftermath heralded a period of dire productivity growth performance.

GDP per capita is over 20pc below where it would have been had pre-crisis productivity trends continued, with annual growth falling from over 2pc to just over 0.4pc.

Forecasters initially predicted a productivity bounceback was just around the corner. But tomorrow never came. Conservative chancellors each year therefore stood at the despatch box to announce weak growth forecasts, before proceeding to do little about it. Then came Brexit.

Uncertainty about trading relations and a Corbyn premiership has cast a long shadow over investment and location decisions since 2016. Under these and demographic headwinds, we've become so depressingly accustomed to weak growth that its absence barely features in public debate. Which is why Boris's rhetoric is so encouraging.

The positive stock market reaction to his victory suggests seeing off Corbyn and the declining probability of a "no-deal" Brexit will deliver somewhat of an investment fillip, as Boris claimed. We might also see some near-term macroeconomic stimulus, although any investment projects will have muted economic effects given lead times and the likelihood the Bank of England would offset any demand pressure that raised inflation.

Given the size of his majority though, the prime minister's economic ambitions should extend far beyond delivering a short-term sugar rush. With unemployment low and migration likely to be curtailed, the scope for GDP boosts from simply adding workers is diminishing anyway. Robust productivity growth is therefore crucial to deliver the tax revenues and wage increases needed to make Boris's first term a clear economic success.

His team know this, and recognise they have a narrow time frame of electoral goodwill to do something about the contentious land-use planning regime, for example. Our byzantine mess of a system constrains economically successful areas from growing, especially through green belts.

But it also reduces the prospect of certain firms achieving efficient premises scale in industries such as retail, social care and childcare, due to limited space and/or high rents.

There's obvious pro-investment policy the government could opt for, including letting corporations write off spending on buildings and capital equipment immediately against tax.

The litmus test of whether Boris is serious about growth will come from how he intends to repay working-class towns he won. The political imperative to be seen to "help" may lead to resources thrown at high street, town and hospital regeneration, as tried and failed under New Labour.

Hare-brained ideas for government schemes to help locals acquire shop space or incentivise them to stay where they were born are already proliferating. This sort of stuff, plus attacks on big tech, is just a form of winner to loser distributional politics Boris should avoid.

If you tax success to subsidise failure, you'll end up with more failure. It doesn't mean nothing can be done. But new interventions or infrastructure should work with market signals, not against them. Removing bottlenecks to growth or joining areas to thriving markets by better transport infrastructure is what works.

Given our population density, economic thinkers Stian Westlake and Sam Bowman think the best way to help poor towns' residents is to remove government barriers to moving while improving connectivity between successful city hubs and close-by towns.

While Boris does not have an economic ideology then, the sheer size of his majority has given him an opportunity to crack thorny structural economic challenges.

There's a potential future where he is ruthless in eliminating barriers to growth, makes infrastructure decisions to obtain the biggest bang for the buck, broadens our free trading horizons and improves tax incentives to invest.

In that world, GDP is somewhat higher, public service pressures are that bit more manageable and economic opportunity has broadened into the regions of his new voters. Now, that's a potential worth unleashing.

urn:contentItem:5WNJ-9PK1-JBG3-60N6-00000-00Boris Johnson, Russia, Heat Wave: Your Friday Briefing2019-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexisBRIEFINGBoris Johnson, Russia, Heat Wave: Your Friday BriefingMatthew Sedacca

Here’s what you need to know.

(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

Good morning.

We’re covering Boris Johnson’s hard-line stance, a new report on Russian election interference, and the record-breaking heat in Western Europe.

Boris Johnson pushes a hard line

Britain’s new prime minister culled about half of the cabinet he inherited from his predecessor, Theresa May, and installed staunch Brexit supporters in key positions.

In a speech in Parliament on Thursday, less than 100 days before the nation is expected to crash out of the E.U., Mr. Johnson outlined tough Brexit demands, including the “abolition” of a so-called “backstop” plan that would have allowed goods to flow freely across the Irish border.

Both moves appeared intended to send one message to the E.U.: He is serious about leaving without a deal if necessary.

Impact: Mr. Johnson’s ejection of so many members of Mrs. May’s team frees them up to openly oppose a no-deal Brexit. And Mr. Johnson seems willing to call a general election this fall if Parliament tries to block a no-deal Brexit.

In Spain: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, whose Socialist Party victory in April’s elections was seen by E.U. leaders as a vote of confidence against the rising tides of nationalism and populism in the bloc, failed to form an alliance that would re-elect him in Parliament, moving the country closer to another national election.

U.S. Senate report outlines Russian election meddling

Election systems in all 50 U.S. states were targeted by Russia in 2016, the Senate Intelligence Committee concluded, painting a Russian intelligence effort more far-reaching than the federal government had previously acknowledged.

But the report — the first from the committee’s investigation into 2016 election meddling — was so heavily redacted at the demand of American intelligence agencies that key lessons for 2020 were blacked out.

While not directly critical of either American intelligence agencies or the states, the report described what amounted to a cascading intelligence failure.

Details: The findings landed just hours after Senator Mitch McConnell stepped forward to block consideration of a package of election security bills, and a day after the special counsel Robert Mueller warned that Russia was moving again to interfere.

Other Capitol Hill news: After Mr. Mueller’s testimony, demands for impeachment are growing louder and more divisive. Four more House Democrats came out on Thursday in support of beginning impeachment proceedings against President Trump, but a majority of Democratic caucus members remain skeptical about what they see as a politically perilous push.

Heat wave blazes across Western Europe

A dangerous heat wave swept across the region on Thursday, with the temperature in Paris soaring to almost 43 degrees Celsius, or nearly 110 degrees Fahrenheit, the hottest in recorded history. Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands all set national records, too.

Scientists say the hottest summers in Europe in the past 500 years have all come in the last 17 years. Several heat waves have been linked to human-caused climate change, and many more are likely to scorch temperate zones like northern Europe in the future.

Climate politics: The northern French town of Grande-Synthe has been a vibrant laboratory of pragmatic green policies. Its mayor, who was recently elected to the European Parliament, faces the challenge of persuading more voters that climate change is a concern for everyone.

If you go: Our Travel desk has put together tips for visitors, including what to expect at nine popular European tourist destinations in the hot zone and suggestions for how to cool off.

Facebook stumbles in disinformation fight

In response to globally growing anger and potential government regulation after the 2016 U.S. elections, Facebook created a library to hold all the advertisements on the social network.

Anyone can see individual ads, but researchers say access to the library’s data for creating databases and tools to analyze the ads is so flawed that it’s effectively useless as a way to comprehensively track political advertising.

The library was the centerpiece among initiatives like expanded fact-checking efforts that Facebook executives used as examples of how their company could be trusted to fix its own problems. But these issues raise questions about the social media company’s efforts to quash disinformation, and reflect the struggles of big tech firms and governments to counter it.

New data deal: Tech giants’ corporate wealth is built on harvesting and commercializing the information supplied by online multitudes. As the backlash against Facebook and other tech giants intensifies, a growing collection of people are calling for a better bargain on how these companies use their data.

Side note: Facebook’s co-founder, Chris Hughes, and antitrust academics have been meeting with government officials to argue that for nearly a decade, Facebook has been acquiring companies to protect its dominant position in the market for social networks.

How Turkey purges its intellectuals

President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has sought to dismantle the country’s academic sector in an attempt to consolidate his grip on power.

Since 2017, about 6,000 academics have been fired. Many have also had their passports canceled, and some face legal proceedings as the country swerves toward an authoritarian state.

Iran: A U.S. military official said Iran fired a Shahab-3 medium-range missile on Wednesday. It appears to be a political statement by Tehran, acting both as a carefully calibrated effort at escalation — and as a message to Europe.

ASAP Rocky: The rapper was charged with assault on Thursday and will remain in custody until his trial on Tuesday, Swedish prosecutors said. The case, which started as a street brawl, ballooned into a diplomatic incident involving President Trump, who lashed out on Thursday at Sweden’s prime minister over what he said was unfair treatment of the rapper.

Libya: About 150 migrants who were likely looking to reach southern Italydrowned in a shipwreck on Thursday, according to the United Nations, which said crossing the Mediterranean had become increasingly perilous because of the decline in rescue ships patrolling the waters.

Ukraine: In a move that is likely to increase tensions between Moscow and Kiev, Ukraine seized a Russian tanker that it claims was used during a naval confrontation last year to block passage through the disputed Kerch Strait.

Snapshot: Above, Franky Zapata, the French inventor of a jet-powered hoverboard, taking off in Sangatte, France, at the start of his attempt to fly across the English Channel. He plunged into the water shortly after liftoff, uninjured.

Tunisia: President Béji Caïd Essebsi, the country’s first popularly elected leader, died at the age of 92. He steered the country through a democratic transition after an uprising that set in motion the Arab Spring of 2011.

Vinícius Júnior: Real Madrid’s teenage forward has kept his native Brazil close, and his life as simple as he can, while he makes his way in Spain. Our reporter visited the star at his villa in the nation’s capital, and got a glimpse at the transition from prodigy to pro.

What we’re listening to: This mini-series from Radiolab on intelligence. “From the dark side of I.Q. tests to a scavenger hunt for Albert Einstein’s brain, ‘G’ highlights the power, and fragility, of humanity,” Remy Tumin on the briefings team writes.

Cook: This banoffee pie — a mash-up of banana and toffee — has generous layers of dulce de leche, bananas and whipped cream. It is not for the faint of heart.

Watch: “Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood” is Quentin Tarantino’s “most relaxed movie by far,” our critic writes.

Read: Max Porter’s “Lanny,” a Booker Prize nominee, richly balances elements of fairy tale, domestic drama and fable. It’s one of six new books we recommend this week.

Listen: On this week’s Modern Love podcast, the actress Amanda Seyfried reads “He’s Playing Our Song,” an essay about a young woman’s discovery of sober love.

Smarter Living: Flying, especially long distances, can be one of the biggest factors in an individual’s carbon footprint. But swearing off flying isn’t necessarily a viable option. That’s where carbon offsets come in: They compensate for your emissions by lowering greenhouse gas emissions elsewhere. Here’s our guidance on buying and using them. (They cost less than you might think.)

And technology that allows hotel guests to use their phones as room keys is expanding, taking aim at those environmentally unfriendly plastic cards.

Garlic

The world’s biggest garlic festival starts today in Gilroy, Calif., serving up more than two tons of the pungent vegetable in dishes like calamari, pesto, french fries and bread.

Garlic — a close cousin to onions and leeks — has been consumed by humans for thousands of years as both food and medicine. Hippocrates prescribed garlic to treat a variety of conditions, and the ancient Greeks gave garlic to both Olympic athletes and fighting cocks to help their performance.

The jury is still out on many health claims (one meta-analysisconcluded the “evidence is not strong” that garlic helps with high blood pressure), but any positive benefits are likely linked to the antioxidant effects of the sulfur compounds that form when a garlic clove is crushed. They also give garlic its powerful aroma.

But do leave your chopped garlic out for 10 minutes to allow those compounds to form.

That’s it for this briefing. See you next time.

— Matthew

Thank youTo Mark Josephson and Eleanor Stanford for the break from the news. Victoria Shannon, on the briefings team, wrote today’s Back Story. You can reach the team at briefing@nytimes.com.

P.S. We’re listening to “The Daily.” Our latest episode is about Robert Mueller’s testimony. Here’s today’s   Mini Crossword puzzle, and a clue: Li’l doggo (5 letters).   You can find all our puzzles here.
