JOHN BRANDBERGH: Sure, by the way, good job last night, Sarah.

RAY RITCHEY: Is that Sarah or Tina Fey in the picture there? We're not quite sure.

JOHN BRANDBERGH: Give Sarah a shout out. I think when there's a change in administration in DC, DC does very well. Those that are in power move to protect what they've had during the last four or eight years. And the newly enfranchised, obviously write the new policy, write the new regulations. So I think that the DC market will benefit from a change in administration even it's the same party but just a new administration I think will benefit from that.

History has shown that when there's a national or international crisis the DC market benefits from an office space standpoint. Unfortunately that's the sad commentary. If you look at the S&L crisis with the formation of the RTC they leased hundreds of thousands of square feet and when they were -- basically worked themselves out of business that was backfilled very rapidly from the growth that was generated.

If you look at 9/11 the formation of Department of Homeland Security they've leased probably a million square feet. I think with this new office of financial stability, whatever it's going to be called, anecdotally the talk is that they'll need between 500,000 and a million square feet.

RAY RITCHEY: And that's obviously bodes well for a lot of those buildings up in [Milmet] that are sitting vacant. And that's one of the few places the government can afford to go. Anyone else have comments on the change of administration?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I don't know about the administration in Washington but I've been much more encouraged about the administration in New York City that hopefully Mayor Bloomberg will with his recent announcement of trying to get the turn on his over turn will return to New York as I think it's key to the New York market that with stable leadership and Bloomberg has really shown to be that over the past eight years.

RAY RITCHEY: And if you'll have no problem to make a major donation to his campaign I'm sure he'll be in support of that.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: You know it's interesting in Washington when we have these elections an interesting side light.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I'll grab your checkbook Ray.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: An interesting sidelight is with all the Congressman and Senators who do not go up for reelection trust me they're not going back to Arkansas. They're not going back to Iowa. They're staying right there in Washington, DC and they're starting their own boutique firms and while it's not a major demand driver it does drive up some demand in some of the top tier buildings in Washington, DC

RAY RITCHEY: Our next question from our shareholders comes from our two largest, Mortimer Zuckerman and Ed Linde. I'm looking at his picture. I'm trying to figure how Mort gets younger looking every year as opposed to -- this is probably a 35-year old picture.

And Mort and Ed ask, "What does the pipeline for future development look like in each of your markets both in terms of the general market and BP specifically? And would you start today on a speculative basis?" John, what do you think about starting a spec building in Princeton?

JOHN BRANDBERGH: On a spec base, you know, as we talked about earlier we are building 71 Carnegie Center for Princeton University and we've had some preliminary discussions about building a second building for them. So certainly on a situation like that we would build -- fortunately in 2000 we had our next spec building all teed up ready to go.

And five developers developed over a million square feet along the Princeton Rt. 1 quarter. We're talking about an 18 million square foot market. And today about half of that is still vacant. So fortunately for us we had the foresight to put the brakes on a bit. We always have our next building teed up but it's premature at this point.

RAY RITCHEY: Dave, how about the suburbs of Boston, we see settlement on there?

DAVID PROVOST: In the suburbs, well we just finished up 77 which some of you will see today, 200,000 square feet and it's pre-leased. This about five building under construction in Central 128. We'll point them out today. Three are fully committed. The other two we've got just about 500,000 square feet about 2% of the overall market are not committed.

So again I think we'll probably hold off. We also for our portfolio we have pretty significant roles in 2009, 2010 so I think we'd want to get comfortable with that before we'd go our speculative basis. But I must tell you there is -- Cambridge is such a tight market there is no development space for office left. There's none left. That's a finite market. It's bordered by residential, it's bordered by the university, it's bordered by the Charles River. So there's no other development site. Most of it is biotech.

Many of those tenants we've seen over many square feet of migration out from Cambridge out to the suburbs. We think that's going to continue. We think that there are real build-to-suit of opportunities. So I think from a (inaudible) standpoint we feel very optimistic about that.

RAY RITCHEY: Now David brings up a good point. It's interesting with this capital crisis our anecdotal observation both in Boston and a little bit in the Valley too -- Roger can opine to this. But the tech side does not seem to be constrained by the capital and still seem to be growing, still seem to be very strong, still be taking down space. Is that just an illusion or what are you seeing, Rod?

ROD DIEHL: Now I mean -- there's definitely been continued demand from the tech side. I mean from a development perspective I mean the Silicon Valley does have, as the Bay area has probably more of the new construction that's underway right now, 3 million square feet plus or minus buildings that are either recently completed or under construction now.

So there is some stuff in the pipeline. Now that sounds like a big number but keep in mind that Silicon Valley in total is a pretty big market. I mean you talk the office market and the R&D market. And if you combine the two that's about 215 million square feet. If you look at just the office market, which is maybe 60 million-plus just Class A R&D you're talking about 100 million square feet. So 3 million square feet of new is pretty -- it's pretty minimal.

So as far as the demand for the space many of those buildings have yet to sign any leases. There's a few big deals that are out there circling now that we expect by the end of the year at least one or two of those will land. So the demand for tech in these new buildings hasn't really come to fruition yet.

But I'd have to say I just saw the recent third quarter numbers for the R&D market and it is tracking the positive net absorption year-to-date, which is meaningful down there considering that many of our other sub-markets have had negative net absorption this year. So that's good news.

RAY RITCHEY: John, how about -- I guess pharma is more your niche in Princeton there. What are you seeing in terms of pharma demand?

JOHN BRANDBERGH: Pharma certainly is the driver in the Princeton market. In pharma-related companies we've had several expansions this year with CROs with clinical research organizations and anybody related to pharma advertising. We've got an advertising agency that specializes in pharma, go from 5,000 square feet to 35,000 square feet.

RAY RITCHEY: And John (inaudible) how about the defense contracting in Brack in Northern Virginia and Maryland?

JOHN BRANDBERGH: The tech community in the Washington area is really defense, intelligence and biotech. And unfortunately with what's going on in the world today fortunately for Washington those are all doing quite well. And I think for the foreseeable future will be the same.

Also with the Brack realignment and I think some of you who follow Duke noticed that they picked up a very nice build-to-suit. It remains to be seen whether that actually goes all the way through because sometimes there's some head pegs there. But Brack, even though there's probably no net new consumption of space just the geographic relocation of that to other markets will hopefully stimulate some demand the other space we backfilled. That's certainly what we anticipate. Any other comments guys?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Yes on the tech we just continue to see really dramatic growth from the tech group. And we'd talked about it earlier Jason Fivek who heads up our greater Waltham leasing he joined us, what? 2001, and I remember we talked about phantom space.

He says, "What's phantom space?" That's from the '90s, people always talked about it and firms used to go in and say, "Okay if I'm experiencing dramatic growth I want to take 10%." They used to take 20% and look at the speculative leasing that happened in '99 and 2000. They were taking 100% more than they needed. Sometimes they didn't have anything and they took the space. Because everybody got burned he started when he did his first deals he was looking at expansion given six months of doing the lease.

So if somebody needed 10,000 they would take 7,000. And we haven't seen any slowdown and continue to see real growth and again as we talk to them we say, "Have you seen any slowdown," and they're kind of all expecting it but nobody has seen it yet.

RAY RITCHEY: You know this is -- we talked about a Wisconsin place building in Chevy Chase, Maryland and Doug mentioned that we have a deal pending for the balance of the building. Well it's actually Microsoft who is committed for -- I'm supposed to say that or not? Well it's Microsoft. Sorry, Doug.

DOUG LINDE: The press release will be going out later today.

RAY RITCHEY: And the big debate is whether they take the 64 or not in anticipation of growth because this is a building that is -- will be 100% leased. They're signing a seven to 10-year commitment and they don't want the situation where they're shy of the building. So we've seen the tech side be very, very stable in a relatively unstable market.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Now Microsoft that's a good example from that meeting -- I mean they're not specific to our space. But they had a real estate said they have a 1,000 job openings and haven't seen any slowdown, and if anything they're looking to grow and become -- in their core markets. I'm sure they're not growing in Oklahoma or Atlanta but they're growing in DC, they're growing in Boston and Cambridge, and they have a -- they're leasing with us 50,000 square feet. They are out in the market looking for 130,000 to 200,000 square feet of expansion. I mean that's incredible growth.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I'd like to add one other thing to that, Ray, is that the green tech -- I mean we see -- we're starting to see more of that with different tenants in the Valley in particular. This is an area that people have talked a lot about but we are starting to see some demand coming from that. In fact, just most recently there's a company called Solyndra which is a solar power.

They've expanded, they're taking down some pretty concise piece of land up in the east side of the Silicon Valley. And Tesla Motors, which is not necessarily a tech company in a sense, but it is an electronic car company, electric car company. They recently announced a deal to take some land in north San Jose.

So we have some of those tenants in our portfolio. We do have a solar company. We have a company that does biofuels and these are early-stage companies. They're starting small but they're looking for more space. I mean this one tenant, this 6,000 foot tenant, looking for 20. So there is a bright spot there. And Silicon Valley has reinvented itself many times over the last 40 years and this could be one other way that it does that.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Speaking of green, and [Michael Cana] did a great job talking about our approach to green. What are the tenants demanding? Is this a deal breaker on some deals? Is it a nice to have? What do we do in existing buildings when people say what are you going to do, make this building more environmentally sensitive? John, what happened with Princeton when you did that build-to-suit for them?

JOHN BRANDBERGH: Princeton emphasized that they wanted a minimum of silver and fortunate for us most of that, the cost associated with that is coming from Princeton University. As far as second generation space we certainly always go green with carpet but we haven't done any, completed much of this at this time.

RAY RITCHEY: And how about New York, what are you seeing with the --

DAVID PROVOST: It's definitely more of a -- it's definitely more of an attractive thing for a lot of foreign companies of which they're a lot in New York. But it's just -- it's starting from a development standpoint all the new developments are going to be lead, silver or gold. And that's just another marketing advantage of a new building, whether it's for a law firm who doesn't really understand why they need to be green.

But they've got clients who want them to be green. They've got new employees that they're taking on every year who are younger and in tune to this stuff and trying to decide between two different firms from a recruiting standpoint it's something helpful to them. I mean every lawyer I have now at the bottom of their e-mails that I get saying, "Do you really need to print this document?" It's coming into the market climate.

RAY RITCHEY: And the answer is usually yes? John, do you want to talk about the government's approach towards green in terms of some of the stuff we're looking in?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: It's an absolute requirement if you do a lease with the federal government to have your building be green. It's definitely on every tenant's check list and depending on who the tenant is it may or may not be a deal breaker.

One of the law firms we're dealing with I think it was kind of interesting that absolutely, positively had to be in a green building, and they put that right in the letter of intent. But they said, the landlord will not require us to build green space. I thought that was a little interesting. But I think that's the next wave. The buildings first, and then all of the tenant build-out space will eventually be green also.

RAY RITCHEY: I'd like to throw out to the audience, are there any questions you'd like to ask our panel of experts about their respective markets or what they're seeing? Any questions? Yes Chris?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible question - microphone inaccessible) that's a good, it's a very --

RAY RITCHEY: It's a timely question.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Exactly, very timely. BlackRock has flip flopped a bit. Originally there were a -- they had a bulls eye on New Brunswick. For them to locate in the State of New Jersey they need to be in an urban enterprise zone which New Brunswick qualified for. And then Pennsylvania who is getting very aggressive trying to attract companies. Had them fairly close and now they're done a 180 and are concentrating on New Brunswick again and RFIs just went out.

RAY RITCHEY: Are there questions? Michael?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible question - microphone inaccessible)

RAY RITCHEY: As a just overall market? Yes I think Mort touched on that today and [Mike Canlupa] may have as well. We acquired the Prudential about 10 years ago and at that time the Back Bay, and again for everybody who doesn't know the market, the downtown market, the overall urban market is 15 million square feet. Back Bay is maybe say 12 million to 14 million square feet depending on what you call Back Bay of that. So it's a smaller market.

It has always traded at maybe 10% to 15% less than the financial district. That is swap now and I think the new development of the Prudential Center as well as some other developments is a big part of that. The high-end hedge funds and private equity firms came over and I think that obviously the brokers coming over that was really the final push that this is the place where people want to do it. Bryan Koop talked about it.

It is -- people are working harder, it's about quality of life. It's about 24/7. It's about those things about recruiting and retaining. Boston's dirty little secret and again we have space down here so we're aware of it that the financial district there's not a lot of night life. There's not a lot of convenience retail. There's not a lot of residential.

But we're really excited about next door bringing a lot of that and what is here is right along the waterfront. If you get deep into the concrete jungle as we talked about across the Greenway it's not -- it's not much different than glorified Hartford. And so some of the stuff we look as -- and that's not negative selling. That is just comparative analysis but --

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Leave off from Hartford.

RAY RITCHEY: Oh I'm sorry.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I like Hartford.

RAY RITCHEY: All right, this is why I love these guys. Are these guys not great?

DOUG LINDE: A press release will be going out.

RAY RITCHEY: But anyhow, so again the vacancy rate we just talked about, the 6% overall so it's obviously higher on the financial district, still single digit. Back Bay is 3% and the biggest challenge that our downtown leasing team has is finding more space. That's why we're excited about Mike and the development group, 88 is really an expansion valve to help our tenants grow.

And what's very interesting and everybody talks about, well as we talk to brokers and we talk to our clients is to your point maybe if we can wait, we will wait. Guess what? A lot of these people can't wait. They need more space.

And what they're saying is everybody else is going to go out of business but I still need more space. And so you talk to these private equity firms actually everybody else that's in your portfolio is going to go out of business but I actually need to grow by 40%. And as we're continuing to see that now again. Is that going to turn in the next couple of months, we'll see. But right now it still remains pretty strong.

RAY RITCHEY: One more question please, yes, Mitch?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible question - microphone inaccessible)

RAY RITCHEY: Maybe you want to start with that.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Sub-lease space has remained pretty constant at about 20% of direct availability. And during the 2001, the dot.com breakup that was up probably around 40%, 45%. So right now as a historical number it's pretty normal in terms of on-market. And I think the assumption is that that will increase up. But right now it's pretty healthy.

RAY RITCHEY: John Brandbergh?

JOHN BRANDBERGH: Yes the sub-lease rate in our market right now is about 10%. But fortunately and (inaudible) whenever we have sub-lease space we have in our leases Bob Pester and Rod have in theirs as well at Embarcadero Center that if you go to the sub-lease market for a sub-tenant you cannot compete with a landlord. So if we're talking to them or they're an existing tenant, we have available space that suits their needs they're prohibitive from doing sub-lease.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: In our three core markets sub-lease is at historic lows anywhere from 1% to 4%. I think the bigger -- what happens before sub-leases obviously layoffs. And we haven't seen -- and we're really watching this and to Doug point's we're all nervous Nellies. We're watching -- sub-lease seems to be that first indicator.

But actually the first indicator is the layoffs. And again because we have a property measurement, we actually walk all our tenant spaces to make sure are there any empty offices. We're not seeing that. So in order for a lot of the space to go under the sub-lease market there would really need to be layoffs. So that's what we're really keeping our eye on.

RAY RITCHEY: Now David do you think because Boston went through so many M&A activities, three, four, five years ago that we've been -- the blow is a little softened here in the last few months or what?

DAVID PROVOST: Yes, there really isn't many banks left in Boston. I think the largest bank that's headquartered in Boston is what? The Eastern Bank, is that accurate? I mean that's a great trivia question. I don't know.

I mean there's not a lot of -- and that was a real concern for us as we've been through enough downturns and our concern was eight years ago what's going to get us out of this mess? And 50 years ago it had been the banks and the Fidelity's of the world. This time it was really that mid-sized firm, 30,000 to 50,000 square feet going to 80,000 to 100,000. So it's a diverse tenant base and we feel pretty confident about it.

RAY RITCHEY: Quick comments, guys, on sub-leasing, Rod?

ROD DIEHL: Yes just quickly in San Francisco the sub-lease space has hedged up a little bit. This year we were running about 500,000 to 600,000 square feet. It's a little over a million square feet right now. And the metric that I usually track is what percentage of that is the overall available space? And right now in San Francisco that's about 16.5%.

If you move down the peninsula that market has actually picked up a little bit more than that. That same metric is about 25% and if you go into the Silicon Valley it's about 13.5%. So it's probably worse in the peninsula and there's a couple of specific sub-leases that kind of move that number up. Down in the Redwood Shores that was a company called PDL that put a bunch of space on the market. So it's edged up a little bit but not dramatically.

RAY RITCHEY: John, anything on the sub-lease environment?

JOHN BRANDBERGH: Yes in our three markets the percentage of the total available space is 10% or less and that's down very dramatically from four or five years ago. Tenants are being very conservative in the amount of space that they take. We have never known a tenant that's gone out of business because they didn't have enough space.

And I think to some extent even though we'd like tenants to lease more space it may make sense for us to support them in that. They are looking more at expansion down the road as opposed to -- which puts more of the onus on us. But they're being very conservative.

RAY RITCHEY: Yes and these statistics that are being offered up here are market-wide statistics, and our own portfolio. I mean it's virtually non-existent I would say in all five of these regions. So like any good talking head show and specifically Mr. Zuckerman's [McLachlan] group, in fact he gives his condolences. He's now flying to down to tape Sunday's program so make sure you watch it.

I'm sure he'll be talking about the same topics he talked about this morning. So I'm asking each one of our panelists to give a prediction of the coming year, and why don't we use a movie theme as kind of the basis behind it. John, do you want to start?

JOHN BRANDBERGH: Well lots of different movies I can think of. But probably the best for the DC region is Being There -- actually the inflection is Been There. Being in the right location, in DC, you will be okay in the future.

RAY RITCHEY: Rod Diehl?

ROD DIEHL: I'm going to expand that, right, and a little bit beyond just one year if you wouldn't mind. I'm going to -- this might sound a little corny, but I'm going to say Little Miss Sunshine for California. And the reason is I have a good friend of mine who's in the home building industry and had this conversation there, feeling the tough times as we all know.

He said to me when I asked him how things were going and if things were going to change in his world, and he said, "Look, this place is going to get better. It's a beautiful place to live. People are going to find a way to earn a living here and stay here, and it will recover." And I think that's the case. It may take awhile -- we don't know how long, but in the long term the Bay area is a wonderful area to live and to run your business and for that -- I think the go forward is positive.

RAY RITCHEY: (inaudible)

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I mean so much of our market is perception and I think if it was the tenant rep brokers they would say, atonement. You know I would think that the market is going to fall off a cliff. I think that if I had to say anything it's probably, I don't know, there's a movie, Frantic, was that what it was, Frantic? I mean was that a movie, Frantic?

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Sure.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Sounds good, why didn't I. I think I saw this movie and it was a Frantic, I remember it was with Harrison Ford and my wife and I watched it, we came out and it was just a real [clumper], it was very slow, and my wife said, "They should have renamed that Deeply Concerned." It really wasn't -- so I think the perception is that it's going to be frantic but everything is going to be fine. So how about, It's A Wonderful Life, how's that?

RAY RITCHEY: John?

JOHN BRANDBERGH: I think it's what you've been hearing all day, I'll reiterate, Best in Show. We have the best product and the best market.

RAY RITCHEY: Good career move there, John.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Can I change my answer, Ray, Best in Show.

JOHN BRANDBERGH: And we'll continue to weather the storms.

DAVID PROVOST: In New York I have the writer's strike on so we're not really making great movies. I think the only prediction you can make in here is that there's going to be a lot of predictions in this movie. Up and down, and I think we all have to wait to see what the reality is going to be because right now there's a lot of perception and a lot of negative perception. But I think we'll have to see what the reality pans out to be.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Yes, I thought you'd go with the Good, Bad and the Ugly.

RAY RITCHEY: Well just first of all let's go to a round of applause to our panelists here, and Doug has been gracious enough to ask me to just kind of summarize today's presentation and the event last night.

And again I think the message we try to get across again is the supply constrained nature of our markets, our long-term leases and the strong balance sheet. I think much more important than those three facts is what you saw today with the depth and breadth of talent that Boston Properties brings to solving the real estate issues of the day.

From Mort Zuckerman down to this panel I think that I daresay that that was like the all-star line up of real estate. And I sat back in that room today so incredibly proud to have been associated with this company for 28 years. And more importantly looking forward to knowing that the team we've assembled here is going to do our darnedest.

And that team, the 20-some odd people there today is merely reflective of the 650 people that are throughout out our buildings, throughout our regional offices, interacting every day with our tenants making sure we offer our clients the best possible space in our respective markets.

Lastly I want to say to all of you we look at these conferences whether it's NAREIT or various investor conferences and we see many friends, and it's so great to see you all come back, come interested, participating and committed to making Boston Properties stores successful, and on that we're most grateful. So thank you very much.

urn:contentItem:4TMY-7N90-TWD3-1026-00000-00Boston Properties 2008 Investor Conference - Final2008-10-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexis100308a1973603.703Boston Properties 2008 Investor Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Mort Zuckerman Boston Properties - Chairman of the Board * Doug Linde Boston Properties - President * Bryan Koop Boston Properties - SVP, Regional Manager - Boston Office * Robert Pester Boston Properties - SVP, Regional Manager - San Francisco Office * Robert Selsam Boston Properties - SVP, Regional Manager - New York Office * Mike Walsh Boston Properties - SVP - Finance * Mitch Norville Boston Properties - EVP, COO * Peter Johnston Boston Properties - SVP, Regional Manager * Mike Cantalupa Boston Properties - SVP - Development * Ray Ritchey Boston Properties - EVP, National Director - Acquisitions and Development * David Provost Boston Properties - EVP - Leasing, Boston Region * Andrew Levin Boston Properties - EVP - Leasing, New York City Region * John Brandbergh Boston Properties - EVP - Leasing, New Jersey Region * Rod Diehl Boston Properties - EVP - Leasing, San Francisco Region

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Good morning, everyone. I want to thank everybody for coming to our Investor Conference today and welcome everyone, and also those people listening in on the webcast. I know this has been a pretty tough week this week and we appreciate you guys tearing yourselves away from your Bloomberg screens to come here. Believe me, had we known six months ago what we know today, we probably wouldn't have picked today and maybe not even this month.

I just want to briefly go through the agenda. We have a series of management presentations to go through, these include a discussion with our President, Doug Linde, and several of our Regional Managers who will talk about our strategy and some of our portfolio. I'm going to provide an update on the capital markets. I assure you this will be a scintillating topic, especially if you like horror flicks.

We're going to have a session on our development that will be lead by Mike Walsh and Mitch Norville. Over lunch Ray Ritchey and our crack team of leasing pros are going to talk about the market and this afternoon we're going to have property tours that include a tour and discussion about Russia Wharf, which is located right next door.

And also we're going to go out to the suburbs and see our CityPoint development. We should be finished around 4:30 and back here. For logistics, on your name tags you will see a table assignment for lunch and also a tour assignment because there are two separate tours.

I also want to thank a few people who worked tirelessly on putting this conference together. Hopefully you've had a chance to meet or at least speak with Arista Joyner who is our new Investor Relations Manager. Arista joined us this spring from the Midwest and she really worked hard putting this whole thing together and organized the entire event. I also want to recognize [Manny Carvello], [Lisa Teralictus], [Rachel Doyle], [Laura Markasie], [Andy Simpson], all of whom were a huge part of this.

I do want to refer you to the Safe Harbor, which is our forward-looking statement disclosure. Unlike on an airplane, I don't have to read you the safety instructions but you do have to read it, so I appreciate that. We're going to start things off this morning with some words from Mort Zuckerman. So I'd like to invite Mort up.

MORT ZUCKERMAN, CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD, BOSTON PROPERTIES: It's not going to be easy to capture the mood of the day, but I thought I would share a story with you about this fellow who came home to his wife a couple of days ago and he said, "Look sweetheart, I don't know how to tell you this. I thought I was investing our funds safely.

We had our entire net worth invested in AIG and Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns and Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, all we thought very, very good investments and they've been virtually wiped out. I just feel terrible about it and I just felt I had to share that with you." And she said, "Listen don't worry, these things happen. I love you, I'll always love you. I'll miss you, but I will always love you."

As a friend of mine put it recently, he said, "My net worth is now down to a level I never thought it would get up to." And in a sense, that does capture a lot of what has happened. A lot of people have lost a lot of money but there has been so much wealth accumulated over the last decade or so that we still have the sort of fire power and fuel to get through this period and rekindle the economy.

I'm going to just try and indicate some of the basic trends, at least as we see it, and to some extent how it will affect the business that we are in. We obviously all see a lot of the same statistics, the thing that really began to unravel the bubble that, I guess in retrospect, we were all living in. I mean it was what happened to housing.

I must say this is something which I have watched for quite a long time, not because it's in our particular area of real estate development but quite simply because it is such a critical industry in this country. It is probably one of the largest employers of labor of any industry and we were building 1.6 million to 1.8 million units and those prices were going up.

Just to put that in perspective, the average increase in housing prices from the year 1945 to the 2000 was 3% a year. And somewhere around 2000, 2001 and 2002 house prices really took off and they grew at a compounded rate between 2002 and 2006 of almost 15% a year. Now it got to a level where those housing prices were quite simply unsustainable by all but a very small portion of the market, if you assume somebody was able to devote even a relatively higher rate of their, or proportion of their income, to cover a home with a 30 year conventional mortgage rate.

And the market simply stalled and once it stalled it began to slide. I wrote an editorial in US News way back when and looked at those numbers and wrote about it and basically said, "Before you buy a house just be very, very, very cautious." And nobody expected, I think, the kind of decline that we had and nobody quite knows how big the decline is.

The estimate is to date, if you look at the Case-Schiller Index, for example, which measures one kind of housing, there's another government formula which measures mostly FHA and similarly financed housing which has declined less. But the Case-Schiller Index, which measures new family homes in 20 markets, is off roughly 20% in the last year.

And frankly, those don't really reflect the true decline in the housing values because these are nominal prices. These do not include sales incentives. And those sales incentives, if you were to believe David Rosenberg of Merrill Lynch, run over $50,000 a unit. So the housing prices, in fact, have declined even more than that.

And what's more, there is a whole change in the attitude of the buyers who are now really looking at these housing prices and saying "Why buy now, they're going down. I'll have a better deal six months from now or a year from now, particularly in a time of relative economic uncertainty."

So housing prices in, my judgment, are going to decline and nobody knows where the bottom is. And I do believe that anybody who tells you that they know either doesn't know or has a specific interest in telling you where the bottom is.

I was listening to Marty Feldstein, the former Chairman of the Economic Advisors and the Principal Economic Advisor for Reagan, who's now at Harvard. And he estimated not only that there are 10 million mortgages today that exceed the value of homes, but that 50% of those mortgages, roughly 5 million homes, the mortgages exceed the value of the homes by 20%.

Now if you have another 20% decline in housing, you're going to have 5 million homes that homeowners are going to have mortgages that exceed the value of their homes by 40% and probably another 5 million that will exceed by 20% and the rest of them under that. And nobody knows what those people are going to do.

But it is going to look to me, and I'm sure to many of you, as if it would be in their self interest to either walk from the homes or basically find a way to sit down with the mortgage lender and say, "Hey, you want the house, you can have it. But unless you write down that mortgage to a level that I can afford, I'm out of here. I'll either rent or I'll find another home, or you can foreclose on the home and then I'll come back in and I'll buy it for even less because the value of foreclosed homes decelerates much more rapidly than any other kind of home."

So there's going to be something that's going to happen. And we don't know just what it is because this has not happened in the lifetime of anybody sitting in this room today. This is really an unprecedented experience. We really had not had major league drops, year-over-year, in housing since the late 1930s. So we don't know what's going to happen. We don't know what people are going to do.

At some point I suppose, if they get to be discouraged enough, they may very well walk from a lot of these homes. And then you will have a lot of foreclosed homes that are going to be thrown on the markets fairly quickly. Because of course as we know, when you have a lot of mortgages that have been bundled and pooled and sold off as securitized mortgage-backed paper, you have servicers who are going to have to find some way to deal with all of these. It's not going to be easy to renegotiate home mortgages under these circumstances.

And therefore, just as we over shot in terms of appreciation of home values, you may over shoot in terms of declines. And that's going to have just a hugely damaging effect. I don't know if this is an exact number, but the estimate has been that at the peak of the value of homes, which was the largest single asset on the balance sheet of the average American household, was $22.4 trillion.

You lose say roughly 30% of that, you're talking about a gigantic decline in the perceived wealth of the American family. And there is, of course as we know, some translation of a decline in wealth to consumer spending, certainly to consumer sentiment. So you're looking at a consumer who is going to be very nervous about his or her major asset, is going to see the stock market having declined, another source of wealth mostly for the top quintile, top 20% who are the major owners of stocks. And what effect is that going to have on consumer spending?

And the point of all of this in once sense is to say, look, the problems may have started in the housing world, but that housing bubble, once it burst, immediately jumped into the world of finance and burst the bubble in the financial world. You now have double bubble in the housing and the financial world that are sort of interacting with each other, with no known bottom at this stage of the game. It is just an unprecedented time and we are looking at one of the most difficult economic times as we look forward to the next couple years and any one of us, I think, has experienced.

So that's sort of the back drop of one part of it. It's not the only part of it. What of course has happened is it may have started in subprime homes and Alt-A homes, in part because of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac which had somewhere between a third and a half of these home mortgages in the first half dozen years of this century or this decade, pushed by politicians who wanted to expand home ownership and exceeded to, by management of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and in many ways was a disgrace.

And it was a disgrace in political terms because particularly the Democrats, I have to say, back in the latter part of the last century and the beginning part of this century who dominated this issue, they set up a huge political operation, one of the most lethal political operations, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, that in terms of rewarding friends and punishing enemies.

And every time some group, and a number of them did, Larry Summers, even John McCain, who really tried to get Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac under control, they were just $1 trillion to $2 trillion in terms of total mortgages a decade ago and now they're somewhere around $5.5 trillion in terms of both mortgage paper that they own and mortgaged securities that they have guaranteed.

They now make up probably 75% of all of the mortgage financing in the country and maybe even more. And they had an absolutely lethal political operation. And one of those companies that operated, as we know, in the gray area between being implicitly private -- publicly supported in terms of their financing, but they had a lot of stock. It gets worse than that. They had roughly $65 of debt for every dollar of equity. At least that was in terms of the equity which they represented that they had.

Now it turns out that the total equity of the two company's numbers, say within the last six months, was about $81 billion, $83 billion. But when they were finally taken over and the government auditors went in, they found out that of this $81 billion or $83 billion, $64 billion of it were what they call tax assets. What are tax assets? These are tax loss carry-forwards that could have sheltered income.

Now no other American corporation keeps that on their balance sheets but they did. And it was 75% of their perceived net worth. This of course assumes that they would have had earnings, which they had not had for quite a number of quarters preceding the government review of it and their projection, needless to say, are for substantial losses. And by the way, they had other tax shelter or tax losses that they could have used.

In addition to that, they changed the time period during which a home was delinquent to sort of write down that mortgage. It used to be 90 days. If it was delinquent for 90 days in terms of home mortgage payments, they began to write down that mortgage. They changed that period from 90 days to two years. Furthermore, they had some securities which were -- absolutely should have been mark-to-market and were not.

Now why did they not do all of this? Of course they did it because they knew that if they did expose this it would indicate how far below even their own regulatory capital requirements were. So you are going to see, I believe, literally some criminal indictments coming out of all that.

But that was one of the major compressors of air in the housing bubble, because they put so much money into this subprime and Alt-A mortgages, which is where the crisis has occurred. Something like 46% of the subprime loans are in delinquency or in default and we have not hit the bottom of that.

Now in the financial world, of course you all I'm sure are as familiar with it as anybody, but this began to have a compounding effect on the financial world. Because the financial world in large part depends on confidence. Credit is a word that derives from the Latin crederi, which means to believe. And people stopped believing and progressively more and more people stopped believing in these financial assets held by any number of financial firms.

And it turns out of course that the financial firms, particularly the major investment banks, had just escalated their leverage. In the year 2004 the SEC changed the regulations in terms of leverage. It was basically capped out at 12-to-1, certain of the assets had discounts, 6% for the secured assets and 15% for the equity assets.

And many of the discounts on the assets were waived and they were allowed to more than double the ratio of leverage to debt to equity. And the next thing you knew, within a fairly short period of time, leverage went up to 30, 35-to-1. Lehman had a 30-to-1 debt to equity ratio, et cetera, et cetera.

But the interesting thing about the debt to equity is that, for a lot of these investment banking firms and for many other firms, particularly in the shadow banking world which I'll get to in a moment, you had the opportunity to use short-term debt to make long-term investments. And then money was around in plentiful supply at very low rates for quite a period of time. And the irrational exuberance, a phrase which was used in a different context, really affected the shadow-banking world.

What was the shadow-banking world? Well back in the 1930s probably 90%-plus of all of the financing in this country was done through the conventional commercial banking world. Today it's less than 30%. But a shadow-banking world has emerged, hedge funds, investment banking firms, conduits, SIVs, money markets, et cetera, et cetera.

And what happened was that this 70% plus was basically unregulated, particularly after what happened in 2004 when the SEC lifted the regulations. And then there was the loss of confidence in the viability of the balance sheets of these companies, as housing prices plummeted taking down the home mortgage values, which in turn took down the mortgage securities, which then affected the credit default swaps and the credit default swaps and the credit default swaps, you really had a situation of really compounding confusion and a lack of confidence in what the real net worth of these companies were and a gradual and then accelerating freeze up of the financial system.

In terms of the lack of understanding of what was happening within these financial institutions, I'm going to cite two things. One was this trader Societe Generale who managed to get involved in $74 billion of trade in a company whose net worth did not even exceed the $74 billion. It was supposed to be one of the most sophisticated banks in Europe and it was just a great scandal.

And when they finally found about it at the right level of management, they lost $7.2 billion. They decided to dissolve all those trades in a very short period of time, I presume, because they didn't like the way it would look if they still had their trades on. But this compounded the losses from an estimated $1.72 to $7.2 billion, a decision which I will never understand.

But be that as it may, that gave a lot of people a feeling of do we really know what's going on in these various financial institutions in terms of the sophistication of the trading and the sophistication of the instruments that were being traded, the futures and the straddles et cetera, et cetera. A lot of the senior management of these institutions would say, "You know there are some rocket scientists in our shop who really understand it." But a lot of them didn't understand it.

And the other one I have to say was, when it was made public that Citigroup had $80 billion in an SIV, which was a part of the "Shadow-banking" system, was not on their books, they have a negative pledge. Basically they were borrowing short to invest long and making that spread, adding it to their earnings.

But it was a separate company, it was not on their books, because Citigroup itself had a negative pledge and they did not provide the financing. But they said if they couldn't get the financing then Citigroup would step in. Well they had to step in and then you began to have a compounding of the sense of a lack of confidence.

And what has happened now, particularly after, in my judgment, the Fed and the Treasury made a huge error in not helping Lehman Brothers continue, because that left, I just saw the statistics yesterday again, they had roughly $150 billion in unsecured paper out there. And $120 million of it apparently has now been a complete loss.

Some of it was held by, it was Fannie and Freddie paper, by some of these money market funds, I think it's called reserve, which was a $60-odd billion dollar money market fund. And the buck was broken. The dollar that people invested they were no longer able to get back. They still haven't been able to repay the people who determined to withdraw. They withdrew or wanted to withdraw $58 billion out of the $60-odd billion, $62 billion, $63 billion fund within a matter of a few days and they haven't been able to liquidate their positions.

And the reason why they were in this place is that they weren't investing in all these safe things, they were competing for money so they wanted to give a slightly higher yield. They took a little bit more risk and it blew up in their face. So we are in a situation now where the financial world is going through great upheaval.

Of the five major investment banks, three of them basically have disappeared. Lehman Brothers of course, Bear Stearns in a different way and Merrill Lynch within a forced marriage with the Banc of America. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley became bank holding companies.

I believe that the principal reason for it was that they each had $100 billion or more in repos coming due within, on an average basis, I believe for Morgan Stanley around 40 to 50 days and for Goldman Sachs slightly longer. But the ability to roll over those funds was really in question and the Fed will be able to help them liquidate some of their paper and make sure that they didn't get into a liquidity crunch, because those banks to a greater or lesser degree are still fairly solid.

So there we are in this extraordinary double bubble of financial crunch and housing crunch and we are not at the bottom. And nobody knows where the bottom is. I have to say that what happened and what is happening now is there is still a credit crunch. The Fed's come up with this program of $700 billion.

I don't exactly know and I've never heard anybody justify where the number of $700 billion came from. The idea of course is that they're going to buy these toxic securities from a lot of the financial firms, create some kind of a market in it and that will presumably improve the financial condition of these major financial institutions and diminish the risk that within a matter of 48 hours or 72 hours one of them could fall through the trap door.

What I don't believe it will do will be to dramatically affect what is currently clearly a credit squeeze. You know in the mortgage world there has been such a dramatic change in the confidence of lenders that they're doing the following. They're reducing the loan-to-value ratio significantly. They're insisting that the borrowers actually have a serious credit score and that they verify and validate the income and the net worth that they assert.

You will know that something like 46%, according to Credit Suisse, of all the subprime and Alt-A loans were no-docs or low-docs loans, that is no documents or low documentation. And they did a survey of these people and it turned out that virtually all of them acknowledged that they had lied about their net worth or their income or both. But the number that really stupefied me was that 60% said they exaggerated their income by 50% or more.

And now you find out of course that these people cannot afford to carry these homes. What everybody was banking on was housing prices going up, which they were at a dramatic rate. Everybody thought, "Gees, why don't I buy a home, my buddy down the street, Joe Jerk, bought three units and in a matter of 18 months he made 40% on his money. I'm a hell of a lot smarter than Joe Jerk, so I'll buy three units or two units or what have you."

It turned out that 25% of the homes that were bought were bought on spec. Now only 4% declared that they were buying them for investment purposes. And the reason for that, if you declared that you were going to be an occupant of the home, you got a higher mortgage and a lower rate. And this has all now turned out to be more or less fictional and everybody is now trying to unravel all of the excessive confidence and exuberance about where home values were going.

The same thing though I believe is true in the financial world, the conventional financial world, the banks and the other institutions that generally provide finance for business. I think that the terms for lending are going to change dramatically. Whatever happens in the housing world, the very transformation of the terms that are being proposed is going to dramatically shrink the housing market. And whatever happens in the business world, the terms that are now going to be proposed are going to shrink the availability of finance to the business world through to the conventional banking or financial system.

Now again, nobody knows what the consequences of that may be, but it isn't going to be good. I think we're going to be in a fairly lengthy period of a declining economy. A very good economist at Harvard, Ken Rogoff, studied 18 recessions in the industrialized world, the Western style economies. There were six of them where the recession started in their version of Wall Street, in the financial world, moved into their version of Main Street and then had the dreaded adverse feedback loop back into the financial world.

Those recessions were deeper and lasted longer. On average I might add, they lasted three years. We had that same kind of experience in this country. We had what started in the financial world with the bursting of the bubble in housing that affected the bubble in the financing world, is going to move into the real economy to a greater degree by far, I think, than what we have experienced to date.

And then you will have that, again, adverse feedback loop back into the financial world, given everything that's going to go on. It's going to affect consumer card -- credit card paper, it's going to affect auto loans obviously, auto loans are plunging. It's going to affect many other different kinds of financing and nobody knows what this mix is going to produce.

And the $700 billion "bailout," rescue plan, whatever you want to call it, if it passes today because it's going to be voted on today, will in my judgment not dramatically reduce the credit squeeze, it will somewhat, but it will at least give people in the world of finance, and particularly amongst counterparties et cetera, et cetera, that the bottom will not fall out of a major firm in a matter of 48 hours. The trap door will not open up and some firm will disappear.

We are also seeing, by the way, the same thing now extending into the financial system in Europe where in many of the countries now the central banks are trying to make sure that their financial institutions don't disappear. And they're taking all sorts of steps. But it does mean too that international trade is going to go down.

Now this is not, and I want to make this clear, it's not going to be anything like the Great Depression of the 1930s. Why? In 1929 the Federal Government made up 3% of GDP, today it makes up 21% of GDP. In 1929 the relationship of the two major virtually decoupled and stable industries in this country, namely education and health, were about one tenth what they are today.

They're well over 20% today, nobody knows the exact numbers, and they were much, much less then and not really basically a ward of the Federal and State government. And international trade is a much healthier part of the economy today than it was way back then when trade virtually collapsed.

As for monetary policy, the money supply back in the last 1920s early 1930s was by law a function of the amount of gold that we had in our vault. And a lot of European countries had, for various reasons, in agreements the ability to exchange their currency for the gold, which they did. The gold supply went down and the money supply had to shrink. This was not the time to shrink the money supply.

And finally of course, the understanding of macroeconomics emerged in the 1930s, which is when Keynes did his major work. And Keynes once famously said, "You know, in the long run we'll all be dead." Wrong. I've always disagreed with him. In the long run we'll all survive and flourish, in the short run we can be dead. And this is, I think, a part of the problem that we're now trying to deal with, which is how we comfortably get through where we are today.

So I don't think it's going to be anything like the Great Depression, but it's going to be a tough period. I think it's going to be the worst recession and the longest recession we've had since the end of World War II. Now I hope this doesn't sound immodest, but I think that in fairness to you I'm going to give you as good a description of what Boston Properties did under these circumstances.

I must say to you that, even when we took on some of the policies and executed them that I'm about to describe, we did not fully foresee what in fact we've now been through. In fact, I don't know of anybody who foresaw that we would have a credit squeeze and a credit freeze that I think a week ago Wednesday caused Goldman Sachs to have to pay 20% for overnight money on that Wednesday night. And Citigroup in Europe was paying 25% and everybody else was in that range.

But we, frankly, looked at value and we thought that a number of the values in the commercial real estate market, we didn't know if they were at the top. In fact when we started to sell some of these assets, one of my colleagues said, "Why are we selling, prices are still going up."

And I said, "Well yes if the prices weren't going up we wouldn't be able to sell." But at these prices we were sellers. And we sold about $4.3 billion worth of real estate at prices that we could not get today because the financing is unavailable. And because of the perception of values is unavailable we were able to sell some properties at a cap rate of under 4% and none of them went much above 4.5%. And we raised an awful lot of money and we did some refinancing and we're in extraordinary financial shape.

And we decided, frankly, even after all of that, that we would try and access the credit markets when the money was available, not when we needed it. And so about five or six weeks ago, I think, we raised $740-odd million in the market, it was a convertible issue. That's no longer available because of the elimination of short selling. And we did it I think at a 5 3/8% rate, which looks absolutely miraculous today.

But it put us into extraordinary financial condition to do things. One of the things that we were able to do was to buy some buildings that were available, including what we believed to be two of the best buildings in New York, namely the General Motors Building and 540 Madison Avenue, which are two of the most highly regarded buildings in New York for the best kinds of office tenants, at a price which was 20% to 25% below what it had been the previous year.

So we made these purchases because we thought they were extremely good values in terms of a price per pound. That is, we could not have replicated those buildings if we had been able to get those sites, and we were not able to get sites like that because Manhattan is truly a supply-constrained market.

There are literally only two new buildings coming on stream in the next four years in Midtown New York and they're on the west side of New York, not on the east side of New York. Virtually nothing is available on the east side of New York in terms of new construction. There's a lot of space downtown, much of which I believe will never even get out of the ground for a number of years, but in Midtown New York there's virtually nothing.

So we thought we had the opportunity to buy these buildings at an extremely attractive price, which is what we stated after we bought it. We bought two other buildings which were just a shade below the two buildings that I just mentioned, but they were all in very good shape. We had virtually no space rolling over for two to three years in any of these buildings.

And a lot of the buildings, particularly the General Motors Building, had average rents that were dramatically below the market. So we thought every time these leases rolled over, we sold the building at a 3.76% cap rate, that wasn't as good as the General Motors Building, and we bought the General Motors Building at a 5% cap rate.

And in the General Motors Building not only were we way under the cost to duplicate that building, those sites simply aren't available, but both the retail space and the office space was dramatically below the market, probably 50% at that point of where the market was. So every time the space rolled over we only had 15% rolling over, so the first three or four years we thought we could pick up some appreciation. And in terms of leasing that, that is being borne out.

So we ended up in this place where we really are not dependent on any financing, not even for construction financing, if we choose not pursue it. We undoubtedly will to the extent that it is available, because we want to have some dry powder since we think there will be opportunities that will come up over the next couple years and we'd like to be positioned to take advantage of that.

But having said that, there is no doubt but that we are looking at a much more difficult period going forward than we have seen in the past. Now we have tried to anticipate this and have really throughout the entire career of Boston Properties, which now to my amazement goes back almost 40 years when Ed Linde and I started the company.

And what our sort of basic philosophy was, which is really quite simple and for us really quite obvious and you will hear a lot more about this here, is we try to stay, a, and most importantly, in supply-constrained markets. One of the guys on our Board was a guy by the name of Bill Daley. Bill Daley was a Secretary of Commerce, head of the Democratic party and now a major player in JPMorgan Chase. He took Jamie Dimon's position in the bank in Chicago and needless to say is also a brother of the Mayor of Chicago.

And the Mayor of Chicago, whom I happen to know just slightly, would call me, "My brother thinks your company is really a great company, why don't you come and develop in Chicago?" Now it's not easy to figure out a way to deflect that, but I found the perfect response I have to say. I said, "You know Mayor, I said, the reason why we can't go to Chicago is that it's too well managed."

He said, "What do you mean by that?" I said, "Because when you get an increase in demand, you get an increase in supply. We like to be in markets where you can't get an increase in supply and therefore you get an increase in rent. So that if we are building a building in a market, we want to know over time that we're going to do better in terms of the increase in the rents than the rate of increase in the consumer price index." And that sort of placated him.

But that in fact does really convey our view. And in that markets that we are in, Boston which has an absolutely insane approval process, Cambridge which has very little land, virtually no land to develop. We've been involved in Cambridge Center since 1980. It took us almost 20 years to complete that whole development, we won that in a competition way back then.

And we have tried to build the best buildings in the best suburban markets in the Cambridge and Boston area where we own Prudential Center and where in [the back] day virtually there's very, very little ability to add space to that market, which is where the -- that market in Boston is shifting to a degree to that. Not that it's all moving there, but that's going to be sort of the Midtown of Boston.

And we're in San Francisco and Washington. And the Washington area is constrained not only because of the lack of sites but because of the fact that there is height limit. And so you have to get a site where you can get enough size and fortunately we have the most talented real estate person in the Washington market, Ray Ritchey, who has been with Boston Properties I think 29 years now and is an absolutely wonderful man.

I happen to have met the Mayor of Washington just yesterday. We were not talking about real estate, we were talking about the educational system in New York City, I'm going to be the Vice Chairman of the Fund for Public Schools and he wanted to talk about that. I mentioned that we do a little bit of work in Washington in real estate and he said, "Well I've never met you," which he had not.

And I said, "Well you may have met my colleague, Ray Ritchey." Ray Ritchey, my goodness. He was so complimentary about Ray, so I know and have known for a long time that we are fortunate to have the best man in the Washington market running all of our operations there. And we tried to really in a sense establish really good independent operations in each of our markets. And by and large I think it's worked out fairly well.

Anyways, somebody once described where we are today in the following way. This man was driving a car in Paris and he was going around the Arc de Triomphe, he had a tremendously important market -- meeting, rather, that he had to go to and he couldn't find a place to leave his car. And he said, "God, I'll do whatever you want. If you can just find me a parking space now, I will do whatever you want." And he was going around and a car pulls out and he's got the perfect parking. He pulls in and he says, "God, he says, don't worry, I don't need you any more."

You see the guy didn't understand the business model. So where we are today is where everybody's going to have to look at their business models and see what works. And it's going to change. We think we are uniquely positioned amongst our confreres in the REIT world to adjust to the new markets.

We by and large had always a very, very conservatively financed company. We are even more conservatively financed today than we ever have been. We are, we believe, in the right markets which are supply-constrained buildings at the top of those markets, or buying to the top of the markets. The best properties we believe had always done better in good times and really done relatively much better in what we euphemistically called challenging times.

So that's sort of been the, at least as we see it, the environment in which we are working and how we have prepared for our self and how we are positioned to go forward. We have a development right next door here in Russia Wharf, which is 82% pre-leased. We have another development in New York which is also going to be substantially pre-leased. We've already signed one of the tenants, we're close to another. And wherever we are developing we are, as I said, the buildings are at the top end of the market and there are always good tenants for those kinds of buildings.

So this is roughly what I have been privileged to talk to you about. And I have to say that I've had an absolutely spectacular time working in the real estate world and working in Boston Properties and working with my colleagues for now 40 years and I look forward to another 40 years. Thank you all very, very much. I'd be happy to answer questions. Nobody has to ask the first question, but if anybody wants to ask a second question? Yes?

Questions and Answers

Housing prices are still 60% above where they were at the end of that year 2000, even after this decline. And this I might say is just unsustainable, especially today.
