UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Mort, you mentioned obviously the acquisitions you've done and buying at discounts to theoretically what they would have traded a year ago. Can you just speculate on what you think the downside potential for commercial real estate values, specifically CBD Office might be? And as well, you've also talked on conference calls about increasing leverage for opportunistic transactions, but do you see that probably as something you might pull back on as well in this environment?

MORT ZUCKERMAN: Well look, I do think that there is a general - an increasing degree of pessimism about the market for commercial real estate. People think that companies are simply cutting back on their employment, particularly in the financial industry. The financial industry in 1980 had about 10% of corporate profits in America, last year it was close to 40%. A lot of employment went up correspondingly, a lot of that's going to shrink. And people think this is going to affect the demand for office space and I would agree.

But again, you have to differentiate and distinguish, just as if you're in New York City, I can tell you Manhattan is not just a part of the New York economy. Manhattan is a part of the global economy, 60-odd percent of the sales at Apple are to foreigners. Apple is this wonderful amazing store in the General Motors Building where their sales are continuing to go up very dramatically. It's just an astounding retail performance and it's become a destination point on the basis of just that store.

But it does speak to the fact that particularly the highest quality residential areas in New York, areas along Park Avenue, Fifth Avenue, Central Park West, Central Park South, all those with views are still doing very well. And frankly, it's also true of the office space. The best office buildings are still doing well.

Now do I think this will continue? By and large yes because, as I was trying to say before with that story, you know people and companies' fortunes may have gone down, but they still never believe that would still be doing as well as they are doing. So there are still going to be those companies that are growing.

We see it now. We're had a tenant, a law firm that unraveled in one of our buildings, 120,000 square feet. The rent was $65 a foot and because we did the lease 10 years ago and it was a 20-year lease and the rent today is going to be -- the building space is all built up, we have a security deposit for here and we're going to be able to sublease that space, or re-lease that space.

We have a situation in the -- actually the New York Times got this story absolutely wrong, surprise, surprise. I believe, I haven't seen the paper today, they said they'd put in a correction. But they described a lease that we were about to do and we are involved still in those negotiations for 300,000 square feet in Citigroup Center. And they said the tenant had to agreed to stay where they were and they were extending the five-year lease.

I wasn't even in New York at the time, I was in Boston, I get a frantic call from their senior partner who said it's not true, it's 100% false. Besides, it wasn't our space it was sublease space. But setting that aside, there are tenants around and there are tenants who are growing.

And this is again one of the advantages of being in the prime buildings because a lot of these tenants want to be in the prime buildings. They want to be on the east side of New York rather than on the west side of New York. And I don't mean to diminish the west side, I'm just saying it's a different quality of real estate.

I will tell you that the EOP deal that Blackstone went ahead with actually started because I called the Blackstone people. Ed and I have been talking about this for a while and we've been watching EOP. And I said, "You know this is a deal we ought to do together."

Well Blackstone being Blackstone, they studied it and they said, "Yes it's a very good deal, we'd like to do it by our self, but we'd like you to buy the New York real estate." And they offered it to us under those terms, I think it was about a 4.3 or 4.25 cap rate. And while we liked the New York assets, they were not the kind of assets that we would normally buy. For us it was a play to buy the company. We turned it down, we said "no thank you." And [Harry Mackwell] bought it at a 3.1% cap rate.

Now it just knocked me over there was that kind of bubble. But what has happened, it is really the prime real estate that has continued to do relatively well. So do I think it's going to be as easy to lease space with the same kind of rate of appreciation? No, I don't.

But a lot of our buildings, we have the longest average lease term, I think it's about seven years and nine months, or six months, deliberately, because we are perfectly happy to predict what we think is going to be the market in two or three years, which is the nature of the development business. But if you're looking out 10 years, it's much difficult to predict, we'd rather have the longer-term leases.

And we are substantially full. I think we had a 99.52% occupancy rate the last time I looked at it. It may be slightly lower now. But I do think that we are -- it's going to be a tougher market environment for sure. Companies are going to be more conscious of the rents they are paying. But still I think we're in the right place, the right markets and the right buildings. And those will still, I think, do relatively well. There was a question back there, did I miss somebody?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: To the extent you're comfortable and maybe after the rest of questions on the economy, can you provide some thoughts on the upcoming election and also the Middle East?

MORT ZUCKERMAN: Well if the election had been held two weeks ago I believe John McCain would have won. The incredible credit freeze and the attempt on the part of the Administration to scare the American people into proving their particular version of bailing out the world of finance by saying, "Oh it's going to affect your credit at the -- you know the President yesterday had 20 small business men in, well they couldn't get their financing for their inventory or they couldn't get financing for their expansion or they couldn't get," --

The news that is emanating is that we are in a very, very serious economic time and it is affecting the entire attitude of the American public. It was always going to be the most important issue, the number one issue, but it is even more intensely shared and widely shared and widely believed to be by far the number one issue. Nobody's talking about Iraq, nobody's talking about very much else other than what's going on in the Congress and with this program.

And if you listen to them, the President goes there, I must say one of the worst speeches I've heard him give and, believe me, that's a real standard to break. But he spoke with complete lack of affect but he also said, you know we are on a verge of a tremendous possible decline. We must do something about it, it's going to affect everybody. And they want to get popular support.

There's huge popular antagonism to this bill. Huge. It is overwhelming. The calls that came into Washington are 300 to one against it because it was presented as a bailout. And it's a bailout of whom? It's presented as a bailout of the world of finance. Wall Street is the euphemism for the world of finance.

And the country sees and has seen Wall Street be so prosperous and do so well with getting salaries that were almost unimaginable, and bonuses. The bonuses for Wall Street community in the year 2006 were a mere $62 billion, that's [with the bonuses]. So when you have this as a political back drop, it's a real issue to say to somebody who has to sell his home, you have to sell it at market. But then he finds out that the government's going to buy in the Wall Street toxic paper at something above "market."

And that's what's going to happen because it's the only way to bail out the financial system. It may not be my preferred way of doing this in providing liquidity to the financial system, but it's the one we're going to have to live with. And we have to do something rather than nothing and I think therefore, at this point, we'll get through.

Although what the Senate did to this bill I have to tell you was just a disgrace. They added on I don't know how many, I think for raw manufacturers I think they got $190 million tax break. And there was another one I saw this morning that was just astounding.

So I do think that there is nothing that's going to happen between now and election day that is going to take this off the front pages. And therefore, on that issue, the country is going to say throw the bums out. You blame the party in power. And whatever you want to say about how much John McCain separated himself from the Bush Administration, which was quite considerably, it was very critical of it but that's irrelevant.

And even though Sarah Palin I think did extremely well last night in at least holding her own against Joe Biden, so all these concerns about her will be disappearing as they inevitably do for the Vice President in a national campaign. Unless something happens in those two debates that we can't foresee, or unless there is some major international event that will change what the subject is, I just don't see Obama losing. I think he will win and he may win fairly big. Five points or six points would be a very big victory for him.

Now as far as the Middle East is concerned, the Middle East is a very, very tough place to anticipate anything getting done. And if anything, conditions have gotten worse. But I will say this. Without going into it in any great detail since I happen to be personally involved in it, there is a great fear in the Middle East among the Sunni Arab countries, of Iran, they are obsessed with Iran. They put great pressure on the United States, on its President when he went there, on its Secretary of State when he went there, to do something about Iran.

Now in that sense there is a recognition that the dispute between Israel and the Palestinians is a side show. So that may create the environment in which progress will be made in that area. Certainly there is, legitimately, a sense that we have transformed the conditions on the ground in military terms, in security terms and today even in political terms in Iraq.

And that I think, if we stay in there for a long enough period of time, and it's not going to be 16 months, that would be a disaster in my judgment since we would throw away what we need, I will tell you something which I'm going to use in an editorial next week off the record.

When Obama was in Iraq on this tour [De'l Resond], that he made, every Sunni tribal leader signed a petition and said, please do not leave in the time period that you have espoused, because we need more time in order to make sure that we and the Shia community, because the Shia dominate the government, can find a way to work together. And if you do that, all the relationships that we are now trying to build will break down and we'll be back into a sectarian war.

Now it doesn't mean he's changing his position, as you heard Joe Biden say, because once these politicians take a stand they feel they cannot reverse themselves without being accused of being weak and flip flopping. That's the thing that worries me about a political campaign, that things are stated that are not necessarily in our national interest, but they are in the political interest of this or that candidate.

So that is the most worrisome thing. I don't think that there will be any kind of military attack on Iran, that I don't believe will happen. And they just had another resolution without any additional sanctions that was passed in the United Nations, so it's meaningless. But there would be intensive efforts on the part of at least the Western countries to intensify the effect of sanctions on Iran. And they will be joined by a lot of partners who will not be visible on the scenes because of the concerns that they all have about Iran.

So in one sense, there will be I think a very different balance in the whole area of the Middle East, including Afghanistan, all the way from Afghanistan to the Mediterranean than we've had before. And it will work in the favor of the United States. One last question I think. Yes, over here.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Can you talk a little bit about your view on short-term and long-term interest rates from here and how that affects commercial real estate valuations?

MORT ZUCKERMAN: Well firstly short-term funds of any significant size is virtually unavailable today. So anybody with cash is going to have an opportunity to do very well in terms of the purchase of real estate if they can finance it. You can't put together, even with the building where you have the building 85% pre-leased, you can't put together easily a $500 million construction loan or a $700 million construction loan, which we could have done a year ago with one telephone call.

So that is going to be a serious impediment to new construction, new development and to purchases. The financing of real estate is going to change dramatically, there's going to be a lot more in the way of equity financing that is going to be necessary.

And in that sense, the buyers will have the advantage of the market going forward. Which means in one sense purchase prices for buildings will go down. They're already gone down, as I said, 20%, 25%. They may go down another 10% or 15%. This is true, as I say of more conventional, real -- that is more commodity space, the highest level buildings have always sold at a premium and they're virtually unavailable.

Now longer term, of course, you have another issue because the -- not, two things will happen. One is the interest rates will go up for longer term financing maybe by 150 basis points. The ratio of the debt to the total purchase price will go down. Equity yields will be seen to have to go up.

And therefore on one level for a while, I think Cap rates will go up, not down. And I cannot tell you by how much, because literally nobody knows how serious this is. One of the things that is a counter veiling aspect here is that if the economy gets to be really weak, the Feds are going to do whatever they can to change the whole interest rate environment. And there may be some opportunities that come out of that.

I do believe in the short run that's going to be the case, but the private market is still very, very, very cautious. I think that's going to take a long time to rebuild the kind of confidence that is going to be necessary to do anything close to the financing that we've have been -- I don't think the financing we've had for the last several years is going to be available.

But even in more conventional times that financing is still going to be held back except for very, very limited number of situations and borrowers. I would like to think that we would be in the latter category, but that is all under the heading of TK, or to come. I think I'm probably taking too much of your time this morning, but I thank you all very much for the chance to speak with you.

So fortunately for us we had the foresight to put the brakes on a bit. We always have our next building teed up but it's premature at this point. RAY RITCHEY: Dave, how about the suburbs of Boston, we see settlement on there? DAVID PROVOST: In the suburbs, well we just finished up 77 which some of you will see today, 200,000 square feet and it's pre-leased. This about five building under construction in Central 128. We'll point them out today. Three are fully committed. The other two we've got just about 500,000 square feet about 2% of the overall market are not committed. So again I think we'll probably hold off. We also for our portfolio we have pretty significant roles in 2009, 2010 so I think we'd want to get comfortable with that before we'd go our speculative basis. But I must tell you there is -- Cambridge is such a tight market there is no development space for office left. There's none left. That's a finite market. It's bordered by residential, it's bordered by the university, it's bordered by the Charles River. So there's no other development site. Most of it is biotech. Many of those tenants we've seen over many square feet of migration out from Cambridge out to the suburbs. We think that's going to continue. We think that there are real build-to-suit of opportunities. So I think from a (inaudible) standpoint we feel very optimistic about that. RAY RITCHEY: Now David brings up a good point. It's interesting with this capital crisis our anecdotal observation both in Boston and a little bit in the Valley too -- Roger can opine to this. But the tech side does not seem to be constrained by the capital and still seem to be growing, still seem to be very strong, still be taking down space. Is that just an illusion or what are you seeing, Rod? ROD DIEHL: Now I mean -- there's definitely been continued demand from the tech side. I mean from a development perspective I mean the Silicon Valley does have, as the Bay area has probably more of the new construction that's underway right now, 3 million square feet plus or minus buildings that are either recently completed or under construction now. So there is some stuff in the pipeline. Now that sounds like a big number but keep in mind that Silicon Valley in total is a pretty big market. I mean you talk the office market and the R&D market. And if you combine the two that's about 215 million square feet. If you look at just the office market, which is maybe 60 million-plus just Class A R&D you're talking about 100 million square feet. So 3 million square feet of new is pretty -- it's pretty minimal. So as far as the demand for the space many of those buildings have yet to sign any leases. There's a few big deals that are out there circling now that we expect by the end of the year at least one or two of those will land. So the demand for tech in these new buildings hasn't really come to fruition yet. But I'd have to say I just saw the recent third quarter numbers for the R&D market and it is tracking the positive net absorption year-to-date, which is meaningful down there considering that many of our other sub-markets have had negative net absorption this year. So that's good news. RAY RITCHEY: John, how about -- I guess pharma is more your niche in Princeton there. What are you seeing in terms of pharma demand? JOHN BRANDBERGH: Pharma certainly is the driver in the Princeton market. In pharma-related companies we've had several expansions this year with CROs with clinical research organizations and anybody related to pharma advertising. We've got an advertising agency that specializes in pharma, go from 5,000 square feet to 35,000 square feet. RAY RITCHEY: And John (inaudible) how about the defense contracting in Brack in Northern Virginia and Maryland? JOHN BRANDBERGH: The tech community in the Washington area is really defense, intelligence and biotech. And unfortunately with what's going on in the world today fortunately for Washington those are all doing quite well. And I think for the foreseeable future will be the same. Also with the Brack realignment and I think some of you who follow Duke noticed that they picked up a very nice build-to-suit. It remains to be seen whether that actually goes all the way through because sometimes there's some head pegs there. But Brack, even though there's probably no net new consumption of space just the geographic relocation of that to other markets will hopefully stimulate some demand the other space we backfilled. That's certainly what we anticipate. Any other comments guys? UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Yes on the tech we just continue to see really dramatic growth from the tech group. And we'd talked about it earlier Jason Fivek who heads up our greater Waltham leasing he joined us, what? 2001, and I remember we talked about phantom space. He says, "What's phantom space?" That's from the '90s, people always talked about it and firms used to go in and say, "Okay if I'm experiencing dramatic growth I want to take 10%." They used to take 20% and look at the speculative leasing that happened in '99 and 2000. They were taking 100% more than they needed. Sometimes they didn't have anything and they took the space. Because everybody got burned he started when he did his first deals he was looking at expansion given six months of doing the lease. So if somebody needed 10,000 they would take 7,000. And we haven't seen any slowdown and continue to see real growth and again as we talk to them we say, "Have you seen any slowdown," and they're kind of all expecting it but nobody has seen it yet. RAY RITCHEY: You know this is -- we talked about a Wisconsin place building in Chevy Chase, Maryland and Doug mentioned that we have a deal pending for the balance of the building. Well it's actually Microsoft who is committed for -- I'm supposed to say that or not? Well it's Microsoft. Sorry, Doug. DOUG LINDE: The press release will be going out later today. RAY RITCHEY: And the big debate is whether they take the 64 or not in anticipation of growth because this is a building that is -- will be 100% leased. They're signing a seven to 10-year commitment and they don't want the situation where they're shy of the building. So we've seen the tech side be very, very stable in a relatively unstable market. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Now Microsoft that's a good example from that meeting -- I mean they're not specific to our space. But they had a real estate said they have a 1,000 job openings and haven't seen any slowdown, and if anything they're looking to grow and become -- in their core markets. I'm sure they're not growing in Oklahoma or Atlanta but they're growing in DC, they're growing in Boston and Cambridge, and they have a -- they're leasing with us 50,000 square feet. They are out in the market looking for 130,000 to 200,000 square feet of expansion. I mean that's incredible growth. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I'd like to add one other thing to that, Ray, is that the green tech -- I mean we see -- we're starting to see more of that with different tenants in the Valley in particular. This is an area that people have talked a lot about but we are starting to see some demand coming from that. In fact, just most recently there's a company called Solyndra which is a solar power. They've expanded, they're taking down some pretty concise piece of land up in the east side of the Silicon Valley. And Tesla Motors, which is not necessarily a tech company in a sense, but it is an electronic car company, electric car company. They recently announced a deal to take some land in north San Jose. So we have some of those tenants in our portfolio. We do have a solar company. We have a company that does biofuels and these are early-stage companies. They're starting small but they're looking for more space. I mean this one tenant, this 6,000 foot tenant, looking for 20. So there is a bright spot there. And Silicon Valley has reinvented itself many times over the last 40 years and this could be one other way that it does that. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Speaking of green, and [Michael Cana] did a great job talking about our approach to green. What are the tenants demanding? Is this a deal breaker on some deals? Is it a nice to have? What do we do in existing buildings when people say what are you going to do, make this building more environmentally sensitive? John, what happened with Princeton when you did that build-to-suit for them? JOHN BRANDBERGH: Princeton emphasized that they wanted a minimum of silver and fortunate for us most of that, the cost associated with that is coming from Princeton University. As far as second generation space we certainly always go green with carpet but we haven't done any, completed much of this at this time. RAY RITCHEY: And how about New York, what are you seeing with the -- DAVID PROVOST: It's definitely more of a -- it's definitely more of an attractive thing for a lot of foreign companies of which they're a lot in New York. But it's just -- it's starting from a development standpoint all the new developments are going to be lead, silver or gold. And that's just another marketing advantage of a new building, whether it's for a law firm who doesn't really understand why they need to be green. But they've got clients who want them to be green. They've got new employees that they're taking on every year who are younger and in tune to this stuff and trying to decide between two different firms from a recruiting standpoint it's something helpful to them. I mean every lawyer I have now at the bottom of their e-mails that I get saying, "Do you really need to print this document?" It's coming into the market climate. RAY RITCHEY: And the answer is usually yes? John, do you want to talk about the government's approach towards green in terms of some of the stuff we're looking in? UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: It's an absolute requirement if you do a lease with the federal government to have your building be green. It's definitely on every tenant's check list and depending on who the tenant is it may or may not be a deal breaker. One of the law firms we're dealing with I think it was kind of interesting that absolutely, positively had to be in a green building, and they put that right in the letter of intent. But they said, the landlord will not require us to build green space. I thought that was a little interesting. But I think that's the next wave. The buildings first, and then all of the tenant build-out space will eventually be green also. RAY RITCHEY: I'd like to throw out to the audience, are there any questions you'd like to ask our panel of experts about their respective markets or what they're seeing? Any questions? Yes Chris? UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible question - microphone inaccessible) that's a good, it's a very -- RAY RITCHEY: It's a timely question. UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Exactly, very timely. BlackRock has flip flopped a bit. Originally there were a -- they had a bulls eye on New Brunswick. For them to locate in the State of New Jersey they need to be in an urban enterprise zone which New Brunswick qualified for. And then Pennsylvania who is getting very aggressive trying to attract companies. Had them fairly close and now they're done a 180 and are concentrating on New Brunswick again and RFIs just went out. RAY RITCHEY: Are there questions? Michael? UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible question - microphone inaccessible) RAY RITCHEY: As a just overall market? Yes I think Mort touched on that today and [Mike Canlupa] may have as well. We acquired the Prudential about 10 years ago and at that time the Back Bay, and again for everybody who doesn't know the market, the downtown market, the overall urban market is 15 million square feet. Back Bay is maybe say 12 million to 14 million square feet depending on what you call Back Bay of that. So it's a smaller market. It has always traded at maybe 10% to 15% less than the financial district. That is swap now and I think the new development of the Prudential Center as well as some other developments is a big part of that. The high-end hedge funds and private equity firms came over and I think that obviously the brokers coming over that was really the final push that this is the place where people want to do it. Bryan Koop talked about it. It is -- people are working harder, it's about quality of life. It's about 24/7. It's about those things about recruiting and retaining. Boston's dirty little secret and again we have space down here so we're aware of it that the financial district there's not a lot of night life. There's not a lot of convenience retail. There's not a lot of residential. But we're really excited about next door bringing a lot of that and what is here is right along the waterfront. If you get deep into the concrete jungle as we talked about across the Greenway it's not -- it's not much different than glorified Hartford. And so some of the stuff we look as -- and that's not negative selling. That is just comparative analysis but -- UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Leave off from Hartford. RAY RITCHEY: Oh I'm sorry. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I like Hartford. RAY RITCHEY: All right, this is why I love these guys. Are these guys not great? DOUG LINDE: A press release will be going out. RAY RITCHEY: But anyhow, so again the vacancy rate we just talked about, the 6% overall so it's obviously higher on the financial district, still single digit. Back Bay is 3% and the biggest challenge that our downtown leasing team has is finding more space. That's why we're excited about Mike and the development group, 88 is really an expansion valve to help our tenants grow. And what's very interesting and everybody talks about, well as we talk to brokers and we talk to our clients is to your point maybe if we can wait, we will wait. Guess what? A lot of these people can't wait. They need more space. And what they're saying is everybody else is going to go out of business but I still need more space. And so you talk to these private equity firms actually everybody else that's in your portfolio is going to go out of business but I actually need to grow by 40%. And as we're continuing to see that now again. Is that going to turn in the next couple of months, we'll see. But right now it still remains pretty strong. RAY RITCHEY: One more question please, yes, Mitch? UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (inaudible question - microphone inaccessible) RAY RITCHEY: Maybe you want to start with that. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Sub-lease space has remained pretty constant at about 20% of direct availability. And during the 2001, the dot.com breakup that was up probably around 40%, 45%. So right now as a historical number it's pretty normal in terms of on-market. And I think the assumption is that that will increase up. But right now it's pretty healthy. RAY RITCHEY: John Brandbergh? JOHN BRANDBERGH: Yes the sub-lease rate in our market right now is about 10%. But fortunately and (inaudible) whenever we have sub-lease space we have in our leases Bob Pester and Rod have in theirs as well at Embarcadero Center that if you go to the sub-lease market for a sub-tenant you cannot compete with a landlord. So if we're talking to them or they're an existing tenant, we have available space that suits their needs they're prohibitive from doing sub-lease. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: In our three core markets sub-lease is at historic lows anywhere from 1% to 4%. I think the bigger -- what happens before sub-leases obviously layoffs. And we haven't seen -- and we're really watching this and to Doug point's we're all nervous Nellies. We're watching -- sub-lease seems to be that first indicator. But actually the first indicator is the layoffs. And again because we have a property measurement, we actually walk all our tenant spaces to make sure are there any empty offices. We're not seeing that. So in order for a lot of the space to go under the sub-lease market there would really need to be layoffs. So that's what we're really keeping our eye on. RAY RITCHEY: Now David do you think because Boston went through so many M&A activities, three, four, five years ago that we've been -- the blow is a little softened here in the last few months or what? DAVID PROVOST: Yes, there really isn't many banks left in Boston. I think the largest bank that's headquartered in Boston is what? The Eastern Bank, is that accurate? I mean that's a great trivia question. I don't know. I mean there's not a lot of -- and that was a real concern for us as we've been through enough downturns and our concern was eight years ago what's going to get us out of this mess? And 50 years ago it had been the banks and the Fidelity's of the world. This time it was really that mid-sized firm, 30,000 to 50,000 square feet going to 80,000 to 100,000. So it's a diverse tenant base and we feel pretty confident about it. RAY RITCHEY: Quick comments, guys, on sub-leasing, Rod? ROD DIEHL: Yes just quickly in San Francisco the sub-lease space has hedged up a little bit. This year we were running about 500,000 to 600,000 square feet. It's a little over a million square feet right now. And the metric that I usually track is what percentage of that is the overall available space? And right now in San Francisco that's about 16.5%. If you move down the peninsula that market has actually picked up a little bit more than that. That same metric is about 25% and if you go into the Silicon Valley it's about 13.5%. So it's probably worse in the peninsula and there's a couple of specific sub-leases that kind of move that number up. Down in the Redwood Shores that was a company called PDL that put a bunch of space on the market. So it's edged up a little bit but not dramatically. RAY RITCHEY: John, anything on the sub-lease environment? JOHN BRANDBERGH: Yes in our three markets the percentage of the total available space is 10% or less and that's down very dramatically from four or five years ago. Tenants are being very conservative in the amount of space that they take. We have never known a tenant that's gone out of business because they didn't have enough space. And I think to some extent even though we'd like tenants to lease more space it may make sense for us to support them in that. They are looking more at expansion down the road as opposed to -- which puts more of the onus on us. But they're being very conservative. RAY RITCHEY: Yes and these statistics that are being offered up here are market-wide statistics, and our own portfolio. I mean it's virtually non-existent I would say in all five of these regions. So like any good talking head show and specifically Mr. Zuckerman's [McLachlan] group, in fact he gives his condolences. He's now flying to down to tape Sunday's program so make sure you watch it. I'm sure he'll be talking about the same topics he talked about this morning. So I'm asking each one of our panelists to give a prediction of the coming year, and why don't we use a movie theme as kind of the basis behind it. John, do you want to start? JOHN BRANDBERGH: Well lots of different movies I can think of. But probably the best for the DC region is Being There -- actually the inflection is Been There. Being in the right location, in DC, you will be okay in the future. RAY RITCHEY: Rod Diehl? ROD DIEHL: I'm going to expand that, right, and a little bit beyond just one year if you wouldn't mind. I'm going to -- this might sound a little corny, but I'm going to say Little Miss Sunshine for California. And the reason is I have a good friend of mine who's in the home building industry and had this conversation there, feeling the tough times as we all know. He said to me when I asked him how things were going and if things were going to change in his world, and he said, "Look, this place is going to get better. It's a beautiful place to live. People are going to find a way to earn a living here and stay here, and it will recover." And I think that's the case. It may take awhile -- we don't know how long, but in the long term the Bay area is a wonderful area to live and to run your business and for that -- I think the go forward is positive. RAY RITCHEY: (inaudible) UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: I mean so much of our market is perception and I think if it was the tenant rep brokers they would say, atonement. You know I would think that the market is going to fall off a cliff. I think that if I had to say anything it's probably, I don't know, there's a movie, Frantic, was that what it was, Frantic? I mean was that a movie, Frantic? UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Sure. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Sounds good, why didn't I. I think I saw this movie and it was a Frantic, I remember it was with Harrison Ford and my wife and I watched it, we came out and it was just a real [clumper], it was very slow, and my wife said, "They should have renamed that Deeply Concerned." It really wasn't -- so I think the perception is that it's going to be frantic but everything is going to be fine. So how about, It's A Wonderful Life, how's that? RAY RITCHEY: John? JOHN BRANDBERGH: I think it's what you've been hearing all day, I'll reiterate, Best in Show. We have the best product and the best market. RAY RITCHEY: Good career move there, John. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Can I change my answer, Ray, Best in Show. JOHN BRANDBERGH: And we'll continue to weather the storms. DAVID PROVOST: In New York I have the writer's strike on so we're not really making great movies. I think the only prediction you can make in here is that there's going to be a lot of predictions in this movie. Up and down, and I think we all have to wait to see what the reality is going to be because right now there's a lot of perception and a lot of negative perception. But I think we'll have to see what the reality pans out to be. UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Yes, I thought you'd go with the Good, Bad and the Ugly. RAY RITCHEY: Well just first of all let's go to a round of applause to our panelists here, and Doug has been gracious enough to ask me to just kind of summarize today's presentation and the event last night. And again I think the message we try to get across again is the supply constrained nature of our markets, our long-term leases and the strong balance sheet. I think much more important than those three facts is what you saw today with the depth and breadth of talent that Boston Properties brings to solving the real estate issues of the day. From Mort Zuckerman down to this panel I think that I daresay that that was like the all-star line up of real estate. And I sat back in that room today so incredibly proud to have been associated with this company for 28 years. And more importantly looking forward to knowing that the team we've assembled here is going to do our darnedest. And that team, the 20-some odd people there today is merely reflective of the 650 people that are throughout out our buildings, throughout our regional offices, interacting every day with our tenants making sure we offer our clients the best possible space in our respective markets. Lastly I want to say to all of you we look at these conferences whether it's NAREIT or various investor conferences and we see many friends, and it's so great to see you all come back, come interested, participating and committed to making Boston Properties stores successful, and on that we're most grateful. So thank you very much. [Thomson Financial reserves the right to make changes to documents, content, or other information on this web site without obligation to notify any person of such changes. SANDRA SMITH, FBN ANCHOR: This is seen as a potential challenge to China's territorial claims over the contested waters.

Turning to markets this morning, it is a busy Tuesday on the earnings and economic calendars. We are getting earnings from big names, including Alibaba, Ford and UPS. We'll get readings on durable goods orders, home prices and consumer confidence. Ahead of all of that we are looking at futures markets here in the U.S., pointing to go lower open on Wall Street, small losses to kick off this Tuesday morning. Dow Futures off eight.

Tech also in focus. Both Apple and Twitter set to report earnings after the close of trading today. Checking in on market action overseas, looking over in Europe, where trading has gotten started, you're looking at the FTSE in London off 21 points; the CAC in France, off just a small a fraction of a percent, down two points. The DAX in Germany slightly higher.

Wal-Mart taking a page out of amazon's playbook. The retail giants want to use drones to make deliveries the company filing for regulatory approval. Wal-Mart also looking to use the devices to check warehouse inventories.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANNOUNCER: Flacco back, pressure on. To the middle, again, for Gilmore. And it ends, secured and intercepted by Tony Jefferson.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SMITH: The Baltimore Ravens missing a chance to tie up that game on the final play against the Arizona Cardinals. Ravens Quarterback, Joe Flacco, intercepted in the end zone, and Arizona won the game, 26-18.

And it's a big night for baseball. The World Series getting underway tonight in Kansas City. The Mets and Royals getting in one last workout yesterday before the series begins. It's said to be a pricey series for fans. The average ticket price is $723 and climbing, that's according to StubHub this morning and it gets more expensive when the teams face off in New York on Wednesday.

Well let's get to that new Monmouth University poll out this morning showing Donald Trump losing more ground in the state of Iowa, while making more controversial comments in a town hall in New Hampshire. Blake Burman has all the latest from Washington, and it gets even more interesting this morning, Black.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Day by day it does, Sandra. Good morning to you. Donald Trump still holds commanding leads nationally, and in a couple of the early of the early voting states, but there's a growing trend in Iowa, according to polls taken there over the last week. Dr. Ben Carson has supplanted Trump in the first caucus state. Take a look at this: Carson has won four of the last five polls there with the fifth being a tie. They're all fairly sizable spreads, with the most recent from Monmouth University showing Carson with a 14-point lead.

Meantime, Trump is facing some scrutiny for a couple of comments he made yesterday in New Hampshire. In one of them Trump said it's easy for women to wear burkas because they don't have to wear makeup.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: In fact, it's easier. You don't have to put on makeup. Look how beautiful everyone looks. Wouldn't it be easier? Right? Wouldn't that be easy? I tell you, if I was a woman, I don't want to -- I'm ready, darling, let's go. It's true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Separately, Sandra, Trump also took credit for Ford's decision to halt production plants truck plans in Mexico and stay in Ohio. However, that was strongly disputed by Ford and Ohio Governor, and presidential candidate, John Kasich. Sandra.

SMITH: All right, Blake Burman, thank you. Let's bring in former White House advisor to President Bush, Bryan Hook and Democratic Strategist, Richard Goodstein. Guys, I don't know where to begin.

[LAUGHTER]

SMITH: Let's first tackle the burka comment. Bryan, to you first, is this going to hurt Trump?

BRYAN HOOK, former ADVISOR, WHITE HOUSE: You know, historically we try not to view American foreign policy through the lens of the burka. This is a very strange comment to be made when we are talking about a real crisis in the Middle East. It makes him in that entertainer column and less in the commander-in-chief column.

SMITH: Well, Richard, normally, you know, I think we'd be looking at a comment like that and saying, gosh, every controversial comment he makes he seems to go up in the polls. Now we are talking about him losing ground in Iowa, again, to Dr. Carson. Are things starting to change here?

RICHARD GOODSTEIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Look, they're changing in a pretty fundamental way in this regard, Trump's whole calling card, incidentally so many of his comments are untethered from reality it makes me think he has a political death wish. His calling card is I'm a winner. If he loses, in his book he's a loser and there's nothing worse than being a loser to Donald Trump. So, he better turn that around in Iowa because he can't keep -- yes, he's ahead in all the other states, I understand that, but - incidentally, Ben Carson is the Gardner of this race, right? I know, I'm dating myself from the movie, being there, but he says all these inane things and people impute to it commonsense, when its, for the most part, idiocy. If I was a Republican, I would be scared to death, or frankly, somebody on Wall Street, that a major political party could nominate either of these two guys, it's scary.

SMITH: Bryan, it's hard to really decide where to go from here because it does seem that things are changing now, but at the same time, it seems like the establishment has been trying to figure out what to do with Donald Trump, but Donald Trump, responding to Richard's comment, has made it clear that he is not going to lose. He has made it clear that the second that he's dropping in the polls or it looks like he doesn't have a shot at winning the GOP primary, he said he's out of the race. He has made that very clear. So what naturally happens next?

HOOK: We have about a little less than 100 days until the Iowa caucus, and that's a long time in presidential politics. Trump is now down five points in that Monmouth poll since the last one. So we are -- we are seeing Trump lose altitude, and I think because we have what, you know, a few months left now, there's plenty of time for the race to move around. I do expect that you're going to see continual movement, and it's probably going to trend more in the establishment direction.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Can I raise an issue though, Gentlemen, and Rich, I know he's die to go make fun of me because I poo poo'ed when he said -

GOLDSTEIN: Thank you.

MCDOWELLL: He said Joe Biden was not going to run for president, and I said -- well, he's not. But with Iowa and to the good people of Iowa, how relevant are the caucuses, particularly with the Republicans, you look back, it was Rick Santorum and Mike Huckabee were -

GOLDSTEIN: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- the last two winners and they, well, were not the nominee?

GOLDSTEIN: Correct. Dagen, so you make a good point. There's even a different point, which is at this point four years ago, and I checked yesterday, on October 30th, 2011 poll, Herman Cain was in first, Mitt Romney was second, Rick Santorum, who ultimately won, was at five-percent. So, all this kind of bloviation about where the polls are, not just to us but everybody is a bit much and I think people have to take it into some perspective. You make a doubly good point, which is Iowa has not being a precursor of how somebody's going to do down the road. Again, for Trump, when your calling card is I'm a winner, and if you lose, that changes everything in people's eyes.

JONATHAN HILSENRATH, EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Can I jump in here? What struck me about these latest polls is that Ted Cruz is moving up. I want to hear both of you -- what you have to say about Ted Cruz and whether he's ready to make his move and whether such a move is sustainable?

HOOK: Senator Cruz has been hanging back and taking a very kind of slow and steady approach to the campaign and you know, somebody like Senator Cruz could play very well in Iowa but then when you see the other states that follow, New Hampshire, South Carolina and down the line, it gets a little trickier.

GOLDSTEIN: I would actually disagree a little bit, Bryan. Can I - if I don't mind. I predicted on your air, Sandra, with Maria, probably six weeks ago, that Cruz was the one to keep your eye on in this regard, I predict that Trump and Carson will crater. I think Cruz has a good shot at gutting kind of the evangelicals, the libertarians when Rand Paul goes away -

SMITH: If you're predict - if you're predicting that Dr. Carson will crater, we've heard your views on Trump, I'm going to force you to tell me why is Dr. Carson gaining so much in the polls right now.

GOLDSTEIN: So people say there's this whole outsider thing. That's just among Republicans, right? Democrats aren't showing any affection for outsiders and I think there's -- it's the same reason that tea party people are so angry with Congress. They are living kind of almost in an alternate reality that somehow or another, a guy like Carson, they just want to think that somehow there's something pure about him that's going to fix everything. It's, again, untethered from reality, but that would be my explanation for why Carson has this boom right now, because people just want to believe in those caucuses out there.

MCDOWELL: Richard, the democrats are showing benefit quite a bit of affection, in terms of money, at least, to -

SMITH: Bernie Sanders.

MCDOWELL: -- to Bernie Sanders.

HILSENRATH: Yes, that's the socialist. He's a bit of an outside the mainstream in Washington.

GOODSTEIN: No question. No question.

SMITH: Bryan last word to you.

HOOK: You're going to see continual movement around here. I also think you're going to see Ben Carson's change, probable quite a lot between now and when the first vote is cast in the Iowa caucuses.

SMITH: All right, good stuff. Bryan Hook and Richard Goodstein, thanks.

GOODSTEIN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: And I will just quickly point out that Trump referred to the media as scum and horrible people so that made me feel good.

HILSENRATH: But meanwhile we spend every segment talking about the guy.

MCDOWELL: Exactly, so where would he be without these --

HILSENRATH: We love what he's doing for our ratings.

MCDOWELL: The horrible scum that we are.

[LAUGHTER]

SMITH: All right, thank you, Gentlemen. Fox Business is teaming up with the "Wall Street Journal" to give you a Republican Debate focused on the economy, business and your money. Be sure to tune in on November 10th when the Republican candidates take the stage in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. You can only see that right here on the Fox Business Network.

I want to say thank you, Gentlemen. I was talking to our remote guests. Thank you, Dagen. Thank you, Jon.

HILSENRATH: Are you saying I'm not a gentleman?

SMITH: Moving on - oh, I can't win this morning. It must be Tuesday. Big tech earnings to look at this morning. Alibaba is scheduled to report before the bell, while Apple and Twitter are set to release results after the bell tonight. Everybody will be watching those. Estimates right now calling for Alibaba to post earnings per share .54 cents on revenues of $3.35 billion. Apple looking to beat Wall Street estimates for the fifth straight time. Investors will be focused on Iphone sales during the quarter and its forecast for the holidays. Twitter earnings puts the spotlight on newly minted CEO, Jack Dorsey. Since taking the reigns permanently this month, Dorsey has cut eight-percent of the company's workforce and donated a third of his stock to the employee equity pool.

Any big surprises that you're looking for today? Apple is going to be a big one to watch, obviously, and the fact that we are talking about the holidays when we are looking at all the earnings, Jon.

HILSENRATH: I'm certainly looking for Apple because the President of the Atlanta Fed has been saying this too, I want to see how consumers are holding up. There have been a lot of headwinds hitting the American economy. We've had a volatile stock market. We've had a stronger dollar, which is hurting exports. The big question for this economy is are consumers spending money? And we will see that if they're out buying Iphones.

SMITH: And it's shocking too, -- well, maybe not. As an economist you can tell me if I should be shocked, but here we have these low oil low prices, low gasoline prices and still we are not seeing the consumer spend that money elsewhere.

HILSENRATH: Not only that but we have unemployment rate coming down to nearly five -percent.

SMITH: Yes.

HILSENRATH: We have in American public that was scared by a very deep recession and slow recovery and people are reluctant to go out -

MCDOWELL: amazon is going to have record sales this holiday season.

SMITH: And FedEx says that they're going to have record shipments. So, people are shopping, it's just not necessarily -

MCDOWELL: And Mickey D's and Starbucks hit new all time highs in the stock market yesterday.

HILSENRATH: I don't know if McDonald's it's a great barometer for how aggressive Americans are spending.

[laughter]

HILSENRATH: -- but the other one I'm looking at is Ford. I think Ford - we are having a car boom right now, a car sales boom.

SMITH: Yes.

HILSENRATH: That's going to be an important one to watch.

MCDOWELL: So much that GM has given workers a raise, finally.

SMITH: All right, we are going to have more on that a little bit. Up next watch out for falling prices and drones. Why Wal-Mart wants to get into the drone delivery. Do you want one of these showing up in your doorstep?

MCDOWELL: No.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SMITH: The United States sending a warship near one of China's artificial islands in the South China Sea. Cheryl Casone's following this story and more for us this morning. Cheryl, good morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Sandra; good morning. Good morning, everyone. Defense Department officials say that a U.S. Navy Destroyer entered waters near the Spratley Islands in the South China Sea last night. The U.S. Lassen is armed with tomahawk missiles. This move is a direct challenge to China's claims that the artificial island chain is within its territorial boarders.

More than 300 people are dead after a 7.5 magnitude hit northeastern Afghanistan. Most of the deaths reported were in Pakistan, but tremors from the quake were also felt in northern India and Tajikistan. The death toll is set to rise, as the most severely affected areas are so remote that communications have been cut off.

Finally, the battle of the drones is heating up. This time it's Wal-Mart. The retailer applying to test drones, home delivery, curbside pickup and checking warehouse inventories. This move is a sign that the retailer plans to go head-to-head with amazon who has been vocal about their plans. Amazon says they're going to be ready to deliver these packages as soon as federal rules allow. That is the question mark because the FAA right, has to, you know, come together with the regulations. They're not even talking about beginning a framework, regulatory framework until 2016, at the earliest. So we can talk about delivery all we want. Are we going to see a drone in our doorstep? It's going to be a while.

SMITH: Right, so we're waiting on the air traffic control regulations these things, right, so they are not running into each other as they drop of your paper towels on your front door. I don't know, is that the goal?

MCDOWELL: I just can't get my head around this how they would execute this, particularly in a crowded urban area. I don't understand - and growing up in a very rural area, that wouldn't make sense either. I don't under - I don't' get it.

SMITH: What do you think, Jon?

HILSENRATH: There's a lot of suburb in the middle, and it looks like the FAA is moving towards allowing more and more of this, according to our story today on this, the FAA, it has issued already 2,000 approvals for testing and use of drones and commercial settings in different ways. What do I think of it? I think it's great. I think it's economic progress. It's an example of companies finding new ways to become more efficient.

SMITH: And it's exciting.

HILSENRATH: As creepy as it might feel -

[LAUGHTER]

MCDOWELL: -- because -

CASONE: No, it's dangerous.

MCDOWELL: It just feels, with the volume of packages that some of these businesses ship, I don't understand how they would actually execute it.

(Cross talk)

CASONE: This is the war that's brewing though, between pilots, between the FAA, the air traffic controllers and the companies. I mean, it's a great business idea -

MCDOWELL: The FAA can't keep up as technology develops.

CASONE: -- but you already have pilots saying, Dagen, that they're seeing these drones and that they are - the minute one goes into an engine this whole story changes.

MCDOWELL: But those are recreational drones that they've had the biggest problem --

CASONE: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- which now the FAA is requiring to be registered. A commercial drone would be less of a threat.

HILSENRATH: Dagen, when you look at a company like amazon or Wal-Mart, they have vast logistic organizations, --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

HILSENRATH: -- their job is to figure out how to make these things work at a lower cost than how to deal with -

MCDOWELL: I don't want my skies filled with these.

SMITH: So just to Dagen's point, they're going to test this out in small residential neighborhoods first, that's according to the Wal-Mart, --

HILSENRATH: Well they're also going to test it out in parking lots.

SMITH: -- and they're going to get permission from those living in the flight path, from the truck to the homes in that area. So it's complicated but it sounds like they --

MCDOWELL: Yes, test them in parking lots because I'm too lazy to get out of my car and go into the Wal-Mart.

SMITH: I am.

HILSENRATH: This is progress.

SMITH: We have to go. Jon Hilsenrath says this is economic progress. We'll keep watching it. Coming up, investors waiting for the Federal Reserve's first rate hike in nearly a decade. I know somebody we can talk to about that.

[LAUGHTER]

SMITH: We'll show you why you will not need to worry about that. We're keeping it simple for you right here on the Fox Business Network.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SMITH: All right, welcome back. Let's get a quick check on markets this morning. Futures right now pointing to a selloff on Wall Street, a small one. We are looking a small fraction of percentage losses across the board there.

One hot topic investors are watching this week is the Federal Reserve. The central Bank on the verge of raising interest rates for the first time in years, but Jon Hilsenrath is here and he says consumers have nothing to fear because mortgage rates will stay low for quite some time. So you need to break this down for us and keep it simple.

HILSENRATH: Right, so we are paying a lot of attention what the Fed is going to do. I have written a million stories about it this year, but the bottom line is for two reasons interest rates are going to stay low even after the Fed starts raising them. First of all, the U.S. economy and global economy are still fairy weak. They are not going gang busters, and in an environment like that, the Fed can't raise interest a lot. They might push them a little bit but not moving very fast. The other thing is that the Fed has telegraphed, they've already told us that they don't expect to raise aggressively after they do this first move, because inflation is also very low. So we are going into a period where once we get this first move off the Fed's table, there's going to be a very slow progression of follow-up interest rate increases.

If you look back to the 2004-2006 period, the last time Fed raised interest rates, we actually didn't see much movement in mortgage rates. In fact, we got a housing boom while the fed was raising rates.

SMITH: I was going to say, so that first interest rate hike, might it take some that are on the sidelines, might it bring in some of that pent up demand, where they're going to fear interest rates going higher so they'll jump in on the first hike?

HILSENRATH: I don't think it's going to be fear. I think what's going to happen is that when the Fed does this, people are going to say, hey, the world didn't end. I can get on with my life. I can go out and refinance my mortgage or take out a mortgage for a home -- particularly in the markets, you know. I think the markets are going to realize that the world didn't end when the feds does this and they're going to get on with the party.

SMITH: It's a good time to refinance right now?

HILSENRATH: You should refinance when it's right for you. If it's an opportunity now, you should go ahead and do it.

SMITH: All right, Jon Hilsenrath, thank you for keeping it simple. We will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SMITH: Good morning, everyone. I'm Sandra Smith, Maria Bartiromo is off this morning. It is Tuesday, October 27, and with me this hour fox Business', Dagen McDowell, and the "Wall Street Journal's" Jon Hilsenrath.

MCDOWELL: He said I was cranky this morning.

SMITH: He did?

MCDOWELL: He did. He's like, what's wrong with you? You're cranky. I said, no, I'm just disagreeing with you.

HILSENRATH: She's hating on drones.

MCDOWELL: I disagreed with you, there's a difference.

SMITH: Who said Tuesdays aren't fun? All right, these are your top stories at 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news: a debt deal on Capitol Hill. Congressional leaders and the White House reaching an agreement on a two year budget deal that also extends the debt limit. This marks one of the final acts for House Speaker, John Boehner, who is set to leave office Friday.

Turning to the 2016 race, Donald Trump losing more ground to Ben Carson in Iowa. The latest university poll shows Ben Carson has a double digit lead over Donald Trump, 32 percent to 18 percent. This coming as Trump made another round of controversial comments especially on women wearing a burkas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, 2016 U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE-REPUBLICAN: It is easy. You don't have to put on makeup. Look how beautiful everyone looks. Isn't that easy? I tell you, if I was a woman I would. I am ready, darling. Let's go. It's true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SMITH: It will be a busy, busy day for earnings and economic data. Walmart taking a page out of Amazon's playbook. The retail giant wants drones to make deliveries at your front door. The company filing for regulatory approval to do so. Walmart also looking to use the devices to check warehouse inventories.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: To the middle. Secured and intercepted by Tony Jefferson.

SMITH: The Baltimore Ravens missing a chance to tie up the game on the final play against the Arizona Cardinals. The Ravens Quarterback Joe Flacco was intercepted in the end zone and Arizona won the game 26 to 18.

It's a big night for baseball. The World Series getting under way tonight in Kansas City. Pitcher Matt Harvey is getting a start for the Mets and he will be going up against Edinson Volquez.

And one retailer is going dark on Black Friday. REI Sporting goods is canceling deals for the day and shutting down stores. Instead, the company wants shoppers to spend that time outside.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Here, here!

SMITH: Turning back to the markets, busy day on earnings and the economy. Alibaba scheduled to report earnings before the bell. Apple and Twitter are said to release results after the bell. We will also get September's Durable Goods orders which are expected to drop 1.2 percent as well as look at the housing market. Case-Shiller home price index will be out. Joining us to break all this down is Vining Sparks' Chief Economist Craig Dismuke. Welcome to you, Craig.

CRAIG DISMUKE, VINING SPARKS CHIEF ECONOMIST: Good morning.

SMITH: Alright, so, what are we looking for this morning? What is hot on your agenda?

DISMUKE: There are important reports, but right now everything is secondary to the inflation data. That is the real big elephant in a room kind of thing. Especially, with Fed policy and what is the Fed going to do. But in the durable-goods report, I expect we will see headline level orders expected to be down because of aircraft. Below that at the core level they're expected to be flat. What is most important will be the Capital goods orders report and specifically not a month over month basis because you get a little of noise on quarter over quarter basis. Orders have been pretty good. They're up 9.75 percent. That is their tracking for the quarter. Pointing for business investment being stronger in the future so that is good news. It's a good sign a business investment is stronger. If you look at the shipment of those items, they're up 2.75 percent quarter over quarter which point to business investment being of 2.75.

SMITH: Well, you obviously looked at these numbers closely. Much closer than any of us. Broadly speaking, where are we as far as economic progress in this recovery? Are we strengthening? And if we are, how slow or fast is it?

DISMUKE: I don't think we are strengthening. And John's point earlier, he mentioned the consumer is so key right now. This has been about the consumer driving economic growth and there have been phases to this recovery/expansion where different parts of the economy are driving activity. Right now, business investment has been weak, so it's down almost 5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year. It was flat in the second quarter of this year.

Business investment has been up and down but overall, it's been weak. It is good news that business investment is a little bit better. That's positive. But at the end of the day, the consumer is what is key and it is an important report but I think it's secondary to what is happening with the consumer and then again with inflation.

JOHN HILSENRATH, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Craig, I need you to settle a friendly disagreement between Dagen and me here about the housing market. We're getting home price data coming up. I say the housing market is strong and getting stronger. And she says it is garbage outside a few metro areas. What is your verdict and what are we going to see in the home price data that come out later today? Did I characterize your point of view?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Yes. And you used the word garbage (inaudible).

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

DISMUKE: It is home prices have been fairly strong, very little inventory. There's construction costs going up. Labor costs going up a little bit in housing. Lumber prices are down. Prices are generally going up. It is very -- the housing data is enigmatic right now. We are getting some weak data. Existing home sales better than expected last month. New home sales down 11.5 percent.

We keep getting this up and down activity. So, I would say in general housing market is trending better. But, there is that challenge and the challenge is if you look at 2013 when mortgage rates rose 90 basis points, housing total sales fell 13 percent. So, that was unusual. To see that drop from a 90 basis point increase. So, you look at what is different in the housing market today than in previous cycles. The biggest difference today is when you look at the number of owner occupied units which are down $2 million in 2005 and rent occupied units which are $10 million since 2006. Which is not good because people who rent cars don't wash them. I have never washed one.

Some people who rent houses or rent multifamily places aren't going to make a capital investment where they are living that we had when we had more of an ownership society so long term as a challenge.

HILSENRATH: We saw in the Glass-Steagall people over invested in those homes and wasted capital in the process. And a lot of other countries you don't have as much emphasis on home ownership. And they have perfectly civil society.

DISMUKE: Sure, but their economic growth is not as strong as we saw when we had more of a homeownership society. When you own something you take more pride in it and you're going to invest in it. And so, I think, in long-term it will be a different housing market. The peak housing was 6.2 percent.

HILSENRATH: Also, demographics at play here.

DISMUKE: That's a big one. The aging population is a demographic issue. It doesn't get enough focus at this point.

MCDOWELL: Like buying homes and selling it though.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: I don't think seniors are going to start trashing their homes. It's a different dynamic.

SMITH: Almost like those houses are maintained to higher standard because they are turned over so often and have to be maintained. That is the discussion for another day. Craig, great stuff. Thank you. Interesting perspective. John, you win.

MCDOWELL: John just leaned in and said I was right

SMITH: Alright. JP Morgan with its own mobile payment platform to rival existing services like Apple Paid. Nicole Petallides has that story this morning. Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: That's right. The country's largest bank is stepping into the ring with the world's most valuable company. JP Morgan is the latest investor in the mobile payments based announcing Chase Pay, a platform that will allow Chase customers to make retail purchases using their smart phone. Creating a direct competitor to Apple Pay. JP Morgan says it has already won the endorsement of a major group of merchants giving it a leg up on the tech savvy rivals. So, the question is are consumers ready to use their phones, smart phones, ditch the credit cards and what happened to cash is king?

SMITH: Anybody use Apple Pay?

MCDOWELL: I have signed up for it but I don't know how to use it in stores.

PETALLIDES: Using your smart phone will be the preferred method of payment. I mean, I just got used to using my debit card in the taxi. Just got out of using cash. This is the wave of the future and there is Apple Pay, Chase Pay credit cards.

(CROSSTALK)

SMITH: A total shift back to cash because everyone is afraid of the paper trail using credit cards and people accessing their data and now, we're going to be even more exposed with all this going on to our smart phones.

HILSENRATH: There isn't going to be. We see where it is going. People moving more towards mobile payments. And cash. I could go weeks without using my cash.

MCDOWELL: Here's why I use a credit card over cash and smart phones. Because I use cash. If I have more than $20, I will drop it and lose it. HILSENRATH: I call it bonus bucks when I discover cash.

MCDOWELL: If I lose it, it usually comes back. I have a tendency to drop it. And with a credit card I keep one credit card in my pocket.

SMITH: You guys must not be good tippers. How can you go through New York City without a few bucks in your pocket? Not that kind.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You add the tip. You don't have to worry about signing a form.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: This is just to bring it back to drones. This is like drones. This is progress when we see new ways of making payments.

MCDOWELL: I fully believe (inaudible)

(CROSSTALK)

PETALLIDES: Be honest here. It's unbelievable. This is the wave of the future. Kids staying with babysitters and nannies demand it.

(CROSSTALK)

SMITH: Alright. Don't forget to start your day with Nicole Petallides on FBN: a.m. at 5:00 a.m. eastern. Catch it on the Fox Business Network. Up next. Is there a link between artificial turf and cancer?

We'll look at a new report that could cause major concerns in the world of sports. A lot of people have been talking about this. Keep it right here on Fox Business.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SMITH: Dreamworks Animation's CEO thanking Elon Musk for saving his life. Cheryl Casone has that story.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Jeffrey Katzenberg is crediting Elon Musk with his survival after a life-threatening car accident in Hollywood on October 19th. Dreamworks Animation's CEO drove an electric Tesla model X Sedan. His car was totaled. He needed surgery after injuring his arm and wrist in the accident but he credits his life-saving experience and crash, thanks to Tesla.

Our sources say Bill De Blasio is getting to endorse Hillary Clinton before his planned candidate forum on November 6th. Discussions are reportedly under way between the two sides and how Bill De Blasio backing Clinton will be announced.

And according to a recent survey, 49 percent of streaming on demand users ages 8 to 29 share at least one account with someone outside of their home.

HBO and other video providers might not encourage password sharing, but they also don't track it. And we know it happens all the time. You give your log information to a friend of a friend or your parents, your neighbor and they use the service. They can't track it. This proliferates.

HILSENRATH: So, how is that different from me leaving my newspaper at the airport and someone picking it up and reading it?

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: It's one newspaper. Not thousands of movies.

HILSENRATH: But you're only sharing a password with one friend.

MCDOWELL: How much revenue if they get shared around a lot more. Netflix, they have subscriptions where you get the family plan or two log ins.

CASONE: This really hurts HBO and Showtime and HULU. And they don't have a way to know your giving your password to whether people. For all they know you have the computer going in one room and your TV going and it is you. The same as if you have a wall street journal log on and share it with somebody.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: You will always get leakage and you have to live with it. To the extent that it makes your friend or your relative that much more interested than your Hulu (inaudible)

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Leakage in the digital world is much greater than in the paper world.

HILSENRATH: It has always been there.

MCDOWELL: It's always been there, but Sandra. She is about to lose her stuff.

(LAUGHTER)

SMITH: Thanks Dagen.

CASONE: All fair point.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: I don't share my password with anyone. (CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: The word retailers use to describe the thievery or shoplifting.

SMITH: Alright. Athletes and parents beware the artificial turf at thousands of schools and parks around the country could be dangerous. The New York Times did this story a year ago. A lot of people still talking about it and surprised by it. Find out what is behind the latest health scare on this turf. Straight ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Top headlines in the Wall Street Journal. After years of decline, U.S. imports on the rise as low oil prices forced domestic producers to scale back supplies. Phil Flynn and the CME group. So, Phil, long story short, we are not producing as much here so we are having to buy it there and bring it in. Is that what is happening?

PHIL FLYNN, CME GROUP: Well, that's exactly what is happening and we are losing the OPECSaudi Arabia started. What we are seeing is these other OPEC oil producers, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia are cutting prices, driving our guys out of business. This is what Saudi rate wanted to do. Can they sustain this price war? We know they are having big financial problems in these countries.

They can't continue to cut prices below our producers. The quality of the oil they are getting. Our refiners are used to refining Saudi oil and Nigerian oil. The shale oil is a little more difficult for them to refine because it is such a high-quality type of oil. They are not used to doing it, better off to export.

The other big story, natural gas, lowest price in three years. We broke below $2, 1 million metric BTUs. Winter might have been canceled because warm weather forecasts driving prices lower.

SMITH: This is part of the deal that was reached late last night. U.S. is planning to sell millions of barrels of crude oil from our strategic petroleum reserve from 2018 through 2025 under the budget deal reached last night. This is the second time the U.S. has raised cash from the reserve. Notable event?

FLYNN: It is a very notable event. It's basically showing we don't need the strategic petroleum reserve. We have a new reserve called North Dakota. The global energy market is changing. The other thing when you look at selling oil from the reserve, from the policy when we were worried about peak oil and the Middle East cutting off power supply. Now they're burying us with supplies.

SMITH: And the report shows a link with green artificial turf and cancer. Questions have been raised about synthetic fiber and scrap tire that makes up the surface. There's the belief that the tiny black rubber crimson the surface which have been known to contain carcinogens and chemicals can make people sick. However, there is no scientific data to prove the connection between the two. Okay, John. Your son plays football and lacrosse on turf.

HILSENRATH: Plays on turf all the time. My two sons and my daughter play on turf all the time. Frankly, there are a lot of other things that happen on those fields I worry about a lot more. When there's no scientific evidence to back it up. You worry about concussions and other injuries. I want to see some hard evidence before I put this on the list of things to worry about.

SMITH: We were living on asphalt green, so fun to play on it but it made you think all the little black or brown pellets in the turf. You get up and it's all over you. Amazing. It gets in their mouths, makes you wonder.

MCDOWELL: I have bruises, doing a workout in the last few days. I think maybe you ought to worry about feeding your kids bacon and hot dogs if you are worried about cancer before you worry about artificial turf. Based on the Wall Street Journal today. That is the big deal.

HILSENRATH: Red meat tied to cancer. Pay a little more attention because there is --

(CROSSTALK)

SMITH: Most of these reports is more correlation than causation.

HILSENRATH: The health organizations study is more scientific and I haven't looked at it but I would think they're close it to causation and correlation. The other problem here is every couple of weeks there is a news story telling us you need to worry about this or that. Americans are over worried with worried lists.

MCDOWELL: You ought to worry. Women getting lung cancer who never smoked is on the rise. Even as the numbers of people who are not smoking in this country are declining. And yet, they have to figure out what it is called.

HILSENRATH: But, you can stop doing everything. You got to figure out what is causing it and respond to that. You can't stop going on artificial turf.

(CROSSTALK)

SMITH: Russell investments Steven Wood joins us to weigh in on a big day of tech earnings. Plus, former treasury secretary David Malpass with his thoughts on a potential budget deal. We have a great couple hours coming up. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SMITH: Sandra Smith in for Maria Bartiroma. With me is Fox Business's Dagen McDowell and Wall Street Journal Chief Economic Correspondent Jon Hilsenrath. But, first your top stories breaking news. A debt deal on Capitol Hill and congressional leaders reaching an agreement on a two- year budget deal that also extends the debt limit. But it could be problematic for his likely replacement congressional Congressman Paul Ryan over concerns from conservatives who will not support raising the debt limit.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DARRELL ISSA, CALIFORNIA CONGRESSMAN-REPUBLICAN: We are about the transition to a new speaker. It is important that we have the speaker to be Ryan, what leadership role. It was the combination of the majority but you need to to have the new speaker in the lead in this process.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SMITH: Donald Trump making more controversial comments on women.

END
