urn:contentItem:5H83-0FF1-DXH2-6498-00000-00Both Apple and Twitter set to report earnings after the close of trading today; Baltimore Ravens lose to Arizona Cardinals, 26-18; The Baltimore Ravens lose to Arizona Cardinals getting underway tonight in Kansas City; Defense Department officials say that a U.S. Navy Destroyer entered waters near the Spratley Islands in the South China Sea last night; More than 300 people are dead after a 7.5 magnitude earthquake hit northeastern Afghanistan2015-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJonathan Hilsenrath; Donald Trump; Bryan Hook; Richard GoodsteinNEWSInternational102701cb.231Both Apple and Twitter set to report earnings after the close of trading today; Baltimore Ravens lose to Arizona Cardinals, 26-18; The Baltimore Ravens lose to Arizona Cardinals getting underway tonight in Kansas City; Defense Department officials say that a U.S. Navy Destroyer entered waters near the Spratley Islands in the South China Sea last night; More than 300 people are dead after a 7.5 magnitude earthquake hit northeastern AfghanistanMaria Bartiromo; Dagen McDowell; Phil Flynn; Blake Burman; Cheryl Casone; Jo Ling Kent; Sandra Smith; Nicole Petallides; Scott Martin

SANDRA SMITH, FBN ANCHOR: This is seen as a potential challenge to China's territorial claims over the contested waters.

Turning to markets this morning, it is a busy Tuesday on the earnings and economic calendars. We are getting earnings from big names, including Alibaba, Ford and UPS. We'll get readings on durable goods orders, home prices and consumer confidence. Ahead of all of that we are looking at futures markets here in the U.S., pointing to go lower open on Wall Street, small losses to kick off this Tuesday morning. Dow Futures off eight.

Tech also in focus. Both Apple and Twitter set to report earnings after the close of trading today. Checking in on market action overseas, looking over in Europe, where trading has gotten started, you're looking at the FTSE in London off 21 points; the CAC in France, off just a small a fraction of a percent, down two points. The DAX in Germany slightly higher.

Wal-Mart taking a page out of amazon's playbook. The retail giants want to use drones to make deliveries the company filing for regulatory approval. Wal-Mart also looking to use the devices to check warehouse inventories.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANNOUNCER: Flacco back, pressure on. To the middle, again, for Gilmore. And it ends, secured and intercepted by Tony Jefferson.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SMITH: The Baltimore Ravens missing a chance to tie up that game on the final play against the Arizona Cardinals. Ravens Quarterback, Joe Flacco, intercepted in the end zone, and Arizona won the game, 26-18.

And it's a big night for baseball. The World Series getting underway tonight in Kansas City. The Mets and Royals getting in one last workout yesterday before the series begins. It's said to be a pricey series for fans. The average ticket price is $723 and climbing, that's according to StubHub this morning and it gets more expensive when the teams face off in New York on Wednesday.

Well let's get to that new Monmouth University poll out this morning showing Donald Trump losing more ground in the state of Iowa, while making more controversial comments in a town hall in New Hampshire. Blake Burman has all the latest from Washington, and it gets even more interesting this morning, Black.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Day by day it does, Sandra. Good morning to you. Donald Trump still holds commanding leads nationally, and in a couple of the early of the early voting states, but there's a growing trend in Iowa, according to polls taken there over the last week. Dr. Ben Carson has supplanted Trump in the first caucus state. Take a look at this: Carson has won four of the last five polls there with the fifth being a tie. They're all fairly sizable spreads, with the most recent from Monmouth University showing Carson with a 14-point lead.

Meantime, Trump is facing some scrutiny for a couple of comments he made yesterday in New Hampshire. In one of them Trump said it's easy for women to wear burkas because they don't have to wear makeup.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: In fact, it's easier. You don't have to put on makeup. Look how beautiful everyone looks. Wouldn't it be easier? Right? Wouldn't that be easy? I tell you, if I was a woman, I don't want to -- I'm ready, darling, let's go. It's true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Separately, Sandra, Trump also took credit for Ford's decision to halt production plants truck plans in Mexico and stay in Ohio. However, that was strongly disputed by Ford and Ohio Governor, and presidential candidate, John Kasich. Sandra.

SMITH: All right, Blake Burman, thank you. Let's bring in former White House advisor to President Bush, Bryan Hook and Democratic Strategist, Richard Goodstein. Guys, I don't know where to begin.

[LAUGHTER]

SMITH: Let's first tackle the burka comment. Bryan, to you first, is this going to hurt Trump?

BRYAN HOOK, former ADVISOR, WHITE HOUSE: You know, historically we try not to view American foreign policy through the lens of the burka. This is a very strange comment to be made when we are talking about a real crisis in the Middle East. It makes him in that entertainer column and less in the commander-in-chief column.

SMITH: Well, Richard, normally, you know, I think we'd be looking at a comment like that and saying, gosh, every controversial comment he makes he seems to go up in the polls. Now we are talking about him losing ground in Iowa, again, to Dr. Carson. Are things starting to change here?

RICHARD GOODSTEIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Look, they're changing in a pretty fundamental way in this regard, Trump's whole calling card, incidentally so many of his comments are untethered from reality it makes me think he has a political death wish. His calling card is I'm a winner. If he loses, in his book he's a loser and there's nothing worse than being a loser to Donald Trump. So, he better turn that around in Iowa because he can't keep -- yes, he's ahead in all the other states, I understand that, but - incidentally, Ben Carson is the Gardner of this race, right? I know, I'm dating myself from the movie, being there, but he says all these inane things and people impute to it commonsense, when its, for the most part, idiocy. If I was a Republican, I would be scared to death, or frankly, somebody on Wall Street, that a major political party could nominate either of these two guys, it's scary.

SMITH: Bryan, it's hard to really decide where to go from here because it does seem that things are changing now, but at the same time, it seems like the establishment has been trying to figure out what to do with Donald Trump, but Donald Trump, responding to Richard's comment, has made it clear that he is not going to lose. He has made it clear that the second that he's dropping in the polls or it looks like he doesn't have a shot at winning the GOP primary, he said he's out of the race. He has made that very clear. So what naturally happens next?

HOOK: We have about a little less than 100 days until the Iowa caucus, and that's a long time in presidential politics. Trump is now down five points in that Monmouth poll since the last one. So we are -- we are seeing Trump lose altitude, and I think because we have what, you know, a few months left now, there's plenty of time for the race to move around. I do expect that you're going to see continual movement, and it's probably going to trend more in the establishment direction.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Can I raise an issue though, Gentlemen, and Rich, I know he's die to go make fun of me because I poo poo'ed when he said -

GOLDSTEIN: Thank you.

MCDOWELLL: He said Joe Biden was not going to run for president, and I said -- well, he's not. But with Iowa and to the good people of Iowa, how relevant are the caucuses, particularly with the Republicans, you look back, it was Rick Santorum and Mike Huckabee were -

GOLDSTEIN: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- the last two winners and they, well, were not the nominee?

GOLDSTEIN: Correct. Dagen, so you make a good point. There's even a different point, which is at this point four years ago, and I checked yesterday, on October 30th, 2011 poll, Herman Cain was in first, Mitt Romney was second, Rick Santorum, who ultimately won, was at five-percent. So, all this kind of bloviation about where the polls are, not just to us but everybody is a bit much and I think people have to take it into some perspective. You make a doubly good point, which is Iowa has not being a precursor of how somebody's going to do down the road. Again, for Trump, when your calling card is I'm a winner, and if you lose, that changes everything in people's eyes.

JONATHAN HILSENRATH, EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Can I jump in here? What struck me about these latest polls is that Ted Cruz is moving up. I want to hear both of you -- what you have to say about Ted Cruz and whether he's ready to make his move and whether such a move is sustainable?

HOOK: Senator Cruz has been hanging back and taking a very kind of slow and steady approach to the campaign and you know, somebody like Senator Cruz could play very well in Iowa but then when you see the other states that follow, New Hampshire, South Carolina and down the line, it gets a little trickier.

GOLDSTEIN: I would actually disagree a little bit, Bryan. Can I - if I don't mind. I predicted on your air, Sandra, with Maria, probably six weeks ago, that Cruz was the one to keep your eye on in this regard, I predict that Trump and Carson will crater. I think Cruz has a good shot at gutting kind of the evangelicals, the libertarians when Rand Paul goes away -

SMITH: If you're predict - if you're predicting that Dr. Carson will crater, we've heard your views on Trump, I'm going to force you to tell me why is Dr. Carson gaining so much in the polls right now.

GOLDSTEIN: So people say there's this whole outsider thing. That's just among Republicans, right? Democrats aren't showing any affection for outsiders and I think there's -- it's the same reason that tea party people are so angry with Congress. They are living kind of almost in an alternate reality that somehow or another, a guy like Carson, they just want to think that somehow there's something pure about him that's going to fix everything. It's, again, untethered from reality, but that would be my explanation for why Carson has this boom right now, because people just want to believe in those caucuses out there.

MCDOWELL: Richard, the democrats are showing benefit quite a bit of affection, in terms of money, at least, to -

SMITH: Bernie Sanders.

MCDOWELL: -- to Bernie Sanders.

HILSENRATH: Yes, that's the socialist. He's a bit of an outside the mainstream in Washington.

GOODSTEIN: No question. No question.

SMITH: Bryan last word to you.

HOOK: You're going to see continual movement around here. I also think you're going to see Ben Carson's change, probable quite a lot between now and when the first vote is cast in the Iowa caucuses.

SMITH: All right, good stuff. Bryan Hook and Richard Goodstein, thanks.

GOODSTEIN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: And I will just quickly point out that Trump referred to the media as scum and horrible people so that made me feel good.

HILSENRATH: But meanwhile we spend every segment talking about the guy.

MCDOWELL: Exactly, so where would he be without these --

HILSENRATH: We love what he's doing for our ratings.

MCDOWELL: The horrible scum that we are.

[LAUGHTER]

SMITH: All right, thank you, Gentlemen. Fox Business is teaming up with the "Wall Street Journal" to give you a Republican Debate focused on the economy, business and your money. Be sure to tune in on November 10th when the Republican candidates take the stage in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. You can only see that right here on the Fox Business Network.

I want to say thank you, Gentlemen. I was talking to our remote guests. Thank you, Dagen. Thank you, Jon.

HILSENRATH: Are you saying I'm not a gentleman?

SMITH: Moving on - oh, I can't win this morning. It must be Tuesday. Big tech earnings to look at this morning. Alibaba is scheduled to report before the bell, while Apple and Twitter are set to release results after the bell tonight. Everybody will be watching those. Estimates right now calling for Alibaba to post earnings per share .54 cents on revenues of $3.35 billion. Apple looking to beat Wall Street estimates for the fifth straight time. Investors will be focused on Iphone sales during the quarter and its forecast for the holidays. Twitter earnings puts the spotlight on newly minted CEO, Jack Dorsey. Since taking the reigns permanently this month, Dorsey has cut eight-percent of the company's workforce and donated a third of his stock to the employee equity pool.

Any big surprises that you're looking for today? Apple is going to be a big one to watch, obviously, and the fact that we are talking about the holidays when we are looking at all the earnings, Jon.

HILSENRATH: I'm certainly looking for Apple because the President of the Atlanta Fed has been saying this too, I want to see how consumers are holding up. There have been a lot of headwinds hitting the American economy. We've had a volatile stock market. We've had a stronger dollar, which is hurting exports. The big question for this economy is are consumers spending money? And we will see that if they're out buying Iphones.

SMITH: And it's shocking too, -- well, maybe not. As an economist you can tell me if I should be shocked, but here we have these low oil low prices, low gasoline prices and still we are not seeing the consumer spend that money elsewhere.

HILSENRATH: Not only that but we have unemployment rate coming down to nearly five -percent.

SMITH: Yes.

HILSENRATH: We have in American public that was scared by a very deep recession and slow recovery and people are reluctant to go out -

MCDOWELL: amazon is going to have record sales this holiday season.

SMITH: And FedEx says that they're going to have record shipments. So, people are shopping, it's just not necessarily -

MCDOWELL: And Mickey D's and Starbucks hit new all time highs in the stock market yesterday.

HILSENRATH: I don't know if McDonald's it's a great barometer for how aggressive Americans are spending.

[laughter]

HILSENRATH: -- but the other one I'm looking at is Ford. I think Ford - we are having a car boom right now, a car sales boom.

SMITH: Yes.

HILSENRATH: That's going to be an important one to watch.

MCDOWELL: So much that GM has given workers a raise, finally.

SMITH: All right, we are going to have more on that a little bit. Up next watch out for falling prices and drones. Why Wal-Mart wants to get into the drone delivery. Do you want one of these showing up in your doorstep?

MCDOWELL: No.

SMITH: The United States sending a warship near one of China's artificial islands in the South China Sea. Cheryl Casone's following this story and more for us this morning. Cheryl, good morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Sandra; good morning. Good morning, everyone. Defense Department officials say that a U.S. Navy Destroyer entered waters near the Spratley Islands in the South China Sea last night. The U.S. Lassen is armed with tomahawk missiles. This move is a direct challenge to China's claims that the artificial island chain is within its territorial boarders.

More than 300 people are dead after a 7.5 magnitude hit northeastern Afghanistan. Most of the deaths reported were in Pakistan, but tremors from the quake were also felt in northern India and Tajikistan. The death toll is set to rise, as the most severely affected areas are so remote that communications have been cut off.

Finally, the battle of the drones is heating up. This time it's Wal-Mart. The retailer applying to test drones, home delivery, curbside pickup and checking warehouse inventories. This move is a sign that the retailer plans to go head-to-head with amazon who has been vocal about their plans. Amazon says they're going to be ready to deliver these packages as soon as federal rules allow. That is the question mark because the FAA right, has to, you know, come together with the regulations. They're not even talking about beginning a framework, regulatory framework until 2016, at the earliest. So we can talk about delivery all we want. Are we going to see a drone in our doorstep? It's going to be a while.

SMITH: Right, so we're waiting on the air traffic control regulations these things, right, so they are not running into each other as they drop of your paper towels on your front door. I don't know, is that the goal?

MCDOWELL: I just can't get my head around this how they would execute this, particularly in a crowded urban area. I don't understand - and growing up in a very rural area, that wouldn't make sense either. I don't under - I don't' get it.

SMITH: What do you think, Jon?

HILSENRATH: There's a lot of suburb in the middle, and it looks like the FAA is moving towards allowing more and more of this, according to our story today on this, the FAA, it has issued already 2,000 approvals for testing and use of drones and commercial settings in different ways. What do I think of it? I think it's great. I think it's economic progress. It's an example of companies finding new ways to become more efficient.

SMITH: And it's exciting.

HILSENRATH: As creepy as it might feel -

[LAUGHTER]

MCDOWELL: -- because -

CASONE: No, it's dangerous.

MCDOWELL: It just feels, with the volume of packages that some of these businesses ship, I don't understand how they would actually execute it.

(Cross talk)

CASONE: This is the war that's brewing though, between pilots, between the FAA, the air traffic controllers and the companies. I mean, it's a great business idea -

MCDOWELL: The FAA can't keep up as technology develops.

CASONE: -- but you already have pilots saying, Dagen, that they're seeing these drones and that they are - the minute one goes into an engine this whole story changes.

MCDOWELL: But those are recreational drones that they've had the biggest problem --

CASONE: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- which now the FAA is requiring to be registered. A commercial drone would be less of a threat.

HILSENRATH: Dagen, when you look at a company like amazon or Wal-Mart, they have vast logistic organizations, --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

HILSENRATH: -- their job is to figure out how to make these things work at a lower cost than how to deal with -

MCDOWELL: I don't want my skies filled with these.

SMITH: So just to Dagen's point, they're going to test this out in small residential neighborhoods first, that's according to the Wal-Mart, --

HILSENRATH: Well they're also going to test it out in parking lots.

SMITH: -- and they're going to get permission from those living in the flight path, from the truck to the homes in that area. So it's complicated but it sounds like they --

MCDOWELL: Yes, test them in parking lots because I'm too lazy to get out of my car and go into the Wal-Mart.

SMITH: I am.

HILSENRATH: This is progress.

SMITH: We have to go. Jon Hilsenrath says this is economic progress. We'll keep watching it. Coming up, investors waiting for the Federal Reserve's first rate hike in nearly a decade. I know somebody we can talk to about that.

[LAUGHTER]

SMITH: We'll show you why you will not need to worry about that. We're keeping it simple for you right here on the Fox Business Network.

SMITH: All right, welcome back. Let's get a quick check on markets this morning. Futures right now pointing to a selloff on Wall Street, a small one. We are looking a small fraction of percentage losses across the board there.

One hot topic investors are watching this week is the Federal Reserve. The central Bank on the verge of raising interest rates for the first time in years, but Jon Hilsenrath is here and he says consumers have nothing to fear because mortgage rates will stay low for quite some time. So you need to break this down for us and keep it simple.

HILSENRATH: Right, so we are paying a lot of attention what the Fed is going to do. I have written a million stories about it this year, but the bottom line is for two reasons interest rates are going to stay low even after the Fed starts raising them. First of all, the U.S. economy and global economy are still fairy weak. They are not going gang busters, and in an environment like that, the Fed can't raise interest a lot. They might push them a little bit but not moving very fast. The other thing is that the Fed has telegraphed, they've already told us that they don't expect to raise aggressively after they do this first move, because inflation is also very low. So we are going into a period where once we get this first move off the Fed's table, there's going to be a very slow progression of follow-up interest rate increases.

If you look back to the 2004-2006 period, the last time Fed raised interest rates, we actually didn't see much movement in mortgage rates. In fact, we got a housing boom while the fed was raising rates.

SMITH: I was going to say, so that first interest rate hike, might it take some that are on the sidelines, might it bring in some of that pent up demand, where they're going to fear interest rates going higher so they'll jump in on the first hike?

HILSENRATH: I don't think it's going to be fear. I think what's going to happen is that when the Fed does this, people are going to say, hey, the world didn't end. I can get on with my life. I can go out and refinance my mortgage or take out a mortgage for a home -- particularly in the markets, you know. I think the markets are going to realize that the world didn't end when the feds does this and they're going to get on with the party.

SMITH: It's a good time to refinance right now?

HILSENRATH: You should refinance when it's right for you. If it's an opportunity now, you should go ahead and do it.

SMITH: All right, Jon Hilsenrath, thank you for keeping it simple. We will be right back.

SMITH: Good morning, everyone. I'm Sandra Smith, Maria Bartiromo is off this morning. It is Tuesday, October 27, and with me this hour fox Business', Dagen McDowell, and the "Wall Street Journal's" Jon Hilsenrath.

MCDOWELL: He said I was cranky this morning.

SMITH: He did?

MCDOWELL: He did. He's like, what's wrong with you? You're cranky. I said, no, I'm just disagreeing with you.

HILSENRATH: She's hating on drones.

MCDOWELL: I disagreed with you, there's a difference.

SMITH: Who said Tuesdays aren't fun? All right, these are your top stories at 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news: a debt deal on Capitol Hill. Congressional leaders and the White House reaching an agreement on a two year budget deal that also extends the debt limit. This marks one of the final acts for House Speaker, John Boehner, who is set to leave office Friday.

Turning to the 2016 race, Donald Trump losing more ground to Ben Carson in Iowa. The latest university poll shows Ben Carson has a double digit lead over Donald Trump, 32 percent to 18 percent. This coming as Trump made another round of controversial comments especially on women wearing a burkas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, 2016 U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE-REPUBLICAN: It is easy. You don't have to put on makeup. Look how beautiful everyone looks. Isn't that easy? I tell you, if I was a woman I would. I am ready, darling. Let's go. It's true.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SMITH: It will be a busy, busy day for earnings and economic data. Walmart taking a page out of Amazon's playbook. The retail giant wants drones to make deliveries at your front door. The company filing for regulatory approval to do so. Walmart also looking to use the devices to check warehouse inventories.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: To the middle. Secured and intercepted by Tony Jefferson.

SMITH: The Baltimore Ravens missing a chance to tie up the game on the final play against the Arizona Cardinals. The Ravens Quarterback Joe Flacco was intercepted in the end zone and Arizona won the game 26 to 18.

It's a big night for baseball. The World Series getting under way tonight in Kansas City. Pitcher Matt Harvey is getting a start for the Mets and he will be going up against Edinson Volquez.

And one retailer is going dark on Black Friday. REI Sporting goods is canceling deals for the day and shutting down stores. Instead, the company wants shoppers to spend that time outside.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Here, here!

SMITH: Turning back to the markets, busy day on earnings and the economy. Alibaba scheduled to report earnings before the bell. Apple and Twitter are said to release results after the bell. We will also get September's Durable Goods orders which are expected to drop 1.2 percent as well as look at the housing market. Case-Shiller home price index will be out. Joining us to break all this down is Vining Sparks' Chief Economist Craig Dismuke. Welcome to you, Craig.

CRAIG DISMUKE, VINING SPARKS CHIEF ECONOMIST: Good morning.

SMITH: Alright, so, what are we looking for this morning? What is hot on your agenda?

DISMUKE: There are important reports, but right now everything is secondary to the inflation data. That is the real big elephant in a room kind of thing. Especially, with Fed policy and what is the Fed going to do. But in the durable-goods report, I expect we will see headline level orders expected to be down because of aircraft. Below that at the core level they're expected to be flat. What is most important will be the Capital goods orders report and specifically not a month over month basis because you get a little of noise on quarter over quarter basis. Orders have been pretty good. They're up 9.75 percent. That is their tracking for the quarter. Pointing for business investment being stronger in the future so that is good news. It's a good sign a business investment is stronger. If you look at the shipment of those items, they're up 2.75 percent quarter over quarter which point to business investment being of 2.75.

SMITH: Well, you obviously looked at these numbers closely. Much closer than any of us. Broadly speaking, where are we as far as economic progress in this recovery? Are we strengthening? And if we are, how slow or fast is it?

DISMUKE: I don't think we are strengthening. And John's point earlier, he mentioned the consumer is so key right now. This has been about the consumer driving economic growth and there have been phases to this recovery/expansion where different parts of the economy are driving activity. Right now, business investment has been weak, so it's down almost 5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year. It was flat in the second quarter of this year.

Business investment has been up and down but overall, it's been weak. It is good news that business investment is a little bit better. That's positive. But at the end of the day, the consumer is what is key and it is an important report but I think it's secondary to what is happening with the consumer and then again with inflation.

JOHN HILSENRATH, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Craig, I need you to settle a friendly disagreement between Dagen and me here about the housing market. We're getting home price data coming up. I say the housing market is strong and getting stronger. And she says it is garbage outside a few metro areas. What is your verdict and what are we going to see in the home price data that come out later today? Did I characterize your point of view?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Yes. And you used the word garbage (inaudible).

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

DISMUKE: It is home prices have been fairly strong, very little inventory. There's construction costs going up. Labor costs going up a little bit in housing. Lumber prices are down. Prices are generally going up. It is very -- the housing data is enigmatic right now. We are getting some weak data. Existing home sales better than expected last month. New home sales down 11.5 percent.

We keep getting this up and down activity. So, I would say in general housing market is trending better. But, there is that challenge and the challenge is if you look at 2013 when mortgage rates rose 90 basis points, housing total sales fell 13 percent. So, that was unusual. To see that drop from a 90 basis point increase. So, you look at what is different in the housing market today than in previous cycles. The biggest difference today is when you look at the number of owner occupied units which are down $2 million in 2005 and rent occupied units which are $10 million since 2006. Which is not good because people who rent cars don't wash them. I have never washed one.

Some people who rent houses or rent multifamily places aren't going to make a capital investment where they are living that we had when we had more of an ownership society so long term as a challenge.

HILSENRATH: We saw in the Glass-Steagall people over invested in those homes and wasted capital in the process. And a lot of other countries you don't have as much emphasis on home ownership. And they have perfectly civil society.

DISMUKE: Sure, but their economic growth is not as strong as we saw when we had more of a homeownership society. When you own something you take more pride in it and you're going to invest in it. And so, I think, in long-term it will be a different housing market. The peak housing was 6.2 percent.

HILSENRATH: Also, demographics at play here.

DISMUKE: That's a big one. The aging population is a demographic issue. It doesn't get enough focus at this point.

MCDOWELL: Like buying homes and selling it though.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: I don't think seniors are going to start trashing their homes. It's a different dynamic.

SMITH: Almost like those houses are maintained to higher standard because they are turned over so often and have to be maintained. That is the discussion for another day. Craig, great stuff. Thank you. Interesting perspective. John, you win.

MCDOWELL: John just leaned in and said I was right

SMITH: Alright. JP Morgan with its own mobile payment platform to rival existing services like Apple Paid. Nicole Petallides has that story this morning. Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: That's right. The country's largest bank is stepping into the ring with the world's most valuable company. JP Morgan is the latest investor in the mobile payments based announcing Chase Pay, a platform that will allow Chase customers to make retail purchases using their smart phone. Creating a direct competitor to Apple Pay. JP Morgan says it has already won the endorsement of a major group of merchants giving it a leg up on the tech savvy rivals. So, the question is are consumers ready to use their phones, smart phones, ditch the credit cards and what happened to cash is king?

SMITH: Anybody use Apple Pay?

MCDOWELL: I have signed up for it but I don't know how to use it in stores.

PETALLIDES: Using your smart phone will be the preferred method of payment. I mean, I just got used to using my debit card in the taxi. Just got out of using cash. This is the wave of the future and there is Apple Pay, Chase Pay credit cards.

(CROSSTALK)

SMITH: A total shift back to cash because everyone is afraid of the paper trail using credit cards and people accessing their data and now, we're going to be even more exposed with all this going on to our smart phones.

HILSENRATH: There isn't going to be. We see where it is going. People moving more towards mobile payments. And cash. I could go weeks without using my cash.

MCDOWELL: Here's why I use a credit card over cash and smart phones. Because I use cash. If I have more than $20, I will drop it and lose it. HILSENRATH: I call it bonus bucks when I discover cash.

MCDOWELL: If I lose it, it usually comes back. I have a tendency to drop it. And with a credit card I keep one credit card in my pocket.

SMITH: You guys must not be good tippers. How can you go through New York City without a few bucks in your pocket? Not that kind.

MCDOWELL: You add the tip. You don't have to worry about signing a form.

HILSENRATH: This is just to bring it back to drones. This is like drones. This is progress when we see new ways of making payments.

MCDOWELL: I fully believe (inaudible)

PETALLIDES: Be honest here. It's unbelievable. This is the wave of the future. Kids staying with babysitters and nannies demand it.

HILSENRATH: So, how is that different from me leaving my newspaper at the airport and someone picking it up and reading it?

HILSENRATH: But you're only sharing a password with one friend.

By John D. McKinnon and Ryan Tracy This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (September 18, 2020). WASHINGTON -- Powerful technology companies are expected to face increased scrutiny no matter who wins the Nov. 3 election, but President Trump and challenger Joe Biden differ on some of the problems posed by Big Tech and how to solve them. In a second term, Mr. Trump and his appointees likely would maintain -- and possibly accelerate -- the broad-scale regulatory scrutiny of technology companies that marked his first term. That effort has included allegations of anticonservative bias online, antitrust investigations of internet giants such as Alphabet Inc.'s Google and Facebook Inc., and actions against Chinese-owned apps such as TikTok and WeChat. Mr. Biden, the Democratic nominee, has also been critical of Big Tech's market power. He and running mate Sen. Kamala Harris (D., Calif.) say they would support stricter antitrust oversight and online privacy rules. But the Biden camp has emphasized forcing social-media companies to better police their sites against false information, and taking government action to help workers under threat from innovations such as self-driving cars. With Congress also focused on Big Tech, both candidates are likely to take a hand in legislative efforts to increase competition in digital markets, expand broadband access and protect consumers' privacy. "The hands-off approach is gone, regardless of who wins the election," said Gene Kimmelman, a former Obama administration antitrust official who recently co-wrote a paper calling for a new agency to regulate large digital platforms. Antitrust The Obama administration -- in which Mr. Biden served as vice president -- developed a tech-friendly reputation, hiring Silicon Valley veterans for key posts and declining to pursue antitrust complaints against Google and others. Some conservative and progressive tech critics alike worry that a Biden administration would take up that stance again, settling any antitrust cases brought by the Trump administration on lenient terms. Biden campaign spokesman Matt Hill declined to comment on the prospect for settling antitrust cases, but suggested Mr. Biden would be tough. "Joe Biden has long said one of the greatest sins is the abuse of power, " Mr. Hill said. "Many technology giants and their executives have not only abused their power, but misled the American people, damaged our democracy, and evaded any form of responsibility. That ends with a President Biden." The Trump campaign says leniency ended with the incumbent's 2016 election. The Justice Department in the Trump administration has been investigating Google for potential anticompetitive conduct in its search and advertising business, and is expected to file a case before the election that likely would carry over into 2021 and beyond. The Federal Trade Commission is also investigating tech companies for potential antitrust violations, including preparing a possible lawsuit against Facebook. During the Democratic primary, Mr. Biden didn't join progressives calling to break up Big Tech firms, saying it would be premature to do so before a formal investigation. This summer, a policy task force Mr. Biden created with Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, his final Democratic primary opponent, recommended breaking up companies for anticompetitive behavior "as a last resort." Nevertheless, Mr. Biden has said that antitrust enforcement hasn't been strong enough and that tech firms deserve a hard look from the federal agencies that oversee competition. Mr. Trump hasn't called for tech breakups either, though that is one possible outcome of the continuing antitrust investigations. Tech's liability shield A particular focus for a second Trump term would be legislation to scale back protections social-media companies enjoy under Section 230 of the 1996 Communications Decency Act, which gives them broad legal immunity for posted content and their efforts to moderate it. Mr. Trump says the law has been used to censor conservative viewpoints. Mr. Trump called for repeal of Section 230 in a Sept. 8 tweet, echoing a position Mr. Biden took earlier this year with a very different motivation. Even so, the law is considered foundational to the internet and has bipartisan support. Mr. Trump ordered regulatory agencies this year to consider tougher oversight of online companies under Section 230 when they don't moderate users' speech fairly or fail to live up to their promises relating to free speech. "It's become evident that Big Tech believes they are the arbiters of truth online -- but they have a clear blind spot when it comes to their bias against conservative voices," said Samantha Zager, a Trump campaign spokeswoman. "President Trump will continue to advocate for an internet that embraces free speech over censorship." As a sign of the issue's importance to the White House, Mr. Trump recently withdrew the renomination of a Republican commissioner of the Federal Communications Commission after he expressed concern about the legal basis for Mr. Trump's tougher line on Section 230. The White House has also pressured the Republican chairman of the FTC, Joseph Simons, to take more action to support the effort, according to people familiar with the matter. Mr. Biden surprised the tech world when he called for revoking Section 230. But unlike conservatives, Mr. Biden says some social-media platforms do too little policing, not too much. His campaign website devoted an entire page to criticizing Facebook and its relatively hands-off policy when it comes to policing political speech. Some critics say that policy benefits Mr. Trump. Mr. Biden has termed the company irresponsible. Mr. Biden hasn't outlined what new policy might replace Section 230, but he appears to want social-media companies to be more active, not less, in taking down content -- especially what the Biden campaign views as false information promoted by pro-Trump groups. Facebook says it is important to allow voters to see the statements of political candidates. Mr. Trump and other Republicans have their own frustrations with Facebook, which has removed some Trump campaign ads and some of the president's statements about the coronavirus. But they have also at times praised the company's decisions, such as when it declined to join rivals such as Twitter Inc. in labeling and shielding from public view a post from Mr. Trump about violent protests. Job protections Mr. Biden has expressed concerns about the potential impacts of many tech innovations, such as self-driving vehicles, on people with middle-class jobs. "Whether your predictions are true about automation and self-driving trucks, these folks aren't stupid," he said in a speech in 2018 at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "They listen, they understand and they're scared to death." Among Mr. Biden's proposed solutions are such ideas as providing extra government aid to help workers who have been dislocated by tech. The former vice president has also been outspoken about using government regulation to force "gig economy" businesses to pay benefits to their independent contractors, by reclassifying them as employees. California adopted such a law last year and debate continues about its efficacy. Ride-hailing companies have said their drivers aren't covered, while state legislators modified the law in response to job losses in other industries. In a New York Times interview early this year, Mr. Biden described meeting as vice president with tech leaders -- "little creeps," he called them -- touting their industry's economic benefit. "'You have fewer people on your payroll than all the losses that General Motors just faced in the last quarter, of employees. So don't lecture me about how you've created all this employment,'" Mr. Biden said he responded. The Trump campaign said policies like California's gig-worker law "take away workers' opportunity to make their own schedules and participate in a free and open gig economy." The Labor Department, which is led by a Trump appointee, last year said people offering services on online sites or apps should be considered employees of the consumer who hires them, not the virtual marketplace. That policy could make it harder for gig workers to win labor disputes. The Trump administration has also sought to expand the availability of worker training through apprenticeships, in part by making it easier for businesses to run their own apprentice programs. Continue reading Both parties are mad about a proposal for federal anti-bias certification

Yesterday, Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) unveiled legislation called Ending Support for Internet Censorship Act, which would shake up the legal foundation of the internet in an effort to root out online bias. Under the proposed law, companies like Facebook and Twitter would be required to obtain a government certification that they are not making politically biased decisions about content moderation, in exchange for liability protections they currently receive automatically.

Hawley's bill would amend Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which gives companies legal protection from what users post on platforms. That provision is often seen as a fundamental part of the internet, and has been described as the law that allowed social media as we know it to flourish. The law has taken a beating lately, however, as some lawmakers, like Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX), call for overhauling 230. Democrats like Nancy Pelosi have also questioned the law, with the House speaker recently saying it's in jeopardy.

But if Hawley hoped to tap into some of that discontent with his bill, it hasn't happened. Lawmakers in both parties, as well as liberal and conservative groups more broadly, largely slammed the idea, calling it a dystopian plan to regulate speech online and an unworkable act of government overreach. Here's a rundown of the responses from the past day:

The senator who wrote 230

Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR) was one of the original authors of Section 230, and defended the law against Hawley's plan. In a statement, the senator said the plan will turn the federal government into Speech Police, flagrantly violating the First Amendment, and would force every platform to become 4chan or 8chan rather than maintain some basic level of decency. He went on to say that Trump's Republican party seems to believe that lawyers and bureaucrats should tell private companies how to make clearly private business decisions.

Ron Wyden

@RonWyden

.@HawleyMO s bill to require government oversight of online speech will turn the federal government into Speech Police, flagrantly violating the First Amendment. This bill would force every platform to become 4chan or 8chan rather than maintain some basic level of decency.

Even some sitting Republican lawmakers questioned the idea. Rep. Justin Amash (R-MI) responded to Hawley's plan on Twitter. This legislation is a sweetheart deal for Big Government, he wrote. It empowers the one entity that should have no say over our speech to regulate and influence what we say online.

Justin Amash

@justinamash

This legislation is a sweetheart deal for Big Government. It empowers the one entity that should have no say over our speech to regulate and influence what we say online. https://twitter.com/hawleymo/status/1141338106550980609 ...

Josh Hawley

@HawleyMO

Today I've introduced legislation to end Big Tech's biggest sweetheart deal from government. No more government protection for Big Tech's political censorship https://fxn.ws/2WLsY89

3,043

6:10 AM Jun 20, 2019Twitter Ads info and privacy912 people are talking about thisA former Republican FTC commissioner

The bill would require members of the Federal Trade Commission to certify that platforms are politically neutral, but not everyone who's worked at the commission was on board with the idea. Joshua Wright, a former Republican commissioner who left the agency in 2015, said in a series of tweets that the bill quite literally injects a board of bureaucrats into millions of decisions about internet content. He called the idea central planning.

But the truth is that there is a ton of consumer surplus here arising from voluntary exchange in social media platforms, Wright wrote. I'm old enough to remember conservatives being into that kind of thing.

Joshua Wright

@ProfWrightGMU

· Jun 19, 2019Replying to @ProfWrightGMU

Both approaches are remarkably short sighted in my view. The antitrust break up approach requires both undermining markets, consumer sovereignty, and the rule of law to achieve some political end.

Joshua Wright

@ProfWrightGMU

The Hawley Bill similarly offers the choice of death by bureaucratic board or the plaintiffs' bar. Yes, this will impose big costs on social media. That might feel good to some conservatives politicians. But the hangover will be the cost it imposes on everyday internet users.End.

10:30 PM Jun 19, 2019Twitter Ads info and privacy57 people are talking about thisThe troll right

The social media platform Gab, which has styled itself as a radically laissez-fairealternative to platforms like Facebook and Twitter and has earned a following from racists in the process asked Hawley on Twitter whether the plan would cement Big Tech monopoly status. After Hawley responded that smaller companies would be exempted, Gab said it supported the idea. These are very fair benchmarks and won't hinder competing startups like Gab, the company wrote. You have our support Senator, would love to chat more about how we can help.

Gab.com

@getongab

· Jun 19, 2019Replying to @getongab @HawleyMO

We both want the same thing: to preserve and defend the fundamental human right to free expression online, for Americans and in our case the entire internet. It would be great to connect with your office and chat more about these issues. Appreciate the work you are doing.

Gab.com

@getongab

Here is the proposal in full for those interested: https://www.hawley.senate.gov/sites/default/files/2019-06/Ending-Support-Internet-Censorship-Act-Bill-Text.pdf ...

These are very fair benchmarks and won't hinder competing startups like Gab.

You have our support Senator, would love to chat more about how we can help.

89

9:31 PM Jun 19, 2019Twitter Ads info and privacy35 people are talking about thisConservative media

In an op-ed posted by the right-leaning Washington Examiner, Philip Klein argued that the legislation would result in less freedom of speech, not more, and would not remedy the alleged problems it's trying to fix. I get that conservatives are frustrated about bias shown in decisions to ban or suspend users, Klein writes, but this response would only lead to a more restrictive speech code.

Tech think tanks

The nonprofit Open Technology Institute, part of the left-leaning think tank New America, said there are reasonable concerns about tech industry moderation practices, but that Hawley's bill wasn't the way to handle them. The group said the concept of a politically neutral' platform is a broad, undefined one that creates an artificial, unmeasurable standard for platforms to meet.

Industry groups

While tech companies have largely stayed silent on the proposal, industry trade groups came out in force against the plan. The Internet Association, which represents major platform companies like Facebook and Google, said in a statement that the bill forces platforms to make an impossible choice: either host reprehensible, but First Amendment protected speech, or lose legal protections that allow them to moderate illegal content like human trafficking and violent extremism.

NetChoice, an e-commerce association that also includes major tech companies like Facebook, Google, and Amazon, said the bill would turn the internet into a hub of extremism, and embolden extreme political movements, such as the KKK. The Computer & Communications Industry Association called the plan ludicrous, comparing it to 1984.

Conservative groups

Right-leaning groups also slammed the legislation. The libertarian group TechFreedom said the bill would give politicians a gigantic regulatory hammer to use against Big Tech, and giving the FTC certification power would set up a partisan bloodmatch every other year.

The Koch brothers-funded political advocacy group Americans for Prosperity was also critical of the plan, calling it misguided and saying it potentially creates a scenario where government has the ability to police your speech and determine what you can or cannot say online.

The Media Research Center, a conservative group set up to combat a perceived liberal bias in the media, was one of the few right-leaning organizations that threw support behind the plan, saying it was the first major step toward holding tech giants like Facebook, Google and Twitter accountable.

urn:contentItem:5VND-37S1-JCB8-W1XY-00000-00Both parties would regret breaking up Big Tech2019-03-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexisCopinion/commentaryPg. 3Both parties would regret breaking up Big TechRICH LOWRY ;

The worst ideas in Washington are often bipartisan. Big Tech is about to learn this lesson, if it hasn't already.

The worst ideas in Washington are often bipartisan. Big Tech is about to learn this lesson, if it hasn't already.

Elizabeth Warren is out with a headline-grabbing proposal to break up Big Tech companies, the sort of overly ambitious government plan that once would have engendered knee-jerk Republican opposition. Not anymore. Who says we all can't get along?

When the senator tweeted her (understandable) objection that Facebook had taken down her ads attacking Facebook and other tech companies, Ted Cruz agreed that the companies have too much power.

Tech is caught in a right-left pincer. Conservatives don't like these companies because they are owned and operated by sanctimonious Silicon Valley liberals subject to the worst sort of groupthink. Progressives don't like them because they are colossal profit-making enterprises.

That's why there is some chance Washington might get together and, along the lines Warren proposes, effectively outlaw the business models of some of the most successful and iconic American companies.

Warren's idea to cleave off the platforms of the tech companies and have them run as "platform utilities" separate from the rest of their business is unworkable and is justified by a series of errors and misjudgments.

It's not true, as Warren asserts, that the antitrust suit against Microsoft in the 1990s opened up the space for Google and Facebook to thrive. Microsoft never got the internet and left the space open for Google and Facebook all by itself, as often happens with a large incumbent wedded to its business model.

She charges that tech companies use mergers to limit competition and cites Facebook's acquisition of WhatsApp. It's hard to discern the harm here. When the social network bought it, WhatsApp was available for a fee. Now it's free, and more people use it than ever. What's the problem?

She calls out Google for allegedly killing off its competitors by burying them in its searches. It's not obvious that Google actually does this, although its search business inherently involves constantly making choices to try to best serve what people want to see. No government regulator is going to improve Google's searches, or is qualified to even try.

Warren's proposal is obviously formulated without taking any account of the interests of consumers, who are the ones who made the tech companies so large.

Why does Google provide for free a tool without which it's impossible to imagine contemporary life? Because it can monetize it with advertising. Without the advertising, which Warren insists should be a separate business, Google has no incentive to devote engineers to improving its search engine.

By the same token, no one will welcome iPhones that no longer come with or sell Apple apps. And would people really appreciate having to go to two different Amazons, one just a platform, one selling Amazon products?

This is all silly, as are the mergers that Warren pledges to reverse, including Amazon's acquisition of Whole Foods. Amazon doesn't have anything close to a monopoly in food retail. Rather than taking over the sector, it's spurring investment and innovation. The nation's largest supermarket chain, Kroger, was slated to increase its spending on investment 200 percent in 2018.

The tech giants aren't stand-pat companies. Amazon alone spent more than $22 billion on investment in 2017. The development of autonomous vehicles, artificial intelligence and voice recognition wouldn't be nearly as advanced if it weren't for the research of the tech companies. The behemoth of yesteryear, General Electric, isn't making these investments.

None of this is to deny genuine concerns about tech companies. They need rules for content that honor the spirit of the First Amendment, and perhaps there should be tighter regulations around privacy. But any real offenses should be addressed with fixes directed at specific conduct, rather than with a massive politically imposed reorganization.

That's a very bad idea, and if you had any doubt, watch it get a respectful hearing from both sides in Washington.

Rich Lowry is editor of National Review.

Many of Amazon's Seattle-area employees will likely be exempt from new proposed labor protections after a push by the tech giant's lobbyists to raise the salary threshold at which the rules would kick in. (AP Photo/Elaine Thompson, File)

urn:contentItem:5SV3-BJF1-JDJN-6195-00000-00Bots of the internet, reveal yourselves!2018-07-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexisBots of the internet, reveal yourselves!New York Times News Service

Currently, bots are easy to make and widely employed, and social media companies are under no legal obligation to get rid of them

New York Times News Service

Robert M. Hertzberg's hatred of bots is personal.

Hertzberg is a state Senator from California and last year, after he introduced a bail reform bill, he noticed that automated accounts on Twitter and Facebook were attacking him and his position. He is currently seeking re-election and one of his opponents in the Democratic primary was a bail agent.

"The bail agents against me had hundreds of bots working in order to create the false impression that there were people against me," Hertzberg said in a recent interview.

For example, he said, one account rapidly responded to tweets about the bill in real time with the message: "Unconstitutional bail reform doesn't work and is racist."

So Hertzberg introduced another bill this year, the first of its kind in the United States, that would compel automated social media accounts to identify themselves as bots — in other words, to disclose their nonpersonhood.

Because bots are only effective if they seem convincingly human. Right?

Depending on how you define them, bots have been around since before most of us were using the internet. Their presence online was considered fairly benevolent, if considered at all, until 2016, when they were among the host of factors used to explain away the election of President Donald Trump.

Pranks

Since then, bots have become, for many people, a digital bogeyman, a viral weapon that can be wielded to influence political opinions, fool advertisers, prank unknowing social media users and get bad hashtags to trend. (They are also the lifeblood of many users we call influencers.)

Last week, Twitter announced it would remove tens of millions of suspicious accounts to crack down on the bots that can be bought (through third parties) by users who want to inflate the number of their followers. The company also said last month that it has been "locking" almost 10 million suspicious accounts per week and removing others for violating anti-spam policies.

Still, bots are easy to make and widely employed, and social media companies are under no legal obligation to get rid of them. A law that discourages their use could help, but experts aren't sure how the one Hertzberg is trying to push through, in California, might work.

For starters, would bots be forced to identify themselves in every Facebook post? In their Instagram bios? In their Twitter handles?

The measure, SB-1001, a version of which has already left the Senate floor and is working its way through the state's Assembly, also doesn't mandate that tech companies enforce the regulation. And it's unclear how a bill that is specific only to California would apply to a global internet.

Altering reality

Oren Etzioni, chief executive of the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence, applauded the spirit of the law but was not as sold on its letter. "This is groundbreaking legislation," he said. "We are on a trajectory where reality, the very fabric of the information we see, can be altered in an unprecedented fashion. When that's done, as the law says, with an intent to mislead, that's a huge problem."

But "you don't want to measure twice, regulate once," he said. "You don't want to put the wrong laws on the books and have unintended consequences."

Jeremy Gillula, a technologist at the Electronic Frontier Foundation who has been critical of the bill since its inception, said the first version was "a little like trying to treat the flu using chemotherapy."

"Not only will it not fix the thing you're trying to fix," he said earlier this month. "It'll cause a lot of collateral damage at the same time."

The bill was drafted by Common Sense Media, a non-profit that provides consumer ratings about the age-appropriateness of movies and TV shows, in collaboration with the Center for Humane Technology, a group of former employees of big tech companies including Google and Facebook who have banded together to regulate their former employers.

Neither Hertzberg nor Jim Steyer, chief executive of Common Sense Media, was overly concerned with criticism when interviewed about the bill in June. The senator called scepticism "the drivel of people who want to stop progress." He said that the analysis he had seen had been influenced by lobbyists and was flat out wrong.

But after they were interviewed and the bill moved through the Assembly's committees, the content of the proposed law changed substantially. The definition of bot grew more precise (from "online account" to "automated online account on an online platformem>"), /em>and language that recommended an online platform for reporting bots was scrapped. Furthermore, the bill now asks only bots that are hoping to sell consumers good and services, or to influence votes in an election, to identify themselves as bots.

But even with the changes, the bill summons significant constitutional questions, said Ryan Calo, a co-director of the Tech Policy Lab at the University of Washington, and Madeline Lamo, a former fellow at the lab.

Lamo said that language in the bill about bots "influencing a vote in an election" ran into a problem that has plagued campaign finance regulations and election-related speech laws: It can be difficult to distinguish speech about political issues from speech explicitly intended to influence voters.

Furthermore, she noted, the bill was simply not crafted to address the problem it had in mind. Insofar as bots have had sway over political views, they have acted at scale, with thousands of automated accounts working to spread a diverse array of messages. It's hard to imagine, she said, that requiring individual accounts to identify themselves in a single state would do much to sap the strength of bot armies.

Lawmakers understanding of technology

All parties agree that the bill illustrates the difficulty that lawmakers have in crafting legislation that effectively addresses the problems constituents confront online. As the pace of technological development has raced ahead of government, the laws that exist on the books — not to mention some lawmakers' understandings of technology — have remained comparatively stagnant. And, as Twitter's action last week demonstrates, technology companies have the power to change dynamics on their platforms directly and at the scale that those problems require. Turning a bill into a law can take a long time. And then the law runs the risk of being inexact.

Calo cited as an example a driverless car law passed by Nevada in 2012, which met with protest from luxury carmakers. They were miffed that the technologies in their cars fell under the loosely drawn definition of autonomous vehicles. The bill was revised and passed the following year.

"Embarrassingly it was the first definition of artificial intelligence I've ever seen in a state statute, and they had to strike it out and rewrite it," Calo said.

With the bot bill, he said, similar issues could crop up.

"Political commentary comes in different forms," he said. "Imagine a concerned citizen sets up a bot to criticise a particular official for failing to act on climate change. Now say that official runs for re-election. Is the concerned citizen now in violation of California law?"

Meanwhile, Gillula said that the bill sought to address a problem that may have been somewhat overhyped.

"I haven't seen anyone say conclusively that Russian bots swung the election," he said, noting that he was not an expert on US political discourse. "Given that people are concerned but there is no conclusive smoking gun proof of concrete harm, I really hesitate to jump to 'let's get something because its such an emergency.'"

But Hertzberg, who also has bills in the works addressing blockchain technology and cannabis banking, is undeterred. He said that his bot bill could have a big impact if passed in California, where so many tech companies are based.

"The political industrial complex is designed to protect the status quo, not to invent the future," he said. "Inventing the future means you have to think differently, be more inventive, be more creative."

The measure, SB-1001, which has already passed the Senate and is working its way through the state’s Assembly, also doesn’t mandate that tech companies enforce the regulation. And it’s unclear how a bill that is specific only to California would apply to a global internet.

Oren Etzioni, the chief executive of the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence, applauded the spirit of the law but was not as sold on its letter. “This is groundbreaking legislation,” he said. “We are on a trajectory where reality, the very fabric of the information we see, can be altered in an unprecedented fashion. When that’s done, as the law says, with an intent to mislead, that’s a huge problem.”

But “you don’t want to measure twice, regulate once,” he said. “You don’t want to put the wrong laws on the books and have unintended consequences.”

Jeremy Gillula, a technologist at the Electronic Frontier Foundation who has been critical of the bill since its inception, said the first version was “a little like trying to treat the flu using chemotherapy.”

“Not only will it not fix the thing you’re trying to fix,” he said earlier this month. “It’ll cause a lot of collateral damage at the same time.”

The bill was drafted by Common Sense Media, a nonprofit that provides consumer ratings about the age-appropriateness of movies and TV shows, in collaboration with the Center for Humane Technology, a group of former employees of big tech companies including Google and Facebook who have banded together to regulate their former employers.

Neither Senator Hertzberg nor Jim Steyer, the chief executive of Common Sense Media, was overly concerned with criticism when interviewed about the bill in June. The senator called skepticism “the drivel of people who want to stop progress.” He said that the analysis he had seen had been influenced by lobbyists and was flat out wrong.

But after they were interviewed and the bill moved through the Assembly’s committees, the content of the proposed law changed substantially. The definition of bot grew more precise (from “online account” to “automated online account on an online platform”), and language that recommended an online platform for reporting bots was scrapped. Furthermore, the bill now asks only bots that are hoping to sell consumers good and services, or to influence votes in an election, to identify themselves as bots.

But even with the changes, the bill summons significant constitutional questions, said Ryan Calo, a co-director of the Tech Policy Lab at the University of Washington, and Madeline Lamo, a former fellow at the lab.

Ms. Lamo said that language in the bill about bots “influencing a vote in an election” ran into a problem that has plagued campaign finance regulations and election-related speech laws: It can be difficult to distinguish speech about political issues from speech explicitly intended to influence voters.

Furthermore, she noted, the bill was simply not crafted to address the problem it had in mind. Insofar as bots have had sway over political views, they have acted at scale, with thousands of automated accounts working to spread a diverse array of messages. It’s hard to imagine, she said, that requiring individual accounts to identify themselves in a single state would do much to sap the strength of bot armies.

All parties agree that the bill illustrates the difficulty that lawmakers have in crafting legislation that effectively addresses the problems constituents confront online. As the pace of technological development has raced ahead of government, the laws that exist on the books — not to mention, some lawmakers’ understandings of technology — have remained comparatively stagnant. And, as Twitter’s action last week demonstrates, technology companies have the power to change dynamics on their platforms directly, and at the scale that those problems require. Turning a bill into a law can take a long time. And then the law runs the risk of being inexact.

Mr. Calo cited as an example a driverless car law passed by Nevada in 2012, which met with protest from luxury carmakers. They were miffed that the technologies in their cars fell under the loosely drawn definition of autonomous vehicles. The bill was revised and passed the following year.

“Embarrassingly it was the first definition of artificial intelligence I’ve ever seen in a state statute, and they had to strike it out and rewrite it,” Mr. Calo said.

With the bot bill, he said, similar issues could crop up.

“Political commentary comes in different forms,” he said. “Imagine a concerned citizen sets up a bot to criticize a particular official for failing to act on climate change. Now say that official runs for re-election. Is the concerned citizen now in violation of California law?”

Meanwhile, Mr. Gillula said that the bill sought to address a problem that may have been somewhat overhyped.

“I haven’t seen anyone say conclusively that Russian bots swung the election,” he said, noting that he was not an expert on American political discourse. “Given that people are concerned but there is no conclusive smoking gun proof of concrete harm, I really hesitate to jump to ‘let’s get something because its such an emergency.’”

But Senator Hertzberg, who also has bills in the works addressing blockchain technology and cannabis banking, is undeterred. He said that his bot bill could have a big impact if passed in California, where so many tech companies are based.

“The political industrial complex is designed to protect the status quo, not to invent the future,” he said. “Inventing the future means you have to think differently, be more inventive, be more creative.”

A bill in the California legislature would regulate bots by making them disclose their automated nature. But how?

FULL TEXT

Robert M. Hertzberg's hatred of bots is personal.

Mr. Hertzberg is a state Senator from California and last year, after he introduced a bail reform bill, he noticed that automated accounts on Twitter and Facebook were attacking him and his position. He is currently seeking re-election, and one of his opponents in the Democratic primary was a bail agent.

"The bail agents against me had hundreds of bots working in order to create the false impression that there were people against me," Mr. Hertzberg said in a recent interview.

For example, he said, one account rapidly responded to tweets about the bill in real time with the message: "Unconstitutional bail reform doesn't work and is racist."

So Mr. Hertzberg introduced another bill this year, the first of its kind in the United States, that would compel automated social media accounts to identify themselves as bots - in other words, to disclose their non-personhood.

Because bots are only effective if they seem convincingly human. Right?

Depending on how you define them, bots have been around since before most of us were using the internet. Their presence online was considered fairly benevolent, if considered at all, until 2016, when they were among the host of factors used to explain away the election of President Trump.

Since then, bots have become, for many people, a digital boogeyman, a viral weapon that can be wielded to influence political opinions, fool advertisers, prank unknowing social media users and get bad hashtags to trend. (They're also the lifeblood of many users we call influencers.)

Last week, Twitter announced it would remove tens of millions of suspicious accounts to crack down on the bots that can be bought (through third parties) by users who want to inflate the number of their followers. The company also said last month that it has been "locking" almost 10 million suspicious accounts per week and removing others for violating anti-spam policies.

Still, bots are easy to make and widely employed, and social media companies are under no legal obligation to get rid of them. A law that discourages their use could help, but experts aren't sure how the one Senator Hertzberg is trying to push through, in California, might work.

For starters, would bots be forced to identify themselves in every Facebook post? In their Instagram bios? In their Twitter handles?

When that's done, as the law says, with an intent to mislead, that's a huge problem."

But "you don't want to measure twice, regulate once," he said. "You don't want to put the wrong laws on the books and have unintended consequences."

Jeremy Gillula, a technologist at the Electronic Frontier Foundation who has been critical of the bill since its inception, said the first version was "a little like trying to treat the flu using chemotherapy."

Neither Senator Hertzberg nor Jim Steyer, the chief executive of Common Sense Media, was overly concerned with criticism when interviewed about the bill in June. The senator called skepticism "the drivel of people who want to stop progress." He said that the analysis he had seen had been influenced by lobbyists and was flat out wrong.

But after they were interviewed and the bill moved through the Assembly's committees, the content of the proposed law changed substantially. The definition of bot grew more precise (from "online account" to "automated online account on an online platform"), and language that recommended an online platform for reporting bots was scrapped. Furthermore, the bill now asks only bots that are hoping to sell consumers good and services, or to influence votes in an election, to identify themselves as bots.

But even with the changes, the bill summons significant constitutional questions, said Ryan Calo, a co-director of the Tech Policy Lab at the University of Washington, and Madeline Lamo, a former fellow at the lab.

Ms. Lamo said that language in the bill about bots "influencing a vote in an election" ran into a problem that has plagued campaign finance regulations and election-related speech laws: It can be difficult to distinguish speech about political issues from speech explicitly intended to influence voters.

Furthermore, she noted, the bill was simply not crafted to address the problem it had in mind. Insofar as bots have had sway over political views, they have acted at scale, with thousands of automated accounts working to spread a diverse array of messages. It's hard to imagine, she said, that requiring individual accounts to identify themselves in a single state would do much to sap the strength of bot armies.

As the pace of technological development has raced ahead of government, the laws that exist on the books - not to mention, some lawmakers' understandings of technology - have remained comparatively stagnant. With the bot bill, he said, similar issues could crop up.

"Political commentary comes in different forms," he said. "Imagine a concerned citizen sets up a bot to criticize a particular official for failing to act on climate change. Now say that official runs for re-election. Is the concerned citizen now in violation of California law?"

urn:contentItem:5XSS-XTJ1-F03R-N166-00000-00Box CEO Aaron Levie says consensus is building around Big Tech privacy2019-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexisBox CEO Aaron Levie says consensus is building around Big Tech privacyIna Fried

Dec 20, 2019( Axios: https://link.axios.com/join/am-signup?source=aci Delivered by Newstex) Even as politicians in D.C. struggle to come up with national privacy legislation, Box CEO Aaron Levie says there is a growing consensus on what should be expected of companies.Why it matters: As large companies adopt policies to comply with EU and California laws, federal legislation becomes more a formality and less of a battleground. "We're stumbling our way there," Levie told Axios on Thursday in an interview at the company's San Francisco office.

The big picture: Specifically, he said, there is growing convergence around several key points. Customers should know how their data is being accessed.They should have some degree of a right to revoke access.There should be limits to how third parties can access that data.Companies should probably be required to provide some level of auditing or reporting to the federal government. What he's saying: "It's a very blurry image but you can start to see the contours of what a global privacy set of laws might look like." "We're probably 5 years out from this being anything that gets standardized. But I think it is not unrealistic that things could start to converge more on this stuff." Meanwhile, Levie expects big companies to largely adopt the California rules[1] that go into effect in January, just as most companies adopted the EU's GDPR requirements globally. Google, for example, committed Thursday[2] to doing just that. "It's just how you will build your systems," he said. The bottom line: Increased regulation is good for Box's business. "The more complex the world gets from a data privacy standpoint," Levie said, "the more companies want partners that can abstract that."Go deeper: The global shortage of privacy professionals[3] [ 1]: https://www.axios.com/california-privacy-law-national-impact-8e86bffe-af22-4966-92ff-f44e12aae9d6.html [ 2]: https://blog.google/technology/safety-security/putting-you-in-control-privacy-2019 [ 3]:   https://www.axios.com/privacy-expert-shortage-202eda9b-c8fa-4bd4-b1c1-11844812ab3e.html
