urn:contentItem:5J1D-BWN1-JBPF-90JN-00000-00Boxed In;MVPDs sound off - and FCC pushes back - on game-changing new set-top proposal2016-02-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexisPg. 6Boxed InMVPDs sound off - and FCC pushes back - on game-changing new set-top proposalcoverstory

WASHINGTON - "Box" is probably the wrong fighting term to use about the current set-top fracas involving the Federal Communications Commission, multichannel video programming distributors (MVPDs) and Silicon Valley. It's more like a bare-knuckles cage match over the future of access to video.

On one side are the MVPDs, who argue the marketplace is already opening up access to video programming without the FCC forcing providers to disaggregate their programming for reassembly by others.

The FCC - pressed by Silicon Valley giant Google, TV-maker Vizio, digital video recorder maker TiVo and others - stands on the other side, saying it's time to break the MVPDs' leased lockbox on programming and prices.

What's at stake is nothing less than the future of television and how its viewers will consume it - and who can access the reams of valuable data MVPDs now use to sell to advertisers. The question of who can access that information also poses huge privacy and security issues for TV watchers.

In December, the Consumer Choice Video Coalition (CVCC) - backed by Silicon Valley giants including Google, TiVo, Vizio, Public Knowledge, the Writers Guild of America, competitive telecom carrier trade group INCOMPAS (formerly COMPTEL) and others - demonstrated a new set-top box for FCC staff ers, hoping to convince the agency to crack open leased cable boxes for competing over-the-top providers. Of the 21 coalition members present, one-third were from Google.

Fast-forward to two weeks ago, and Google- which just topped Apple as the world's most valuable company, at half a trillion dollars in valuation - hosted a similar demonstration of the coalition's "competitive Navigation device solution" for Capitol Hill staffers. The proposal's mere existence is a game-changer for third-party devices, and a potential huge victory at the FCC that cable operators and studios say would hurt their businesses, as well as consumers.

The FCC has proposed to require cable operators to make their programming available to third parties in a way that cable operators say would force them to re-engineer their networks and strip away copyright and consumer protections.

Googleand others in the coalition said the proposal creates a "virtual headend" so that an MVPD's signal can be viewed along with over-the-top offerings on a competitive device. That device could be a box, phone, tablet, smart TV, dongle or even a leased cable box.

The idea is that the device allows access not only to the MVPDs' programming, but to content from the Internet, including Netfl ix, Amazon Instant Video and YouTube.

More worrisome for cable operators, it could allow these third parties access to the most precious of all screen space: the fi rst thing viewers see when they turn on the TV. Might it be an ad from Google?

Cable operators, movie studios and others have formed the Future of Television Coalition to fi ght the proposal. It's not that they don't want their content side by side with OTT, they said (and that's already happening in the marketplace without FCC intervention). Rather, they see the FCC's move as an unnecessary thumb on the scale for the Googles and TiVos of the world.

"It disaggregates the provider of the service from their customer, which no business is really going to like," one coalition source said. "And it gives third parties a way to come in and get revenue out of the ecosystem that devalues the content."

Coalition co-chairman Alfred Liggins, the president and CEO of cable network TV One, said, "The 'AllVid' proposal is a brazen money grab by Big Tech companies that would do severe damage to the programming ecosystem, and in particular, niche and minority-focused networks."

Cable operators argue that the proposal is essentially a revival of the AllVid proposal the FCC off ered up in 2010. Wheeler and FCC officials, though, say the new plan is far from that.

Wheeler has pushed the plan with tough talk about the skyrocketing price of set-tops and the lack of competition. He went so far as to use a Public Knowledge/Consumer Federation of America chart at a press conference to illustrate why it's necessary to "unlock" the box for edge providers and consumer groups. (Gigi Sohn, a top adviser to Wheeler, is the co-founder of Public Knowledge.)


The goal of the rule-making is to open up MVPD platforms to retail devices such as TiVo's Roamio DVR (pictured).


FCC chairman Tom Wheeler used a chart from Public Knowledge and the CFA to make a case for "unlocking" the set-top at a press conference.

At press time, cable operators and other members of the Future of Television Coalition hadn't seen Wheeler's notice of proposed rulemaking, so all they had to go on in formulating reasons why the FCC was on the wrong track were the painful (for them) memories of AllVid and the CVCC proposal.

Multichannel News talked to senior FCC officials who have seen the NPRM to get their responses to the cable operators' key concerns - and they have a ton of them.

So, in one corner, from an NCTA filing with guidance from Future of TV Coalition sources, are the perceived blows the chairman's proposal would inflict on a video-access marketplace if it unfolds along the lines of the proposal put forth by Googleet al. In the other, top FCC officials, speaking not for attribution, weigh in with their responses.

"Would this turn the "opening screen" - what viewers see when they turn on their TV sets - over to a third party?

MVPDs: The first screen could be "Welcome to Google" only, with ads down the side. How would a Cox Communications or Comcast subscriber get directly to their channel lineups (on the same channels) on that opening screen as well?

FCC: "While we cannot predict the design or interface that device makers and software developers may come up with, they will be required to pass through all of the content the consumer is entitled to receive. The Notice of Proposed Rulemaking asks how that should be defi ned," an FCC source told Multichannel News. "This proposal is intended to introduce competition in devices and apps available to consumers. If a consumer does not like the interface or user experience available on one off ering, they could look for an alternative off ered by a competitor." In other words, what that opening screen will show is yet to be determined.

"What happens to programming agreements?

MVPDs: Retail devices would have access to parts of the MVPD service from which they could create their own service off erings, without responsibility or compensation to programmers or MVPDs.

FCC: "The CableCard works the same way," an FCC source said. "It gives an independent vendor such as a TiVo access to the MVPDs' programming and guide information. And none of these things have happened.

"And on the compensation issue: If you think about this logically, if I'm a Comcast subscriber, I'm paying Comcast whether I'm using their box or whether I use a TiVo box," the agency source added. "Comcast is then passing that money on to the programmers, based on the fact that I count as one of their eyeballs. They are also able to sell advertising based on the fact that I count as one of their eyeballs. Nothing that our proposal would do would change any of that. They keep their subs; they keep their subs's money. We're just saying you should be able to get a box or view it with an app on any device you want without disrupting any agreement between the programmer and the MVPD."

Under the CableCard regime, third parties are not required to display the guide in the same manner as MVPDs, but they are required to pass through a channel lineup, and that won't change, the official said. "Any package that the consumer has paid for shall be passed through in full and displayed in full by the third party," the FCC source said.

In addition to those channels being available in order, they can also be searched by category in a similar way as can be searched today. "If an MVPD can do that today and be in compliance with a third-party programming agreement, why wouldn't a third party be able to do that?"

"Would this proposal infringe on copyrights?

MVPDs: Device manufacturers would be allowed to infringe on programmers' copyrights by displaying and copying protected works through manufacturers' own services without permission or compensation.

FCC: "Nothing we are doing undoes any copyright protections that exist today.

"As part of our proposal, we would require that the copy-protection information be transmitted from the MVPD to the device or app, and that the device or app must honor that copy protection mandate from the programmer." If the device doesn't honor copy-protection rules, programmers would have the same redress as they do under copyright, the official pointed out, though that is not the FCC's purview.

"Would consumers lose modern features off ered by the box, like Time Warner Cable's "Start Over?"

MVPDs: Consumers would be denied access to many modern MVPD service features like voice search, starting a show in progress at the beginning and other interactive enhancements, which MVPDs rely on to ensure the quality of their user experience and to provide value to their customers and stay competitive.

FCC: If viewers want such enhancements, they can keep them. "We're not telling anyone they have to give up their cable box. All we are saying is that, as a consumer, if you want to buy somebody else's box, you should be able to. And who's to say that new box won't have those features or a diff erent feature that consumers want?"

"Wouldn't the proposal require some sort of in-home adapter, not to mention added costs for consumers?

MVPDs: MVPDs must provide customers with a government-designed in-home, leased device in order to receive MVPD service on a retail device, raising equipment and energy costs for consumers.

FCC: Officials said that sounded like AllVid, which they said was not the chairman's proposal. "We are not designing a device. In fact, we are not even mandating a device. We are very pro-app, and software and competitive devices [in] whatever format these innovators want to develop in. We are just trying to encourage that. AllVid was two boxes. We were telling people we are going to design a box and you have to have two boxes to get your cable programming. But that's not what we are doing here.

"In fact, we would love it if our proposal resulted in no boxes. The way of the future is not the box. Wouldn't it be great if you could just hook up your MVPD service to your Smart TV and you could see everything?"

"Would this complicate issues like privacy, and perhaps thwart emergency alerts? MVPDs: Device manufacturers are not obligated to abide by Title VI consumer protection regulations such as, among others, privacy protections and emergency alert requirements.

FCC: "Our proposal specifi cally seeks comment on maintaining emergency alerting. The safety of the public is very important to the commission. Nothing that we do in our proposal to create a competitive marketplace will undermine emergency alerting."

As to consumer-protection regulations, the official said that MVPDs do have different obligations under the Cable Act than device manufacturers. "Title VI applies to MVPDs only." But the official said that those device manufacturers are already subject to some pretty strict privacy laws and regulations of their own, enforced by the Federal Trade Commission - citing a "ton" of consent decrees against app and device manufacturers and the fact they are subject to strict California laws on privacy, as well as strict European Union privacy regulations for any device or app sold in member countries.

" Can this make it easier for hackers since there's now a single point of attack? MVPDs: Cable operators and other providers would have to use a common content encryption technology (DTCP-IP), creating a single point of attack for hackers. DTCP-IP also does not support today's rapidly evolving video business models. FCC: That is a reference to what CVCC is asking, said one official, and the chairman's proposal "is not that." He said the chairman's proposal "recognizes there are a wide variety of methods for protecting content from theft and misuse, and TV providers ought to use multiple systems," and so the proposal "does not prescribe any particular content-protection system" so those can evolve. But the proposal does recognize that third parties need access to those content protection systems, whatever they wind up being, so the proposal requires that a pay TV provider license at least one such system on reasonable terms. "There will be no government standard that we select, or even that we approve" and the FCC remains "tech-neutral" on hardware vs. software.

" Doesn't this force MVPDs to essentially give away their guide data? MVPDs: MVPDs would be required to provide program-guide data, which they do not own, to retail devices, thereby exceeding their licenses with guide data suppliers.

FCC: The FCC will seek comment on the "exact level" of information that is needed to pass through from an MVPD to a third party in order to maintain all of the rights the consumer has paid for.

"Could this focus on box-vs.-no box stifl e innovation in next-generation technologies, not to mention the growing demand for apps?

MVPDs: Providers would have to support an expensive legacy technical solution, thereby interfering with plans to deploy next-generation systems and technologies (e.g., IP cable and IPv6).

Moreover, this would force cable operators and others to implement an infl exible, one-size-fi ts-all technology mandate that ignores the video marketplace transition to apps and creates a drag on innovation in the highly dynamic video-device marketplace.

FCC: "That, again, sounds like AllVid. This isn't AllVid.

"It's very clear by everything we have put out that we are very supportive of apps. We think apps are the way of the future and what we are proposing to do is tech-neutral. It does not mandate a box. If people want to develop a box and consumers are happy with boxes, they are welcome to them. But what we are trying to do here is let people innovate, whether they want to do boxes or something that is like the Amazon Fire stick or if they want to do an app. All options are open in the proposal."


Cable operators argue that the market is already pushing them to add cross-platform functionality to platforms such as Comcast's X1 (pictured).

"How would technology standards be decided for this new sharing arrangement?

MVPDs: The proposal relies on standards not yet invented or implemented and would take years to develop - by which time the "solution" will likely have become outdated.

FCC: On the one hand, the official said, cable operators have consistently said they don't want the agency setting a standard and "now they aren't happy with us wanting to let a standards body set the standards, a body we think they should be a part of. It is tough to have it both ways.

"We are requiring the standards be set by an open standards body with participation from MVPDs, CE manufacturers, app developers and generally following the executive guidance on open standards bodies. We don't want to be in the middle of it. It is not a government-mandated standard."

"How does this proposal change what is already happening in the marketplace, with viewers accessing cable and over-the-top side-by-side without the FCC stepping in?

MVPDs: This is a solution in search of a problem.

FCC: "It is very true that some of the larger MVPDs make apps available to certain devices where they entered into contracts with those devices.

"The problem is, today if I open up, say, a Comcast app on my Smart TV, I can't search what is available to me through my Comcast subscription versus what is available to me from Netfl ix. I have to go into each app, search inside that app, get out, go to the next screen if I want to go to Hulu after that.

"The nice thing about being able to let unaffiliated vendors develop apps for devices is that we anticipate functionality very similar to what TiVo does today, allowing consumers to search across all the sources of programming that they have access to because they pay for many of these things. It will be easier for consumers to fi nd the programming they want at the price they want to pay for it."

urn:contentItem:5GY9-HN91-JB20-G45X-00000-00Box Inc at Deutsche Bank Technology Conference - Final2015-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexis091615a5811268.768Box Inc at Deutsche Bank Technology Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Dylan Smith

Box, Inc. - CFO

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: So we are super happy to have Dylan Smith, the CFO of Box, kick off DB's tech event. So welcome, Dylan.

DYLAN SMITH, CFO, BOX, INC.: Thanks, [Carl]. So I did just want to spend a few minutes to kick off just given an overview of earnings announcements, some of the things we've been up to. We had our Q2 earnings announcement a week ago today. And this presentation and our Q&A may contain forward-looking statements, which probably isn't too surprising.

But just to give a bit of an overview, so in Q2 when we are on a January 31 fiscal year-end, so this is the quarter that ended on July 31, we surpassed 50,000 paying businesses. Revenue in the quarter was close to $75 million, so approaching a $300 million annualized run rate and growing at 43% year on year. Billings were right around the same growth rate, up 45% year on year, and we also disclosed an adjusted billings metric that sorted through some of the payment terms and payment duration variability that we see, and that was also 45% year on year. So adjusted billings and calculated billings up 45%.

Continue to show progress on cash flow from operations. So over the first half of the year, cash flow from operations was negative $29 million. Versus last year in the first half, that was about negative $50 million. So both in terms of dollars as well as a percentage of revenues showing pretty significant progress in terms of our overall operating profile as we continue to march down and look to achieve our commitment of positive free cash flow by the end of next year, so five quarters from now or Q4 FY 2017.

And then our customer economics continue to be very strong. So retention rates dollar weighted of 121% over the last 12 months, which means that had we not signed up a single new customer, we would have grown revenue by 21% year on year. And that's a result of primarily fee expansions driving the net expansion rate of 25% year on year, less only 4% customer churn, so very, very strong economics there.

And then not going to go down the full list, but just wanted to highlight we've made a bunch of progress on both new products for the first time since going public just this past January. So that includes Enterprise Key Management, which you may have heard of as one of the big security initiatives that allows our customers to manage their own keys. So that we launched early in this year and have been really -- early this year. And then in Q2 we also released Box Governance for retention management and just deeper compliance and things like that. We've also made a couple of acquisitions in the endpoint security space in 3-D viewing and editing, and we've announced a number of new industries from government to financial services which are going to be big initiatives for us going forward.

And then most recently, we signed a big partnership and what we have called the most meaningful partnership we've ever signed in our history with IBM back in June. And we will talk a bit more about that. And then we continue to see the message resonating and really strong validation in the market from Gartner and Forrester in terms of the technologies built and just the leadership position that we are building as well. And then last month, we also announced that we brought in Jeetu Patel to run our platform business and as our Chief Strategy Officer, and that really just shows the importance of the platform business going forward and a lot of the bets we are making in that space.

And just at a very high level with IBM, it really is something where we are spending most of this year really aligning our go-to-market efforts, building out the technology, and building these joint roadmaps. So a lot of deep integrations on the mobile app development front, so tying in really nicely with our respective partnerships with Apple to just think about all the different ways to drive productivity to the enterprise and then really a great way to expand our global markets opportunity and for a way for IBM to take FileNet and some of our other core content assets and extend that into a cloud and mobile environment.

So we're really excited about that relationship. And although it is very early and they are a big company, we've been really pleased with the early progress and have dozens of active customer conversations across the globe.

And the relationship does extend to a whole bunch of the different properties. We focused on enterprise content management. I mentioned FileNet, but it also is everything from analytics with Watson and all the initiatives they have there to some of their security, collaboration, and mobile offerings as well. So a lot of the technology operations that we will be building over the next couple of quarters and go into market with.

And I think we will have time for Q&A at the end, but I will now make my way over -- (multiple speakers)

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: You're welcome to stand there if you'd like. So maybe, Dylan, I will start off the Q&A. Just given that you just talked a little bit about the quarterly results, do you want to elaborate a little bit on the mid-[40s] billings and revenue growth rate? Was there anything that you saw on the quarter, even nuanced shifts in demand that surprised you and Aaron?

DYLAN SMITH: So there wasn't anything too surprising with respect to the quarter. We have -- just because of the model a lot of visibility, especially into the revenue side, and we are seeing more stability in terms of those payment frequencies. So had pretty good visibility into the outcome, and a lot of that growth was really just driven by strong continued traction in some of our larger enterprise customers. So we give out a $100,000 plus deal metric, and we had more than 50% growth in that category of deals. So that was one of the drivers of our growth.

But really in terms of anything it surprised was just the early traction that we've seen with Enterprise Key Management and with Box Governance. So having not just a number of deals actually close in Q2, but dozens of conversations ongoing with prospects for both of those products, so we've been really pleased with the initial response of some of those new areas.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: That make sense. And in your opening comments, you highlighted the big IBM deal. So I think that's worthy of a couple of questions. So I think one question that I have is while the frenemy concept is quite common in Silicon Valley, here you've got a big partnership with a company that itself has a very large enterprise content management business in FileNet. So what are the some of the puts and takes around the partnership vis-a-vis Box and FileNet?

DYLAN SMITH: IBM is less of at this stage a frenemy and a true partner, whereas they started to build out over the past couple of years a content Navigator in the cloud as a way to extend a lot of the content capabilities they have into a mobile environment, into a cloud environment, but pretty quickly realized that it would be a massive undertaking based on the complicated and deep needs of their enterprise customers to replicate what we've done.

And so what they decided to do was still keep, of course, the core content that they have in place, but completely shut down all of the content navigator pieces and instead partner with Box.

So at this stage, there's not a lot of conflict, unlike some companies like Microsoft where we have I think a frenemy relationship in a very real way with IBM. They have made a very big bet to go with Box and recommend that and drive that across their organization in terms of the way to extend the content capabilities of FileNet.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: That make sense. And for those in the audience sharpening their pencils on the billings estimates for Box, Dylan, can you talk a little bit about how that relationship trickles down into your own billings numbers going forward?

DYLAN SMITH: Sure. So I would say that we expect just because of all the things we're doing together and everything we want to build to really make a partnership come to light is we would expect the majority of that impact to really start to take -- to kick off in billings next year or FY 2017, just especially because of some of the deal cycles that we see in these larger enterprises.

That said, we have been really pleased with the engagement as I mentioned. We were at their global sales kickoff. Just happened to happen about a week after we signed the deal, so we got center stage and have been able to get in front of thousands upon thousands of IBMers across the globe. And so we could see some impact as soon as the end of this year in our Q4, but would expect the bulk of it to start coming in billings and revenue next year.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay. And maybe one other aspect of the Box-IBM deal that at least caught my attention is that Box is getting integrated with their mobile device management to mobile first. To me that's interesting because I was also the other day glancing at the Box Works agenda, and I noticed that a fellow named Tim Cook is scheduled to attend. So there seems to be a little bit more of a mobile angle to the Box story. Do you mind elaborating on that?

DYLAN SMITH: Sure. So we've been a mobile focused company for a very long time actually. So I think back in 2006 or 2007 is when Aaron -- my co-Founder, our CEO and I were declaring it, this is the year of mobile. And year after year after year, we were wrong for a number of years until the iPad came out, and Apple really gave a reason for enterprises to be bringing mobile in productivity use cases. And that's when we really started to see an uptick, and that was a huge catalyst for our business back in the 2011/2012 timeframe as CIOs were grappling with the way to give these tools to their employees, and Box very quickly built native applications. So we were almost the only game in town to do that, and that was very basic productivity enablement use cases.

Now where we are seeing the evolution with Apple and with our partnership, as well as with IBM is, it's much more focused on these targeted use cases that are going to drive much more business value. So whether that is building custom content applications for your field sales team, whether that is point-of-sale applications, so your retail associates or Disney employees in a theme park can have access to the latest information that they need to serve customers or even to a patient application for a major -- a hospital to be able to access information in real time or more seamlessly sign in, get the information -- those are the types of things that we're building with Apple and with IBM that is very different from what mobile meant to us even just a couple of years ago.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay. And maybe before I go on, just because this IBM-Box deal is very big for you, does anybody in the audience want to press Dylan a little bit more on the IBM partnership before we move to some other questions?

No? Okay. So let's keep going.

Another big partner obviously is Microsoft. So I would love to understand that a little bit better. Obviously they've got share points. They are integrating it with Office 365, too. So where is the angle where Box can play a part with Microsoft?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, so Microsoft is definitely more in that frenemy category, and they are very motivated to sell as many Office 365 licenses as possible. That's a huge strategic initiative/imperative for them. And I think what they found is to do that, it serves their interest, as well as this more open approach that they are taking under [Satcha] to be able to provide a best-in-class content management and file sharing and collaboration experience for their customers.

And so we actually see -- while SharePoint is something that they have really been deemphasizing over time and rolling that into broader -- the broader Office 365 piece, what they've done more recently and what gets us really excited is they are treating us as a first-class citizen as it relates to content.

So when you look and you are in Outlook or your in Office Online, both from a save to and an open from standpoint, Box is right there side-by-side with OneDrive. And I think the reason for that is they want to make sure they are giving their customers' options to be credible and to drive as many workloads and as much stickiness from Office 365 as possible. And more and more as we scale and become an important player in the enterprise, they are hearing from customers that are very, very important to them like Eli Lilly and Toyota and GE that we have made a major bet on our content strategy on Box, and if Box and Office 365 don't work together well, that's going to create some pretty big challenges for us.

And so I think that combination of factors, both the sort of experienced self in creating these seamless content experiences, as well as market pressures, have really caused Microsoft to want to open up the platform. And so, of course, all else equal, they are still going to want to put all of the storage and everything on OneDrive, but they've definitely changed their tune over the last couple of quarters and given us a great opportunity to work with Office 365, as well as Outlook, their mobile applications, etc.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Got it. Okay. And just working through the other big tech players that in various ways bumped into Box, EMC is another one. And on the surface, they should be a formidable opponent given that A, they are making a big push into cloud, and B, they've got a very big ECM franchise. I think in the recent news, they sold their simplicity unit to a consortium of private equity firms, and I'm wondering why did they bail from the space, and does their elastic cloud storage offering still compete with Box at all?

DYLAN SMITH: So I think it's the same reason that we've seen a lot of players either deemphasize or look to evolve their strategy in this space. Over the last few years, we've seen -- I don't think it's an exaggeration to say dozens of new entrants. But over the past 12 months, I think we are starting to see some folks leaving the play -- the space. A lot of independent players are now kind of looking for buyers, and I think it's really because as much as EMC has every right to be in the space, I think it's just not interesting for them to have a 4% market share, something like that. And so they think about -- especially as it's a very different model for them with respect to the cloud is it probably makes more sense to double down on the core things that they do really well and leave this to partnerships and other players to be able to meet those needs for their customers.

I think we will see more of that in that consolidation and divestitures over time. But today, to answer the second question, we don't really compete directly with EMC's elastic cloud services. Occasionally, there will be use cases where, I am thinking about the ROI use case as large enterprises are moving more and more content onto Box, that might allow them to buy less from an EMC or a NetApp or something like that on the pure storage side. But in terms of a head-to-head competitive situation, we don't really run into EMC very often.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Got it. And my last question, filling out the competitive discussion is on Citrix. They have obviously got a rival product, but as everybody knows, Citrix has gone through a significant restructuring of late, and I am wondering if Citrix is popping up anymore, any less on your radar, let's say, in the last six months or so. Any change worth calling out?

DYLAN SMITH: No major trajectory change as it relates to Citrix. ShareFile is the competitive product that they have in this space, and we still do see them from time to time, typically not in the large enterprise conversations that we are focused on. That's where it does tend to be more off in a Microsoft conversation. So we will see them from time to time, but I would say the trajectory is probably flat or possibly slightly down in terms of how often we see those guys.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay. And I would love to ask you next, Dylan, about a comment you made on the recent call about pricing being relatively stable. So to me that's a positive given that you've got a number of big companies that want to be in this space. So the fact that you have kept the pricing stable to me is strong, and could you talk a little bit about what some of the puts and takes are that end up with a relatively stable pricing environment?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, I would say the biggest thing is just the investments that we've made over the last few years in building more and more functionality and differentiating in our product. And more often -- I mean we still will see the use cases of pretty basic enterprise file sync and sharing. But more and more, we are seeing people understand the value they can get out of a service-like box, and in those situations, especially in the enterprise, there just aren't a lot of other options out there that go as deep. And that's why although we are selling to larger customers and with large deployments, we give volume discounts, we have still been able to maintain stable pricing even in the face of that because, on an apples to apples basis, if we are selling 1000 seats two years ago versus today, we actually commanding a higher price point.

And so it really comes down to just building on our leadership position in the enterprise, as well as building out more and more technology. And it's not been through some of these new products that I mentioned that are really starting to come to market for the first time. So it is Enterprise Key Management, Box Government, the Box Developer Edition that we announced, and will be generally available in Q3. All of those things represent even additional upside as we think about the pricing strategy.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay. And Dylan, as you just described Box moving into large enterprise, bigger deals, one key part of the story that is enabling you to pull that off is this verticalization approach. And I think you've announced that so far there's been a push around three verticals. I think it's healthcare, media entertainment, and retail. If I am right, could you talk a little bit about why those three verticals to start and what the roadmap to add new verticals looks like?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, so when we tend to think about our vertical strategy, it's really -- usually we will start with what are the major markets for us? We're already seeing success and so focus a lot on the professional services space as well. But in many cases is we look in the areas where there are either industry-specific workflows and use cases that we can go after from a platform standpoint and areas where our focus on compliance and security are going to be differentiators as well. So in some of the spaces you mentioned, you are really opening the door and making that push possible where our investments and achieving HIPAA compliance and PCI compliance for healthcare and retail respectively, now a major focus, especially going forward on financial services.

We've talked about government as well, so it tends to be that combination of areas where by really building these relationships with customers, we can add an extra layer of value where it's not using just the horizontal capabilities of Box, but setting ourselves apart by understanding and building some of those workflows, as well as the compliance side are really what we look at. But now we have either launched or announced really the major verticals we think are going to allow us to accelerate our growth.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay. And just to press you a little bit on the healthcare side, some of those in the audience follow a company, Viva, which is really the CRM SaaS play, but they've expanded their offering into the content management space attacking big pharma particular. Is that part of your definition of healthcare, or are you going after other components to that pretty broadly defined vertical?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, so we tend to think about our push -- while pharma is a part of it and we have some very large pharmaceutical companies, I think they just may only do really well a specific part of that lifecycle and where the content really matters, and we take a more general approach around -- might be a pharma company, but how do we solve the content management collaboration needs across the entire firm?

So that might be things where it is the field sales enablement I mentioned briefly where you are giving iPads to thousands of pharmaceutical reps to go out and sell their customers in areas like that. So really just I think a broader part of the lifecycle, but we don't go quite as deep into some of those pieces. So we really rarely see Viva in competitive situations.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay. And you had mentioned that financial services will likely be a big push. I think you just opened up a big New York office. You hired Adam Ross I think to run that vertical, right? Maybe you can talk a little bit about the challenges of convincing a big bank like Deutsche Bank to embrace Box. Obviously it's a different beast. There are compliance and regulatory issues to deal with. What makes cracking the financial services market so attractive to you, and what are some of the challenges?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, I think -- what's attractive to us is just some of the challenges and the state of technology in a lot of different areas, and I would say that Adam is really going to be tasked with identifying what are the biggest opportunities that we can focus our efforts in the highest value use cases, and a lot of it if we're looking at a opportunity like Deutsche Bank. First, we want to understand where are the biggest pain points and where they are not able to meet the business needs, whether that's on the investment banking side or retail banking, wealth management, etc., and really go in there and see where are the gaps.

But I would say that some of the challenges that are pretty unique are large banks tend to have not just in terms of being able to get our foot in the door, compliance and regulatory challenges. That's where FINRA compliance, everything that the SEC requires, etc. are really important and investments that we've made to enable this.

I would say large banks also have quite a bit of focus on both the security side of things, deeper than most verticals as you know and would imagine, as well as controlling their own information and really giving differentiated customer experience. And so they are customers.

So on the first one on the security front, that's really where this Enterprise Key Management comes in, and that's been really helpful in terms of allowing us to have some of these conversations. It really was a nonstarter because there's still a lot of large banks who are a little bit hesitant to go all in with the cloud, and so the ability to actually manage their own encryption keys is another layer of security that's been really helpful.

As it relates to these specific customer experiences, that is really where we think we have a huge opportunity with the Box Developer Edition where we can work with these financial services customers and work with a Deutsche Bank to say, okay, what is really important for this process and for these customers? You can actually build those custom content experiences on top of the Box platform, fully customizable for what you need, own that IP, own that experience end to end, but have with that, all of the permissions, security, content management, collaboration capabilities that you get with our core platform. And so that's really the way we think about it is that combination of compliance, security, and ownership are some of the challenges that we think we are really well positioned to solve for our customers and why we get so excited about the opportunity.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And Dylan, does the new Box Governance feature play to that focus on security, data access -- ?

DYLAN SMITH: Absolutely. Both security, as well as compliances, and everything around information rights management to be able to set retention policies where, for example, you might not be able to delete information for seven years and where that might have normally been what would be -- you use a write once, read many or WORM drive to be able to put that information on. We have now architected those same capabilities into our software so it becomes a much easier to manage and less expensive proposition that fulfills the same compliance needs but using the Box platform.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay. And just a minute ago, you talked a little bit about the Box platform? Do you mind elaborating on that? How that will be differentiated from some of the other SaaS companies that are trying to build out platforms? I think you just hired actually, if I'm not mistaken, from EMC a new individual to head up that unit. How will you differentiate yourself, Dylan, and how big could that platform part of the Box story end up being five years from now?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, so that's where really driving that strategy and -- both from a product standpoint and go to market standpoint, that's what Jeetu Patel, who is the CEO of Simplicity over at EMC, is going to be tasked with. But the way we think about it, there's really -- the most interesting opportunity is using a platform to extend our market opportunity into these B2B2C use cases. So where we might have a customer who is already using Box for their corr employee or external collaborator content management collaboration. But now saying how do we provide and power these new digital experiences for their customers? And that's where we see both within regulated industries, as well as within even nonregulated businesses, a huge opportunity to change the content experience and just to make a much better experience for close to the value chain to our customers' customers.

And that's really the main focus of our platform initiative, which is something that most other platform companies haven't done in the past. There's also going to be an IFV component, so that's where you can think about something similar to a force.com. So I think that's a pretty big corollary there in terms of the way that we want to give all the tools for these developers to build their businesses with Box at the back end and make sure they don't need to rebuild everything around security and permissions and things that we've already done. And so that's another big piece of it. And both are going to be under Jeetu's purview going forward.

And I would also just note that that is going to be a big focus of ours at BoxWorks, which is our annual user conference coming up in just a couple of weeks in San Francisco. So we're going to talk a lot more about the evolution of the platform and what that means going forward.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And Dylan, it sounds like your -- Box is bulking up on the leadership front and adding a lot of terrific people. I think another individual you added recently was Paul Chapman, the former CIO of HP Software, correct?

DYLAN SMITH: That's right.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: So maybe talk a little bit about when he comes aboard, what will he and the team focus on in terms of changing Box's underlying data infrastructure? What's the vision?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, so I'd say that already as you might imagine, we've taken a cloud first approach to our internal technology stack. So Box at the center and what would be a number of best-of-breed applications. And we do manage our own data center infrastructure, and he is going to be very focused on especially the networking, the collaboration, and the connectivity across our sites is not going to be specifically running the production infrastructure, but is going to be more focused on our internal applications and all of the things we can do to really show to our customers the gold standard of a cloud-based environment at scale, especially as we grow with Box at the center.

And so one of the things that I think is a huge opportunity both for Box and for our customers over time as we build out these platform initiatives is all of the different workflows, use cases, and really bleeding edge things that we can do with the Box platforms. That's something that Paul is going to be very focused on, as well as hardening the overall data strategy and showing what we can do.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Okay. Why don't I take a quick break and see if anybody in the audience -- I know everyone is still waking up. Any questions for Dylan you would like to ask?

I will keep powering through then.

Let's turn to one question on the financials. Not so much on the revenue and billings line, which I opened with, but more on the bottom line. Everyone always wants you to get to break even faster. I'm sure you have taken that question a lot over the last year. So I think you have communicated some cash flow breakeven guidance, correct? Maybe you could repeat that for the audience, talk a little bit about the path to get there, and if you can say anything about earnings, non-GAAP operating margin breakeven, that would be great, too.

DYLAN SMITH: Sure. So we would say we are very committed to achieving positive free cash flow by the end of next year. So in Q4 of fiscal 2017, which is about five quarters from now, is when we are committed to hitting that breakeven point and then being free cash flow positive in the following year. So our FY 2018 or effectively, calendar 2017, and every year thereafter. So that's a really important, I think, milestone and commitment for the Company.

And we've shown pretty strong progress just as we scaled and as we've really managed the spending and driven leverage especially on the sales and marketing side is how we plan to get there is just continued execution on those fronts. And I mentioned briefly that we've seen pretty strong progress and pretty solid progress over the first half of this year, producing our overall operating cash flow consumption pretty noticeably and as a percentage of revenue going from negative 51% to negative 21% year on year. And so just continuing to do those things is how we're going to drive the cash flow.

Breakeven -- with respect to the operating income breakeven, that's going to be still trailing that by at least a couple of years. And some of it we've not talked about as explicitly for that breakeven point, but would say that over time can expect us to continue to drive leverage in all the line items of the P&L.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Got it. Okay. And maybe my last one is you touched a little bit on this, but you've got your big BoxWorks event coming up in a couple of weeks as you said in San Francisco. I think you're going to do an analyst day there as well. Can you give Deutsche Bank's clients a little sneak preview of what's coming? I don't think you want to open the kimono too much, but what are the big themes that you are going to be pressing on at BoxWorks this year?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, so I don't want to steal too much of Aaron's thunder, but I would say that a big focus is going to be this platform business. So everything around the Box Developer Edition, what that means, and how we're thinking about the evolution of the business going forward. We see just going back to the size of the opportunity that four or five years from now in terms of our new bookings, it could literally be 50% on what people consider core and what Box is today on the content management collaboration side and 50% on the platform side. And so we do see it as a huge opportunity, and I don't think it's something that we've talked as much about or that people really appreciate about the Company's potential. So that's going to be a big focus area, as well as just continuing to talk about all the things we are doing on the partnership front, with mobility, etc. without getting into the specifics.

And then I would say as it relates to Analyst Day specifically, which is going to be on 30 September, is we are going to really dive much deeper into that path to becoming cash flow positive and how we think about that and some of the levers there, as well as some of the trends we're seeing from a competitive standpoint, and we will also get an opportunity to sit down with Adam Ross and (technical difficulty)

urn:contentItem:5N5W-9S71-JB20-G3FV-00000-00Box Inc at Morgan Stanley Technology, Media & Telecom Conference - Final2017-03-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:40ZLexisNexis030217a8656911.711Box Inc at Morgan Stanley Technology, Media & Telecom Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Aaron Levie

Box, Inc. - CEO, Co-Founder, Chairman

* Dylan Smith

Box, Inc. - CFO, Co-Founder

Conference Call Participants

* Melissa Gorham

Morgan Stanley - Analyst

Presentation

MELISSA GORHAM, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: We're very happy today to have Aaron Levie, CEO of Box, and Dylan Smith, CFO of Box. So, very timely to have you guys here.

AARON LEVIE, CEO, CO-FOUNDER, CHAIRMAN, BOX, INC.: Yes, to talk about the Snapchat IPO.

MELISSA GORHAM: (laughter). No.

AARON LEVIE: I thought that was half the questions. Is that not the case?

MELISSA GORHAM: That's for later. No, but it's timely because you reported Q4 earnings last night, and so I guess maybe a good way to start is, Aaron, if you can maybe just recap what you thought the highlights were for Q4, and then we can get into some of the details.

AARON LEVIE: Yes. So it was a record quarter for us on a bunch of accounts. We generated and reported $110 million in topline revenue. We closed the year at about $399 million in revenue. We generated $10 million in free cash flow. That was something that we told the investors about two years ago when we were going public that at the tail end of FY17, that's when we'd be able to hit the free cash flow positive. So we had been on a march for a couple years driving the business to ensure that we could both grow pretty significantly on the topline, as well as achieve that free cash flow positive point.

We reached over 71,000 customers globally. It was also a record quarter in terms of all of our big deal segments, so 64 deals over $100,000 so that's our -- we track sort of annual contract values of large customer segments, so 64 deals with over $100,000. Record deals over $500,000, record deals over $1 million.

And ultimately, what we're seeing in the market is that the past 10 years of all the product that we've been building, the organization that we've been building, has led us to be able to build a leading position in cloud content management, and more and more enterprises are actually going out and deploying our overall set of solutions and capabilities. Box Governance, which is a product that we launched about a year and a half ago, has now been sold over 700 times into the customer base, and with new customers, it was also a record quarter for the number of customers of Box Governance.

So overall, a very, very strong quarter, significant improvements on things like sales and marketing, spend as a percentage of revenue, 14 points of improvement year over year, and so just very happy about the topline results of the business and then generating cash, obviously, was a very important milestone for the Company.

MELISSA GORHAM: Okay. Great. That's helpful. Maybe if we can just start on the partnerships, because I think that was maybe one of the notable pieces coming out of the quarter. And, obviously, IBM is a big part of that. I think you said 18 out of 64 large deals are coming from IBM, so it seems like it certainly is ramping well, but I'm just wondering if you can maybe talk about where you are in the maturity of that relationship. And then, is that -- this kind of traction, is this what we're going to expect throughout FY18?

AARON LEVIE: So our partnership strategy overall, if you think about where we sit in the ecosystem, our mission is to make sure that we can help companies manage, secure, govern all of their content, all of their information in one place, and then extend that out into any application or service that they are using.

So inherently in our business model, we're already very, very partner centric. We work a lot with Microsoft. We announced a partnership at the tail end of last year with Google. We work with Facebook with their enterprise product, with Slack, and many other services, and so the core value proposition of Box is that we are going to be a neutral, agnostic player that plugs into the rest of your technology environment and helps you secure and manage your information.

IBM has been a really significant partner for us in both building on top of our platform, building applications and services for their customers, as well as reselling Box into their customer base. And if you kind of think about where IBM is biggest, when you think about governments all around the world, banks, large industrial businesses, healthcare providers, these are the areas where we're seeing traction through the IBM partnership, so customers in either industries or geographies where we don't necessarily have as many feet on the ground.

And so throughout all last year it was really kind of a ramping period for us in building the partnership, culminating in really strong performance in Q4 where they did close -- where we closed with them 18 deals over $100,000. And then if you kind of zoom out to the broader partner landscape, nearly half of our $100,000 deals or above came through our channel partners. So, if you look at the overall channel model broadly, whether it's with telco partners like AT&T, technology partners like IBM, or even system integrators and resellers like Macnica in Japan, all of these partners are actually contributing and driving more growth of our business in both regions and industries where we don't necessarily have as much of a direct sales force.

So we think that the IBM partnership is a really great template for how we can do large partnerships at scale with big tech companies, big telcos, system integrators, and we're not only going to continue to scale the IBM partnership this coming year, but ultimately try and repeat that success with many other partners in our ecosystem. So we're really happy about the level of investment that we made this year, the return that that created, and also the kind of proof point of what we can do from a partnership standpoint.

I'm going to say one more thing, but the -- I think if you look at SaaS generally, you rarely see as much of a partner-centric or channel-centric or even system integrator-centric approach that we can deliver, and the reason for that is customers are looking for partners to be able to help them retire legacy systems, to be able to migrate their data to the cloud, deliver solutions through mobile environments, and so we happen to have a very -- a type of product and a platform that naturally fits within an ecosystem of so many different players, and that's why you're going to see a pretty significant ramp in growth, due to our partnerships.

MELISSA GORHAM: Right, okay. So I guess kind of related to that and just taking it one step higher, Aaron, I believe you describe Box as a modern cloud content platform, but if you go back, let's say, five or even 10 years, everyone thinks of Box or your competitors as file, sync, and share. To what extent --

AARON LEVIE: We still think of our competitors as file, sync, and share.

MELISSA GORHAM: To what extent has the customer conversations changed such that they are coming to you for this content platform or is this just plain file, sync, and share?

AARON LEVIE: So 12 years ago when we started Box, the first use case we had was how do you share files from any device with anyone, anywhere. That was the core use case we had.

What we didn't even realize was there was this multibillion-dollar market for companies that were spending so much time, energy, and resources on traditional forms of content management. The reason we started Box was because we were running into this end-user problem that was very akin to what the market thinks of as enterprise file, sync, and share.

But very quickly, enterprise file, sync, and share functionality reached a plateau. Within a couple years of us existing, we had built all of the major capabilities that we would think of as enterprise file, sync, and share, and so the big opportunity that we recognized eight, nine years ago was as companies began to move their information and their content to the cloud, they would need modern ways of securing, governing, controlling, and ensuring compliance around all of their content.

And when we looked at that industry, that was the traditional domain of enterprise content management, of storage infrastructure, of security technology, of some of the system integrators or consulting teams that were working on compliance for your information. And so we saw this disruptive opportunity where if we took those capabilities, built them in a modern cloud-first, mobile-centric, end-user-centric kind of way, we would actually be able to go and disrupt this multi-tens of billions of dollars industry.

Now customers, though, have had to take a bit of a journey to be able to actually see Box in that way, for us to be able to sell Box in that way, and be able to actually kind of move customers through the maturity of their lifecycle. And so, if I go back -- if we go back five or six or seven years ago, most of the early adopters of Box in large enterprises, whether it was Procter & Gamble or General Electric or Eli Lilly, they were using Box as a modern sort of file, sync, and share product across their enterprise, but the reason they chose us was due to this longer-term vision.

When we fast forward to today, most of our large enterprises, especially those that are deploying this enterprisewide, are buying us because what they are trying to do is have one system of record for their content management in the cloud. When we look at all of our transactions that are in the $500,000 segment and above or $1 million segment and above, these are companies that are often using Box to retire legacy systems. We had one financial services customer that was able to retire -- will be retiring a Documentum deployment, as well as consolidating their EFSS capabilities, so file, sync, and share capabilities, into Box.

So we want to solve that entire spectrum of use cases, everything from that end user, that first use case we saw 12 years ago, the end user that wants to be able to share files and collaborate, all the way to being the system of record where your legal team is going to manage their contracts or your marketing team is going to manage their digital assets or the insurance claims team is going to be able to manage all the insurance claim documents. That's really where the ultimate spend is, and we're the only company in the cloud that has built all of the sort of modern core capabilities to be able to solve that and we still have a very expensive roadmap to build an even stronger position in this market going forward.

DYLAN SMITH, CFO, CO-FOUNDER, BOX, INC.: And just to go on that a bit, I think we've been talking about and building this vision for many years now, but it is a pretty notable change. Just over the past few quarters, as you have Box zones and our governance capabilities and a lot of our compliance capabilities really coming together, so for customers is actually the reality that they can retire some of these legacy systems, we think that's going to provide a pretty meaningful catalyst for us to be able to rip and replace more of their systems and increase our contract value.

So in addition to the firm Aaron mentioned, we had a large energy company in the Asia-Pacific region retiring OpenText, a very large life sciences company based in the UK who is going to be retiring Documentum as well. And so realizing that time to value now by deploying Box not just for end-user productivity and collaboration, but to have pretty meaningful cost replacement as well is something that we are now able to deliver to customers and we're pretty excited about.

AARON LEVIE: And I think, just one more build on that, if you look at sort of the best in class or best of breed categories of technology, I think if you go talk to customers it's very clear that the world is moving to the cloud for CRM. It's very clear that the world is moving to the cloud for HCM or HR/IS. It's very clear that the customer is moving to the cloud for IT service management.

There hasn't been a company or a product that's been able to take all of the capabilities or all the use cases that a Documentum and OpenText, traditional content management systems, have been able to solve for and have a cloud-first model to be able to deliver that, and that's what we've been building over the past, again, five, six, seven, eight years.

And so, we're at a point where the product is mature enough where we can go attack some of these more regulated use cases, these more extensive, complex use cases, and the good news is we already have a number of the customers, so we're in over 60% of the Fortune 500 today. And so, our opportunity is to go after all those customers and have them start to use Box more as a system of record for their information, not just as an end-user collaboration and sharing tool.

MELISSA GORHAM: Okay. So over the past year, you've been able to execute well to this large opportunity. You are definitely winning large deals. You are increasing the upsell opportunity, while also at the same time really keeping sales and marketing expense relatively low in terms of growth, in the most recent quarter 2% growth in sales and marketing.

I guess two questions on that. The first is what's enabled you to sustain 30%-ish topline growth, but also only growing sales and marketing low single digits? But then moving forward, your guidance, I think, is assuming an acceleration, so why do you feel as though you need to pump the pedal on the sales and marketing expense in 2018?

DYLAN SMITH: Sure. So, really pleased with the leverage we've been able to drive over time. The majority of that both historically and then going forward is in sales and marketing line, so our operating margin this past quarter was negative 12% versus negative 37% Q4 the year prior.

A few things that are driving that. So one of the things we've been really pleased with the results in is the growth in our self-serve, online sales engine. So that channel nearly doubled its contribution to the business this past year, and we're also moving more and more customers through that channel, which has allowed our sales force to move upmarket, so that's allowed us -- while we only grew actual rep headcount by about 10% over the past year, that understates the actual capacity and reach that we've been able to drive, and I think a lot of the growth and maturation of our channel relationships have also helped to extend the sales force to, again, drive the amount of pipeline we are able to build and conversations we are able to have at a much faster rate than the actual growth in our sales headcount.

Another driver of this has been our continued focus on serving customers more efficiently, so our free user base and the cost for all of those users, which is a sales and marketing expense, was 5% of revenue this past quarter. That's down from 10% the year prior. And then, just continuing to drive rep productivity improvements as well has been a big focus. So, we increased billings per rep by about 12% this past year and saw similar improvements the year prior.

And then as we move forward, we still think a lot of these same trends are going to play out over time. Would say that while we are not going to be moving that self-serve line again this year, so we won't expect to see the same sort of step function leverage in the coming year, we do think we have the opportunity to continue expanding that universe of customers as we go forward. So we wouldn't describe that as sort of a one-time improvement, but something that we'll continue to work on over time.

We also this year, to speak also on the investment side of things, are going to be making some pretty core investments in our marketing infrastructure and technology stack to be able to scale more efficiently over time. And then on the sales front, we think about that and it really is a balance between growth and profitability and make those decisions really based on the opportunity we're seeing in the market, the pipeline that's building, et cetera, and that's what gives us the confidence to grow our quota-carrying headcount by about 25% in the coming year.

And part of that is seeing some new opportunities open up, partly through some of the products that Aaron has been talking about, but internationally, in particular our Japan business has been growing really nicely. Now that we have this sort of core compliance capabilities and products to go after the German market, we're going to be making some investments there. So we're very, very focused on continuing to drive rep productivity improvements, sales efficiency improvements, and you can get a sense of that in terms of how we're thinking about the longer-term growth if you look at the model that we put out a couple of quarters ago at our analyst day where, when we are at $1 billion in revenue, we expect to have operating margins just north of 10%. But it's not necessarily going to be a completely linear path to get there, particularly given the size of the market and the opportunity that we're seeing at this moment in time.

MELISSA GORHAM: Got it. That's helpful. So you noted improved sales productivity. You said 12% increase in billings per sales rep, I believe. You are guiding to 25% growth in quota-carrying sales heads and you're also guiding to revenue up about 25%-ish year over year. Why wouldn't revenue grow faster if you're seeing improved sales productivity?

DYLAN SMITH: So we know certainly from an initial guidance point of view, we do see, if we are able to execute on some of these opportunities and there's upside we've talked about, could see that higher.

The only thing I'd note is most of these reps will be a largely, ideally frontloaded plan from a hiring standpoint. It does take us about nine months to fully ramp an inside sales rep, about a year to fully ramp our field reps, so even the reps that we're hiring today we wouldn't expect to really start contributing until the back half of the year, and most of that is not going to show up in revenue for this year, but rather on a go-forward basis.

MELISSA GORHAM: Okay, got it. I just want to shift to competition and make sure that we address that because that's definitely an area that investors focus on because your competition are the largest vendors in the tech world, Microsoft, Google. It sounds like Microsoft, you certainly have a good relationship from a partnership perspective, and one of the areas that you talk about is just your security and enterprise capabilities that distinguish you. Why can't Microsoft catch up on those capabilities and why are they playing so nice with you when they actually compete directly with you?

AARON LEVIE: So let me do the last question first. I think when you look at the state of enterprise software today, it is breeding out of necessity, in some cases, more than anything it's breeding the need for players to be able to interoperate and begin to work together.

We're in a multiplatform, multi-stack world that's not like it was in the 2000s or the 1990s where Microsoft or Oracle or SAP could sort of own the entire stack. And so when you're Microsoft today, and if you even look around this room, you have iPads, you have Android devices, you have Windows PCs, you have MacBooks, and so they are in a completely different world than they were when they could control the whole stack.

So they recognize that, to be able to serve their customers successfully, they have to partner with third-party solutions and external companies. That's the first thing that's sort of happening from a culture change at Microsoft and within the industry.

For us specifically in terms of competing with Microsoft, I think first and foremost our customers actually want a neutral provider to be the backbone of how they manage their information and their content. If you put all of your data in just one of these vendors, it reduces your ability to have a futureproof solution that can integrate with all the different applications that you're using. Maybe one day you are going to use Slack, maybe the next day you are going to use Facebook at work, maybe the next day you are going to use Gmail. You want to be able to have a solution that can connect to any of the applications that are in your environment without having to worry about will that content management system successfully integrate with those solutions.

So actually in this area, being agnostic and being a neutral independent player is actually an advantage for our customers, which is where they see us in the stack as being that open platform that they can leverage.

Competitively and from an innovation standpoint, I think when you look at the architecture of Microsoft solutions, this is also a point of advantage. So Microsoft is competitive with us, yes, but they actually have multiple solutions that they are trying to use to help customers be able to share and manage their information.

We think that's architecturally the wrong approach for this industry. So they have a product that you might be familiar with called OneDrive; that's their end-user sort of file, sync, and share solution. They also have a traditional service called SharePoint, which is their traditional content management and collaboration system.

We think that the future architecture actually demands that those aren't two different systems, so there is actually one platform, there's one cloud content management system that companies can have to be able to manage their data because you actually don't want to fragment your data, depending on whether you are trying to access content from a mobile device or trying to collaborate externally.

And so architecturally, we have a fundamentally different point of view around the future of this market, which gives us a decade-long headstart in terms of the category that we're building out in. So it's not a matter of building out more features to replicate Box. In fact, the more features they build out, actually the more they make the challenge harder for their customers.

So we think that due to the openness that Microsoft is driving, that leads to a really strong partnership. We think that we have a number of integration points that our customers value, so we're integrated pretty deeply into Office 365. We're integrated into some parts of Outlook. You can imagine that we're exploring ways of looking at Azure, just as we work with other major cloud providers. We integrate very deeply into Windows. So when you look at the total tie of the services that Microsoft cares about, we're actually a very strong partner or complement to probably 90% to 95% of their technologies and only competitive in a very limited area for them.

MELISSA GORHAM: Got it. Okay. That's helpful.

AARON LEVIE: And maybe the only other final point is when you look at any of our large customers, if we look at the 64 deals above $100,000 last year -- last quarter, sorry, the majority of those will be enterprises that either have or will be deploying Office 365. So it's not as if when you buy Box, you don't buy Office 365, or vice versa. We're deploying alongside Office 365 in most large enterprise environments.

MELISSA GORHAM: Got it. Okay. Let me just ask one on the upsell opportunity and then I'm going to open it up to the audience for questions. So, you've been broadening the platform around Box. You have enterprise key management. You have governance, which you talked about yesterday, really ramping well, platform. The average price per seat has stayed relatively stable at $100 per user, so when are we going to start to see the average selling price move up on a per-seat level as you are penetrating that upsell opportunity?

DYLAN SMITH: So we've seen stability over the past several years and feel pretty good about continuing to drive at least stable pricing at $100 per user per year.

There's a little bit of a dynamic of puts and takes here where we've been able to maintain price per seat, and that's been partially helped by the traction we're seeing with some of these newer products, but at the same time you're seeing much larger deployments, typically a pretty steady and meaningful increase in the number of large deals that we're selling and typically we tend to give volume discounts for those larger deals. And that $100 per user per month is a -- sorry, per year -- is a weighted average, so you're seeing a lot of these larger deals that might come in in the mid single-digit range per user per month for selling 100,000-plus users, for example, but you'll get some benefit from the additional products as well.

So, I think it will be a little bit of a function of how quickly we can sell larger deals with more seats, as well as the traction that we see from some of these products that's ultimately going to determine kind of the balance of those puts and takes, but that's the dynamic, which is why, despite increased traction with the products or because of that, we've been able to hold very stable pricing.

MELISSA GORHAM: Okay. And when you're talking about your longer-term outlook that you laid out at the analyst day, are you assuming significant ASP increases or is it just penetration in the number of seats?

DYLAN SMITH: Yes, so from a price per-seat basis, we expect that to be pretty stable going forward as well because of the dynamics, but overall would expect to see higher average contract values not just because of the increased penetration of some of these newer products, but also as we increasingly go after the heart of the legacy enterprise content management market, those are much more valuable use cases and will typically have larger deals than maybe a departmental enterprise file, sync, and share deployment, for example.

AARON LEVIE: And I think, just to add on that, when you look at a sort of like-for-like customer, when you do add a product like Box Governance or KeySafe, you see a 30% or so uplift in price per seat, and so comparing customers that actually have deployed or purchased those solutions, you do get a pretty material price per-seat uplift. But at the same time, we're doing much larger deployments to much larger customers, which obviously gives the volume discount that Dylan mentioned.

MELISSA GORHAM: Got it. Okay. We have time for one question, if there's any in the audience. I have more, but okay.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Thanks, good morning. Can you discuss how your -- your two new products, Box Notes and Box Relay, help us understand how you are positioning those two products in their respective markets and what's the go-to-market strategy?

AARON LEVIE: That actually is -- they represent kind of two ends of the spectrum of our strategy. So when you think about Box and when you think about cloud content management, we think there's three really important variables to keep in mind.

The first is you have to have the best product for end users who want to be able to share and collaborate and be able to get their work done. You need to be able to have all of the right security, compliance, governance, and control features at the enterprise layer to be able to help companies have a system of record for the data, and then you need an open platform that integrates into all the different applications that our customers use. So those are really the three key focus areas of Box and our product strategy.

Box Notes is really the -- at the end-user level spans the entire spectrum of use cases that we solve. So Box Notes -- I'm sorry, Box Notes and Relay span that entire spectrum. So Box Notes is really for end users that want to be able to share and collaborate and be able to have a knowledge repository for all of the work they are doing with teams.

It's a completely free product. It's available to 100% of our customers. It drives stickiness, it drives active user engagement, and then, ultimately, it becomes a way of helping customers put more and more of their information into Box and providing a secure way for them to manage that data. So we want as many users as possible to put as much information as possible into that product.

Box Relay, on the other hand, is really about powering intelligent workflows for end users and for teams and for the overall business, and that takes us much more into some of the traditional HCM use cases, but done in a much more modern cloud-first or cloud-centric way.

So we're leveraging the workflow technology from IBM, using our sort of design ecos and end-user interface, and we've built and co-designed an end-user process management or workflow solution that lets you do complex process automation for content use cases, so that could be invoice automation, it could be HR document reviews, contract reviews, and so a lot of the traditional workflow that you would have expected in the enterprise content management space, but done in the cloud.

So, both of those products really kind of support the two ends of the end-user spectrum, and Relay will be coming out later this year. We're starting to roll that out with some data customers, and the one thing I would just add is the feedback from customers around us entering this space has been unbelievable. So both Relay specifically, but Workflow broadly, we have had an overwhelming response from customers saying this is exactly what we've been looking for from Box to help us move beyond being able to do end-user file sharing and collaboration, but ultimately to be able to power important and critical business processes on Box.

So I would say that Relay is our first foray into Workflow with enterprises, but you are going to see more capabilities over time both in the Box core product, as well as additional services that allow us to address use cases in the Workflow space.

MELISSA GORHAM: Okay, great. Unfortunately, we're out of time, but thank you so much.

AARON LEVIE: Okay. Thank you. Cool. Take care.
